South Africa still bears the scars of its past of racial division and conflict.
 
Racism takes many forms. It can be found in people’s attitudes and utterances, in how they behave towards each other, in who gets hired for a job or who gets promoted.
Much remains to be done but we believe strongly that Africans have now put the continent on the path to sustained and strong economic growth.

Between 2014 and 2018, South African firms invested over $10.2 billion – R160 billion – in different parts of the continent, making South Africa the 5th largest source of foreign direct investment on the continent in value behind US, France, UK & China.
Eight-eight women-owned companies were assisted to promote their goods and services through various trade promotion and marketing events in the continent.
In the last financial year, 1,029 emerging exporters completed training, of whom 1,006 were black-owned, 494 were women-owned and 227 were youth-owned.

Government has a number of interventions to support South Africans that want to trade & do business in other African countries. The empowerment of black-owned businesses, women & youth through export readiness & export capacity is at top of this agenda.
The African Continental Free Trade Area is a significant development that will change trade patterns and has the potential to transform African economies. #AfCFTA

The vision of African leaders today is aimed at breaking this pattern. We are determined to build strong and inclusive economies through industrialisation and the beneficiation of the minerals and commodities that are extracted from their countries.
Just as colonial powers extracted the continent’s wealth for their own enrichment, today African economies participate in the global economy primarily as a source of minerals and commodities.
In many ways, Africa’s colonial past has continued to shape its economic development over recent decades.
The greater challenge we have, which is a responsibility we all share, is to work together to rid our society of such attitudes and practices altogether.

With the laws and institutions we have in place – which will be reinforced by the passage of the Prevention and Combating of Hate Crimes and Hate Speech Bill – we have a robust legal framework to deal with anyone promoting discrimination & intolerance.
In addition, the Bill of Rights states that: “Everyone has the right to freedom of conscience, religion, thought, belief and opinion.”

There is no place for religious intolerance of any sort in the democratic South Africa.
 
Our Constitution is clear that no person may be discriminated against on the basis of, among other things, religion, conscience, belief, culture or language.
It will also have a direct and tangible impact on the living conditions of many poor and middle-class families who will now have decent housing and reliable access to water and sanitation.
The Economic Reconstruction and Recovery Plan is intended not only to stimulate economic growth and create jobs.
The infrastructure build also includes large water projects in the Western Cape, KwaZulu-Natal, Northern Cape, Eastern Cape and Limpopo
These projects will be labour-intensive to ensure that we stimulate the local economy and ensure collective ownership of the water supply infrastructure.
To date, over 1,300 projects have been scoped by the internal engineering team of the department and about 500 projects are implementation ready.
Water tanks had been delivered to a total of 158 local and district municipalities by the end of August 2020.
As part of government’s response to the COVID-19 pandemic, the Department of Water and Sanitation allocated R306 million to the provision of potable water to communities throughout the country.

The accelerated delivery of serviced residential stands is expected to create a substantial number of job opportunities, largely benefiting women and youth. It will also support the construction industry and provide opportunities to local businesses.
The development of these areas involves the upgrading of informal settlements, the rapid release of serviced land, affordable rental housing and integrated residential developments.
These are areas with specific developmental needs, using indicators such as high levels of urbanisation, unemployment and poverty.
This is in line with the Medium-Term Strategic Framework, which makes provision for the declaration of Priority Human Settlements and Housing Development Areas.

A central pillar of the Economic Reconstruction and Recovery Plan is a massive infrastructure build and maintenance programme.
 
Among the areas of significant infrastructure investment are integrated human settlements.

Ultimately, the courts will make the determination whether the information of the bank accounts of private persons should be made public or not.

While this Act does not extend to the funding of internal party leadership contests, I have said before, that this is perhaps a good time for this House to consider whether it is necessary & desirable for funding of internal party contests to be regulated.

The Political Party Funding Act – which I signed into law last year and which the EFF has consistently opposed – does regulate public and private funding of political parties and requires the disclosure of donations accepted.

I am sure that the Honourable Malema would agree that it would be unreasonable to expect the disclosure of such information until such time that all candidates and all parties are held to the same requirements of disclosure and transparency.

Nor is there a provision for the disclosure of such information in the Executive Ethics Code or in the Code of Ethical Conduct and Disclosure of Members’ Interests for Assembly and Permanent Council Members.
To repeat what I said on this matter in this House on 22 August 2019, there are no rules or regulations in place for the disclosure of donations for internal party leadership contests.
To repeat what I said on this matter in this House on 22 August 2019, there are no rules or regulations in place for the disclosure of donations for internal party leadership contests.

It is therefore not within my power to make any of them public.
 
Absolutely no evidence of corruption or any other form of improper conduct exists in relation to these documents or to CR17 campaign.

The bank statements in question are from accounts over which I do not have control. They belong to entities and private companies which I do not control and whose internal financial affairs are protected by the country’s privacy laws.
Only the FIC can ‘allow’ these documents to be made public.

The FIC has confirmed in its affidavits before court that the information it shared with the Public Protector could only be made public with their express permission, which was not sought by the Public Protector.
The body from whom the Public Protector obtained the bank statements in question, the Financial Intelligence Centre, has consistently opposed the publication of these documents.
As the Honourable Malema should know, it is the EFF – not the Public Protector – that has brought the application to unseal documents related to the Public Protector’s report of July 2019.
As Honourable Members will have seen in recent months, there has been clear evidence of progress in bringing cases to court.
Much of the past two years has been focused on building up the capabilities of the institutions that we rely on to combat corruption and state capture.

The South African Revenue Service is also playing a vital role. It has established the Illicit and Criminal Economic Activities Division, which also focuses on investigations into state capture & tender abuse related to personal protective equipment fraud

Recent amendments to the regulations of the State Capture Commission now allows the Commission to share information, records and documents directly with the Investigating Directorate and any law-enforcement agency in South Africa.
As further evidence of improved cooperation, the Investigating Directorate has also secured forensic accountants and legal resources from SARS, the SIU, FIC, Reserve Bank and State Security Agency.

To enable the Directorate to address complex and organised corruption, personnel have been seconded from the South African Police Service, the Hawks and the Independent Police Investigative Directorate (IPID).
Together with the National Prosecuting Authority, the Hawks have prioritised 10 priority corruption-related cases to fast track for investigation and prosecution.

Since the beginning of this 6th Administration, the Directorate for Priority Crime Investigation – also known as the Hawks – has established task teams to fast track corruption investigations in municipalities, government and the private.
In May this year, we established the fusion centre based at the Financial Intelligence Centre, which serves as an operational hub with dedicated resources to fight COVID-related corruption.

The fight against corruption and state capture has required extensive measures to stabilise and revitalise our law enforcement agencies, with capable and ethical leadership able to restore the credibility of these vital institutions.

As our economy has been steadily opening up and restrictions on movement and activity have been eased, we have been able to turn our attention from emergency measures towards an ambitious plan of economic reconstruction.

We must remember that every additional person we come into contact with increases the chances of transmission. We should avoid large gatherings. We should rather meet in small groups. If we must go out, we should limit contact with others.
What we are witnessing in the Eastern Cape should be a wake-up call to all of us, that we cannot relax and we cannot be complacent
From the progress we have made, from the lessons we have learnt, we now know that under the current alert level 1 we have all the tools we need to prevent a resurgence.

#TaxiLekgotla

We salute you for all you do to keep our country going. And we give you our assurance that we remain committed to doing whatever is necessary to bring the industry into the mainstream so that the invaluable service you provide can be improved.

You are making a difference in the lives of our citizens daily, whether it is a grandmother who needs to go collect her pension, the worker on the way to an office or factory, or a learner who needs to get to school.
Since its inception, the taxi industry has been a lifeline to our people.

What we strive for is for all forms of public transit to be integrated to allow people to seamlessly make use of all modes available. It is only through an integrated system that we are able to offer the best value for money and convenience to the public.
If we are to meet the targets we have set ourselves, an efficient, safe and reliable public transport system will be key to transport the workforce.
Our Economic Reconstruction and Recovery Plan sets out a number of interventions to spur economic activity, to create jobs and to embark on a renewed industrialisation path.

As we rebuild our economy in the wake of the #COVID19 pandemic, the taxi industry needs, and will receive, our full support. You are a critical part of the South African economy & society. You create businesses & support jobs, both directly & indirectly.
This lekgotla must be a turning point for an industry that is too often associated with disregard for the rule of law and the rules of the road, the abuse of customers and conflict.

Formalisation means greater regulation; and the compact that must emerge from this lekgotla must be anchored in the rule of law. We must eradicate illegal operations that affect both the industry and government and are a catalyst for conflict.
I am pleased that issues like access to finance and skills development will also be discussed here, because they are crucial in determining whether a fledgling taxi business succeeds or fails.

We have invested substantially in the Taxi Recapitalisation Programme & will continue to leverage its potential. We will be giving renewed attention to supporting business growth, especially to empower previously disadvantaged individuals such as women.

Just as the industry must itself address and overcome issues of safety and violence, we remain committed to driving interventions that strengthen the industry. That is why among the issues that will be discussed at this lekgotla is that of subsidisation.
We also need to address the conflict relating to competition over routes and the associated acts of violence and criminality.

These include the issue of labour relations and allegations of exploitation of workers; the high number of road accidents involving taxis; the industry’s response to the rise of e-hailing services; and compliance with tax laws.

From this lekgotla, we need to come up with concrete measures to ensure the long-term sustainability of this important industry. We have to address several challenges that have tarnished the reputation of the industry.

At the heart of all our endeavours is formalisation, regulation and economic empowerment.
 
#TaxiLekgotla
We share a common aspiration to see the minibus taxi industry overcome its challenges, adapt in response to the demands of modern public transportation, and ultimately to grow and thrive.

High barriers to entry, such as the cost of vehicle financing and maintenance, is threatening business viability. Badly maintained and old vehicles threaten the safety of passengers and other road users.

The taxi industry is therefore one of the most important sectors in our economy. This makes it all the more necessary that there is transformation and empowerment with real benefits to the businesses involved.

Today, the vast majority of public transport commuters use taxis followed by buses and trains. The industry is a major source of business creation with approximately 150,000 taxi business owners in operation.

The sector emerged at a time when apartheid spatial planning severely restricted people’s access to safe & reliable transport. From its humble beginnings of a few operators, mainly in the urban centres, the industry has grown from strength to strength.

The taxi industry is the lifeblood of our public transport system.
 
Since the late 1970s it has served our people by providing an accessible means of public transit in nearly every corner of the country.

To the world, #ORTambo was the voice of South Africa’s liberation movement. He articulated the aspirations of every South African man, woman and child who yearned for freedom. His name was known around the world, from Oslo to London, from Accra to Moscow.
He spent through three decades in exile, working tirelessly to forge international support for the anti-apartheid struggle.

He dedicated his life to the people of South Africa and to the achievement of democracy. He led the struggle for freedom through its darkest and most difficult moments.

We want to attract higher levels of investment in our natural resources sector, in renewable energies & in agriculture. It is our intention to increase and not decrease social spending to narrow the deep inequalities that exist in our respective countries.

We have to take advantage of the dramatic changes the pandemic has brought to the world of work by equipping our people with the necessary tools and skills to take up occupations in a technology-driven economy.

The pandemic has once again brought to the fore the importance and necessity of universal health care coverage. We have to turn this period of crisis into one of opportunity to build resilient economies on the African continent.
For every African man, woman and child to realise their full potential, we have to continue to invest in poverty eradication, in education and in improving health outcomes.

We are encouraged by moves by the international financial institutions to provide relief to indebted countries, and reiterate our call for a moratorium on interest and debt repayments by stricken countries.
We are continuing to call for a comprehensive economic stimulus to assist African countries to mitigate the effects of the pandemic.
Countries will struggle to meet their obligations to their people, with critical resources having been diverted to fighting the pandemic.

While we acted swiftly to implement a nation-wide lockdown – which delayed the surge in infections – we also put in place significant economic and social relief measures to protect businesses, workers and households.
As the African continent, our response to the pandemic has been both strategic and collaborative.
Protect & Invest in People: Human Capital in the time of #COVID19 #InvestInPeople
#BuildingANewEconomy

The passing of Dr Vuyo Mahlati is a great blow to the agricultural fraternity and to the country as a whole; more so at a time when much of our work around land reform is coming to fruition. Our thoughts & prayers are with her family, colleagues & friends at this difficult time.

The brutal killing of a young white farmer, allegedly by black men, followed by the spectacle of white farmers storming a police station to get to a black suspect has opened up wounds that go back many generations.

Archbishop Tutu is a national treasure and global icon of moral consistency, spiritual virtue and the defence of the most vulnerable people not only in South Africa but around the world. I wish the Arch a very happy birthday in the company of Mama Leah, the family and colleagues.

Today we are united in celebrating the passing of another year in which we have benefited from the Archbishop’s wisdom, the bravery of his conviction in fighting for human rights, the warmth of his love for all South Africans and his care for humanity.

Transforming patterns of agricultural land ownership is vital not just to address the historical injustices of the past, but to safeguard our nation’s food security.

I once again congratulate all who have made this occasion possible. What we are seeing is impressive indeed, and I look forward to seeing this form of integrated development being expanded to all parts of the country.

#GrowSouthAfrica 🇿🇦

The launch of this development is a ray of sunshine in an otherwise gloomy climate. It is a demonstration of our resilience as a country and of the strength of public/private partnership.
 
#GrowSouthAfrica 🇿🇦

#Mooikloof is an excellent example how public/private sector interests can be aligned and work for mutual benefit.

#GrowSouthAfrica 🇿🇦
We will be looking at how best to leverage private sector resources and skills to help government deliver its mandate to provide decent housing to our people.
The reality is that the fiscus cannot on its own support the rising housing demand in the country. #COVID19 has only worsened an already dire situation.

The #Mooikloof Mega City development will also lead to the creation of some 41 000 jobs at a time when they are sorely needed.

#GrowSouthAfrica 🇿🇦
Potential homeowners will also be able to apply for assistance from government’s Finance Linked Individual Subsidy Programme #FLISP #GrowSouthAfrica

The Department of @HumanSettlement through its agency, the Housing Development Agency, is assisting a model to make it possible for more low-income households to benefit from the development.

#GrowSouthAfrica 🇿🇦

@CityTshwane has facilitated approval of appropriate zoning and the provision of water, waste-water, and energy bulk infrastructure. As government we are walking the talk on enabling conditions for development by issuing licences & zoning rights speedily.
The Gauteng Provincial Government is funding the expansion of the Garsfontein provincial road to accommodate the projected increase in vehicle traffic generated by the development.

The successful launch of Mooikloof further reinforces the appropriateness of the District Development Model, and the collaboration of the three spheres of government has made the project possible.
#Khawuleza #GrowSouthAfrica 🇿🇦

Most people are housed 40 KM’s from employment opportunities, as a result, they spend over 40 minutes travelling to and from work, and spend over 40% of their incomes on transport expenses. In many cases those affected are the poor who live in 40m2 houses.
Spatial integration is aimed at undoing a prominent feature of the apartheid project. We continue to feel the effects of apartheid spatial design in what may be termed the 40/40/40 principle.

In the inaugural State of the Nation Address of the 6th Administration, I outlined 7 priority areas that will guide the work of government. Amongst the priority areas mentioned was spatial integration, human settlements & local government.
#GrowSouthAfrica
But by far the most important aspect of this catalytic project is its contribution to inclusionary housing development.
It is pleasing to note the development is being pursued in line with green building principles, and will make optimal use of green belts and green spaces for residential recreation.

Once completed, the #Mooikloof Mega City may end up becoming the world’s largest sectional property development, with land also earmarked for schools, shops and offices.
 
#GrowSouthAfrica 🇿🇦

We seek to unlock the energy of our country and use infrastructure as a driver of economic growth. The Mooikloof Integrated Development has a total project value of over R84bn and is one of the 62 Strategic Integrated Projects gazetted at the end of July.

The launch of the #Mooikloof development is the outcome of a successful public-private partnership. I want to congratulate the developers @BalwinProp, @GautengProvince & @CityTshwane for bringing this project to fruition within such constrained timeframes.

As we begin the long and difficult recovery from the coronavirus pandemic, we can draw encouragement, confidence and hope from the measures we are taking now to address our immediate electricity challenges and secure our energy supply well into the future.

I did not want to upstage the team at @PresidencyZA with my dance moves, but job well done! Thank you all for participating so enthusiastically in the #JerusalemaChallenge. @MasterKGSA & @NomceboZikode thank you for giving the world such a special & proudly South African moment.
Let us choose solidarity above isolation. Let us choose unity of purpose above narrow self-interest. Let us emerge from this great adversity strengthened and even more united.

We have to act with urgency to achieve the Sustainable Development Goals. As the international community let us choose cooperation above unilateralism.
 
#GlobalGoals #UNGA

This will ensure that the interests of a few will not undermine efforts at finding solutions to emerging crises that are global in nature. As we look to the post COVID-era reconstruction, we have to address the economic, social, humanitarian and environmental needs of countries.
To maintain peace and security, we need a Security Council that better reflects and represents the United Nations membership in keeping with the principle of the sovereign equality of all states.
We further support the call for the waiving of unilateral punitive measures, such as sanctions, during the pandemic to enable affected countries to secure much-needed supplies and support.
South Africa calls on all parties to armed conflict to use this opportunity to work towards peaceful resolution, all the while addressing the humanitarian needs of their populations.
South Africa and the @_AfricanUnion supports the call by the UN Secretary-General @antonioguterres for a global ceasefire and the scaling up of humanitarian assistance to vulnerable societies.

It is imperative that the Security Council continues to work closely with regional organisations in this regard, including with the @_AfricanUnion. We must coordinate our efforts and strengthen multilateralism if we are to contain the damage that this pandemic could cause.

Vital gains made in political processes towards peace are under threat. It is our collective expectation as the international community that the UN Security Council will continue to play a key role in ensuring that this pandemic does not undermine international peace & security.

The threat to lives, livelihoods and social stability posed by the #COVID19 pandemic has significant consequences for global peace and security. Situations of instability and conflict have the potential to worsen, and there is a possibility of new forms of social unrest emerging.

Allow me to begin by congratulating the Republic of Niger on assuming the Presidency of the UN Security Council. Please be assured of South Africa’s full support and cooperation.
 
#UNGA #BetterAfricaBetterWorld #UN75 #UNGA75
#UNGA75 #BetterAfricaBetterWorld

As much as we celebrate our customs and traditions on this day, let us also appreciate that in practising our cultures freely and openly, and in speaking our native languages, we are reclaiming not just our heritage, but our pride and our dignity as South Africans.
We will continue to support every effort to preserve our common heritage, as well as those of individual communities.

We will continue to strive to eradicate poverty, inequality and underdevelopment. We will continue to uphold the rights of all our people to practice their cultures, to speak their languages and practice our traditions.

Restoring their dignity is the preoccupation of this administration. In the wake of COVID-19, and well into the future, it will remain our singular concern.
 
We will recover from this crisis and rebuild our lives and our economy.

Any symbol, monument or activity that glorifies racism, that represents our ugly, has no place in democratic South Africa. The struggle against apartheid was first and foremost aimed at ensuring that all our people should reclaim their dignity, black and white.
Building a truly non-racial society means being sensitive to the lived experiences of all this country’s people. We make no apologies for this because our objective is to build a united nation.

The naming and renaming of towns and cities forms part of this, as well as the erection of new statues and monuments. Monuments glorifying our divisive past should be repositioned and relocated. This has generated controversy, with some saying we are trying to erase our history.

Building a united nation means we must be aware of and check our own acts of racism and prejudice continuously. We come from a history of prejudice and exclusion, and since democracy we have worked to transform the heritage landscape of our country.

The social cohesion we seek in this country means we must be mindful of the legacy of our past, whether we are businesses selling products, whether we are producers of content for television, or otherwise.
It is disheartening to see that in democratic South Africa, there are still crude stereotypes of black women being put on public display.

An offensive hair advertisement that was recently published shows that we still have a long way to go. The apartheid government denigrated our cultures and tried to make us ashamed of our cultures, our traditions, our languages and our very appearances.
With the same determination, we must stand firm against attempts to disrespect our country’s women through crude forms of representation in the media, in advertising and in popular culture.

We must put an end to this terrible shame that is tainting the image of our country. When you oppress a woman, you oppress a nation. When you beat a woman, you beat a nation. We must do away with practices that discriminate against women.

Abusing women is not our tradition, nor is it our custom. It is not, and will never be, our heritage. Throughout the history of this continent, women have built and shaped our societies. They have ruled kingdoms. They have been highly respected and valued.

So long as this country’s women and children live in fear from violence, we cannot regard ourselves as totally free. So long as women are being harassed, abused, beaten, raped and murdered, we cannot say we are a civilised society.

It is important that generations that come after us must fully grasp the importance of the freedom we have all achieved. The men, women and children of tomorrow must be proud to have inherited a democracy that affirms the worth and dignity of all our citizens.

As part of Heritage Month we have launched 3 books that acknowledge the efforts of these great women. Throughout the month we’ll promote greater awareness of their work. We will also promote the work of many others who are doing so much to conserve our diverse customs & cultures.

Mama Katrina Esau is a champion of the culture of the San people, and is one of the two last remaining speakers of the N|uu language. Over the years she has single-handedly worked to keep the language alive by running a school for young people.

Dr Mahlangu’s paintings inspired by Ndebele design are on display in more than a dozen countries around the world and her work has won numerous awards. Mama Madosini, the Queen of Pondoland music, is the greatest living musician who can play the indigenous bow instruments.

Yet as there are those who have passed from this life, we have our Living Human Treasures, our repositories of knowledge, customs and traditions. This Heritage Month is dedicated to Dr Esther Mahlangu, Mama Madosini Latozi Mpahleni and Mama Ouma Katrina Esau.
 
#HeritageDay2020

We pay tribute to them all, for in their own unique way they have contributed to preserving our past, but also to defending the struggles of the present. It is because of them, and many like them, that we are today able to celebrate where we have come from.
We have lost the legendary photographer Jürgen Schadeberg. We have mourned the passing of Ouma Griet Seekoei, one of only remaining speakers of the endangered N|uu language.

We have lost Achmat Dangor and Elsa Joubert, two celebrated authors whose works gave expression to the human condition under apartheid. We have had to bid farewell to the musical giant, the founder of Ladysmith Black Mambazo and the father of isicathamiya, uBab’uJoseph Shabalala.

In Heritage Month we honour those who work so hard to preserve all aspects of our traditional and modern heritage. We pay tribute to the spirited defenders of our heritage that we have sadly lost this year.

In as much as we join the international community in the search for diagnostics, therapeutics and a vaccine, we are also looking at the important contribution indigenous knowledge systems, particularly traditional medicine, can play in improving the health outcomes of our people.

This year’s #HeritageDay is taking place in the shadow of the #COVID19 pandemic. This pandemic has taken a toll on human life, on communities and on our economy. In this time of the pandemic, we have seen the knowledge of traditional medicinal plants increase.
Long before the advent of modern medicine, our ancestors used the herbs and plants that are so abundant here to heal, to give strength and for sustenance.

We are home to the most beautiful sites dating back to antiquity, opening a window into the lives of the earliest ancestors of humankind. Our indigenous knowledge systems preserved by our elders and traditional healers are a vital part of our heritage.

Heritage doesn’t only find expression in dress, rituals, food, music, art & language. It finds expression in our natural world. We are the 3rd most mega-biodiverse country in the world with abundant fauna & flora. This is what makes South Africa the most beautiful country.

Heritage is a source of identity and cohesion for our nation. It makes us who we are. Heritage shapes and moulds us, and gives us a sense of belonging. It is the inheritance passed down from generation to generation, linking the present to the past.
 
#HeritageDay2020

We are a nation that steadfastly protects those indigenous languages that are facing extinction such as N|uu, Nama, isiHlubi, Khelovhedu and other indigenous languages.
 
The greatest thing about heritage is its dynamism.

We are a nation of eleven official languages that also celebrates other languages commonly used by various communities in South Africa, including German, Greek, Gujarati, Hindi, Portuguese, Tamil, Telugu and Urdu.

We are the nation that is taking the world by storm with the #JerusalemaChallenge, as young and old in France, the UK, Jamaica, Angola and even in Palestinian East Jerusalem itself are getting in on the craze.
 
#heritageday2020

We are the nation of the maskandi, Malay choral music and sokkie treffers, but also of amapiano.
 
#HeritageDay2020

#HeritageDay is a time to appreciate the many facets of our cultures, customs and traditions. It is the time when we put them on display to appreciate and celebrate and share our cultures and traditions with others.

Dumelang, Molweni, Sanibonani, Goeie Dag, Thobela, Lotjhani, Ndi masiari, Nhlekanhi. Today we celebrate the unique and diverse heritage of this place we call home: Mzantsi Afrika, Afrika Borwa, Afurika Tshipembe, Suid-Afrika.
 
#HeritageDay2020 #MyHeritageYourHeritage
Celebrating our Living Heritage #HeritageDay #HeritageDay2020 #MyHeritageYourHeritage

A nation that empowers women is a strong and sustainable nation. It is our wish that world leaders use this occasion to reaffirm their commitment to the Partnership for Women's Digital Financial Inclusion in Africa. #UNGA #BetterAfricaBetterWorld
Unless women are brought into the mainstream of the economy they will continue to bear the brunt of exclusion and marginalisation and be vulnerable to abuse and exploitation.
Through digital platforms, a greater number of women will have access to funding and online banking, fulfilling a need that traditional banking services are unable to meet.
We believe that a digitally-enabled economy – with a strong emphasis on gender equality – has the potential to be transformative, fair, sustainable and competitive.
We have also announced that 40% of all public procurement will be reserved for women-owned businesses and are working with AU member states to develop similar policy guidelines across the continent.
In support of greater economic and financial inclusion, South Africa has made a commitment of 500,000 USD to the African Women Leadership Fund, which seeks to empower women financial leaders.

Women must have greater access to affordable financial services. They must have access to working capital, credit lines, insurance and to digital tools such as mobile banking platforms.
 
#UNGA

We must enable them to take advantage of technological advances to start businesses, to trade and to seek employment. The coronavirus pandemic has had a dramatic effect on economic activity on the continent and around the world.
By giving women the tools to become financially secure and independent, we are investing in a society in which their rights to dignity, security and financial empowerment is secured.
As South Africa and as Chair of the African Union we wholly support the #G7Partnership for Women’s Digital Financial Inclusion in Africa.
#G7Partnership for Women's Digital Financial Inclusion in Africa #G7 #UNGA #BetterAfricaBetterWorld #UN75
Opening of the General Debate of the UN Assembly #UNGA #BetterAfricaBetterWorld

To resolve our global challenges – be they health emergencies, transnational crime, conflict & war, climate change, or natural disasters – we must work together. It is only through multilateralism that we can forge common strategies for the benefit of all.

Sending well wishes to the Deputy Secretary General of the African National Congress, Cde Jessie Duarte, on the occasion of her 67th birthday. A tried and tested servant of the people, we wish Cde DSG a long and healthy life and thank her for her dedicated service to the nation.

For Africa, the path we must take is clear. The @UN’s 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development is our lodestar for transforming our world, and the template for global cooperation and partnership. We must ensure that no country is left behind. #SDGMoment #UNGA75 #UNGA

George was indeed a son of this soil. Not born of it, he was the soil itself. We will forever remember him in his robes, rising to address the court, and smiling, leaning on his cane as he whispered to his clients and his protégés. From where he stood, he moved the earth.
#RIPGeorgeBizos 🕊
Progress in the national effort to contain the #COVID19 pandemic
During this pandemic, our media has played not just its traditional watchdog role, but exercised its civic duty in supporting the national effort to contain the coronavirus.
High-Level Meeting of the Facilitation of the “Access to COVID-19 Tools Accelerator”#COVID19 #TheAfricaWeWant
We are pivoting the recovery process on a number of key priorities including infrastructure and mass employment.

As we go into the recovery process, our focus will be on implementation, directed and coordinated from the Office of the President. We hope to increase the capacity of the state to enable us to focus on our priorities.

The R500bn is almost 11% of our GDP. There is no peer country that we know of that has done as much as that. We are at the level of more developed economies that have way more capacity in so as far as stimulus packages.

We have committed that we will provide the law enforcement agencies with the necessary resources so that they can speed up their work. My responsibility is to capacitate and strengthen their capabilities so that they can do their work without any fear, favour or prejudice.
In many companies, as with Government, when employees are suspended, it is with full pay, because that is what the labour laws dictate.

The commitment to fight gender-based violence & femicide is real. I am confident that we will achieve our objectives & have the National Strategic Plan implemented. I've never been more serious about anything than I am about effectively addressing this pandemic.

Hiking prices of PPEs is not only wrong, but it is criminal and completely unacceptable, including the supply of shoddy equipment or products. I subscribe to the view of the @WHO that it is akin to murder.
There is an intense focus on detecting and prosecuting COVID-related corruption and improving transparency in procurement.

The news of the passing of #GeorgeBizos is very sad for us as a country. An incisive legal mind and architect of our Constitution, he contributed immensely to our democracy. We extend our deepest condolences to his family and dip our heads in his honour.
Engagement with members of the South African National Editors’ Forum #PresidencySANEF

Over the past week, three key Bills relating to gender-based violence have been introduced in Parliament. Through the introduction of these Bills, we are honouring the promise we made to the protestors last year and to all the women of this country.

I also wish SASCO well in the SRC elections in all institutions where they will still be held this year.
May SASCO continue to grow in strength and unity over the next 29 years. Amandla!

#SASCO must remain a united fighting force truly in the hands of students. I wish all students well in their studies for the remainder of this academic year, especially given the challenges brought about by #COVID19.

We need a strong #SASCO to ensure that conditions at institutions of higher learning are conducive for academic success. SASCO's success in all these things is inextricably linked to the ANC's success in building an educated society based on the vision of the Freedom Charter.

We need a strong SASCO to ensure that bursaries which are meant for the poor actually go to the poor.
We need a strong SASCO to ensure that residences which are meant for students whose homes are far away from campuses truly serve their purpose. #SASCO29

It is your revolutionary duty to get your qualifications and place your skills at the disposal your movement to better serve the people. The ANC relies on a strong and fighting #SASCO to ensure that its progressive policies in higher education are implemented to the letter.

We must never have career student leaders or university veterans who become gatekeepers preventing others from accessing higher education. Despite the well-known difficulties associated with political activism, #SASCO members must lead by example and excel in the classroom.

Beyond this, students have a responsibility to make use of all available opportunities and pass all their modules in pursuance of yet another objective of SASCO, which is, academic excellence. #SASCO29
You must pursue this mission relentlessly with the full understanding that our revolution is doomed to fail if we do not constantly win society over in the battlefield of ideas. #SASCO29

You have a responsibility to conscientise students and ensure that our universities are never turned into incubators of only a particular kind of thinker who not only harbour anti-ANC sentiments but also work to produce more who are opposed to the objectives of our revolution.
SASCO also has an immense role to play in the creation of a conscious and mobilized citizenry upon which the success of the National Democratic Revolution is dependent. #SASCO29

We need young people who are conscious of the tasks at hand and who will participate both in the conceptualisation and implementation of our programme of fundamental socio-economic transformation. #SASCO29

For the ANC to succeed in executing the tasks of the National Democratic Revolution, it needs an educated society with the necessary skills to build a sustainable and inclusive economy. Our universities and TVET colleges have an immeasurable role to play in this regard. #SASCO29

You must always remember that true to its nature as the real congress of the people, the ANC is as much yours as it is ours who happen to lead it at this moment.
#SASCO29

Your responsibility as young intellectuals who must shape the future of this country is to thoroughly engage the ANC on whatever matter through the available platforms and channels.
#SASCO29

It is however important to mention that contradicting the ANC on policy matters should not be the same as the headline and sound bite driven populism of shouting down from rooftops everything the ANC says or does. #SASCO29

It is indicative of the political maturity in the student movement and the deep understanding of constructive criticism as one of the basic tenets of our organisational philosophy.
#SASCO29

The CC approach employed by SASCO in its relationship with the ANC in that it will complement the ANC where it agrees and contradict where it disagrees is encouraged.
#SASCO29

It is impossible to imagine that this can happen successfully without the active involvement of SASCO because of the organization’s primary location in centres of knowledge production and consumption. #SASCO29
The tasks of the revolution during this decisive phase include educating and training a critical mass of ANC members ideologically, politically, academically and morally. #SASCO29

The ANC has determined that we are now in the second phase of our long drawn transition from colonialism of a special type to the National Democratic Society.
#SASCO29

I am asking these practical questions not with the intention of imposing an additional burden on SASCO but because I believe that they are important in order for the student movement to know and fully appreciate its role in the advancement of the National Democratic Revolution.

The question SASCO must answer is whether or not there is any practical & coordinated work undertaken by the organisation in communities, amongst and with the people, consistent with the assertion of the SPOT document: “we are members of the community before we are students.”

It is for this reason that when the call was made during the ‘Decade of Freedom’ to render South Africa ungovernable and apartheid unworkable, the student movement formed part of the broader progressive youth movement organised under the auspices of SAYCO. #SASCO29

The progressive student movement in this country has always seen and appreciated its role and duty beyond campus boundaries.
#SASCO29

You were quite correct in this thinking & conceptualisation because the history of the student movement, particularly in the sixties and seventies, is littered with best examples of how a student organisation can truly be committed both in theory and practice to community work.

I suspect that it is on the basis of this very phrase that you, as an organization, have ‘community work’ as one of the pillars of your day to day struggles.
#SASCO29

And yet the overriding question that must be answered honestly is whether or not the rank and file membership of SASCO fully understands and appreciates the depth of the revolutionary content of such a simple sounding phrase.
#SASCO29
The assertion in the SPOT document thus brings SASCO a step closer to being an organisation of organic intellectuals. #SASCO29
I understand this to mean that SASCO seeks to produce thinking members who are concerned about the challenges facing society in general and are organic to the cause of the people. #SASCO29

Consistent with its historic mission of being the intellectual hub for the Mass Democratic Movement, SASCO asserts in its Strategic Perspective On Transformation (SPOT) Document that "we are members of the community before we are students". #SASCO29

SASCO is part of the progressive forces in our society pursuing the objectives of the National Democratic Revolution.  
#SASCO29

The 29th Anniversary virtual rally of the South African Students Congress is currently underway under the theme: “Building a modern student movement to deepen the National Democratic Revolution and for the attainment of Working-Class Power.”

#SASCO29

Dr Lubisi, it has been an honour to serve alongside you. You have been an exceptional leader & you will be missed. You’ve done your duty with honour & distinction, and served your country loyally, patriotically & faithfully. We wish you well. We shall miss you. I shall miss you.

When civil servants are committed, when they are ethical and principled, when they understand the true meaning of public service, governments truly work for the people. And it is men and women like Dr Lubisi who set the standard.
Achieving a non-sexist society as set out in the National Democratic Revolution is a process, but we must achieve it in our lifetime. #ANCMensDialogue

This has been a very insightful and engaging dialogue, which has improved our understanding and strengthened our resolve to confront this grave social challenge. This message must spread throughout all our structures in all our provinces. #ANCMensDialogue

Ensuring equal representation of women and men, and active inclusion of people from the LGBTQI+ community in leadership positions across society, will aid in our efforts to change mindsets about traditional gender roles and stereotypes. #ANCMensDialogue
We must create and support institutional reforms that advance women and gender-non-conforming individuals as leaders and decision-makers. #ANCMensDialogue

We must enforce accountability for pay equity, provide fair compensation for care work and create transparent systems to ensure non-discrimination in recruitment, hiring and retention. #ANCMensDialogue

We must educate fathers on the benefit of taking full paternity leave as this can aid in bolstering children’s development. This can also contribute to gender equality in the workplace. #ANCMensDialogue

Government must establish policies and practices that encourage men to be full partners in care work through parental leave. Employers must have policies and practices that recognise the equal parenting responsibilities of men. #ANCMensDialogue
When boys see fathers and older males more actively involved in domestic care and work, they are more likely to contribute to such work. #ANCMensDialogue
Men must become more active in households and contribute equally to care work. In this way, we become examples for young boys and work against oppressive gender stereotypes. #ANCMensDialogue

We must destigmatizse girls’ and womens’ health, including menstrual hygiene and pregnancy. Men and boys must be engaged in order to become informed allies and promote inclusivity and equality. #ANCMensDialogue

We must confront toxic masculinity and consistently check our own impulses to subconsciously reinforce patriarchal attitudes, such as the impulse to assign greater importance to male voices and opinions. #ANCMensDialogue
We must be positive and reinforce the message that women and girls enjoy equal protection under the Constitution and all the laws. #ANCMensDialogue
We must reinforce these programmes in our homes by teaching both boys and girls non-violent methods of resolving conflict. #ANCMensDialogue

Creating, funding and scaling up programmes that establish zero tolerance for gender-based violence. That means implementing these programmes in workplaces, online and confronting all forms of GBV wherever we encounter them. #ANCMensDialogue
We must emphasise, in word and in deed, that women and girls are not property. #ANCMensDialogue

One of the most important interventions we can make is to confront and change harmful gender norms that perpetuate gender inequality at home, at work and in public. We must be consistent in our messaging that women and girls are equal to men and boys. #ANCMensDialogue

It is us men who must agree that we are going to sacrifice the privileges that we have enjoyed. We must agree that women must be moved to the front. There must be greater focus on the economic & social empowerment of women, ensuring that they have a greater stake in the economy.

We must lead the campaign to eradicate our communities of gender based violence and femicide, in a principled way,  guided by the National Democratic Revolution, which dictates that we must build a non-sexist society. #ANCMensDialogue

We must take the fight up as men &talk to other men. We know the perpetrators and we keep quiet. Silence about gender-based violence is one of the greatest factors that enable this crime. All too often, we know our comrade, friend or relative is a perpetrator, but we keep quiet.

As men, we must stand us and declare that we are going to bring an end to #GBVF. It is us who violate the women of our country; it is us who abuse, rape and kill women through toxic masculinity. It is us who have the power to end this scourge. #ANCMensDialogue

We need to go back to a culture of community to defeat these pandemics. Men need to stand up and work in partnership with the women in our country in combating gender-based violence and femicide through confronting patriarchal norms and attitudes. #ANCMensDialogue
However, effective laws and more policing will not be enough on their own. We need all of society to work together to eliminate gender-based violence and femicide. #ANCMensDialogue

It is a tragedy that such laws are necessary, but government is adamant that we will do everything in our power to deal with gender-based violence and femicide. 

#ANCMensDialogue

The Criminal Law (Sexual Offences and Related Matters) Amendment Bill and Criminal and related Matters Amendment Bill aim among other things, to tighten bail conditions for alleged perpetrators and provide for harsher minimum sentences. #ANCMensDialogue

It is clear that we need to do much more and better to effectively deal with gender-based violence and femicide.

My thoughts are with the Mlangeni family and with all who have had the blessing of meeting & being touched by Bab’ Mlangeni’s passion for achieving a better society, his passion for a life that is well-rounded, adventurous, healthy & embracing of people from all walks of life.
He was a champion and exemplar of the values we need to build a South Africa that provides dignity and opportunity for all and which takes its rightful place in the global community of nations.

With his passing as the last remaining Rivonia Trialist, Bab’ Mlangeni has indeed passed the baton to his compatriots to build the South Africa he fought to liberate and to reconstruct during our democratic dispensation.

Bab’ Mlangeni’s dramatic life was a unique example of heroism and humility inhabiting the same person and throughout his long life he remained a beacon of ethical leadership and care for humanity in our own country and around the globe.

The passing of Andrew Mekete Mlangeni signifies the end of a generational history and places our future squarely in our hands. Until recently, we were able to sit at Bab’ Mlangeni’s feet and draw on his wealth of wisdom and his unfailing commitment to a better life for all.

I would like to thank the Mandela family for the very important gesture of sharing this information with the nation. This is a virus that affects us all, and there should never be any stigma around people who become infected.

Today we face a new enemy in the form of coronavirus. Its effects have been devastating on lives, livelihoods and communities. It has left none of us unaffected.
 
Just yesterday we received the news that Zindzi too had tested positive for the virus.
We share a common and collective duty to expend our every effort in realising the promise of an equal society to which liberation fighters like #ZindziMandela devoted their lives.

She repeatedly called for a shift of mindset on the part of all South Africans to be conscious of the plight of the disadvantaged and to play their part building a society in which all people are free from want and hunger.
 
We draw many lessons from her life.
Zindzi believed that true reconciliation could only come about when the formerly advantaged acknowledged their privilege, and made amends to the formerly oppressed.

Zindzi’s activism did not end when democracy came. She remained committed to realising a South Africa founded on equality and human dignity, and did not hesitate to speak forthrightly about the many challenges our country faced.

In a letter Madiba wrote to her in 1987 he noted that, “he heard from an acquaintance that she was as strong as a rock”.
 
He went on: “That is just the kind of remark a father would like to hear about his beloved child. I literally swelled with pride and satisfaction.”

She was recruited as an underground operative of Umkhonto we Sizwe, and worked with the communities of Weilers and Orange Farm to launch the first ANC branch with Isithwalandwe Walter Sisulu in the 1990s.
 
Zindzi was her father’s pride.

On account of being a Mandela, Zindzi did not have a choice but to be associated with the liberation struggle. But it was her own choice to immerse herself in that struggle.
 
She was a fearless activist and a leader in her own right.

It was in the same year that, despite the difficulties of her life, she managed to obtain her law degree, inspiring young women everywhere to further their education despite the harsh conditions under which they lived.

Zindzi captured the hearts and minds of all freedom-loving South Africans as the message was broadcast to the world. As a young woman, she stood as a symbol of hope and strength to a traumatised nation.

Hers was a childhood lived under the harshest of conditions, as the apartheid regime intensified its repressive laws in a bid to break the fighting spirit of our people. She was just over a year old when her father was arrested & saw her mother being harassed by apartheid police.
She was born to parents who were icons of our struggle, Izithwalandwe Nelson Rolihlahla Mandela and Nomzamo Winnie Madikizela-Mandela. She was born in 1960, the year of the Sharpeville Massacre.

We offer our profound and deepest condolences to the Mandela family on their great loss. We have lost a devoted activist, a patriot and a fearless freedom fighter whose life was committed to the liberation of this country.

Though it is always sad to lose a loved one, her passing was so unexpected, and while she was in the prime of her life, has come as a great shock to us all. The leaders and members of the African National Congress are in deep mourning.
Just days before we commemorate the birthday of the father of our nation, President Nelson Mandela, we have lost his youngest daughter, Cde Zindzi Mandela.

#FreedomCharter65

This harkens back to the systematic dispossession of land, which remains one of the greatest injustices suffered by Black people in the history of our country. We are addressing this heinous crime against the people.
 
#FreedomCharter65

Our movement, government and all social partners must work together to bring about the radical transformation of the economy and achieve economic inclusion.

It is undeniable that the wealth of this country remains largely in the hands of a predominantly white and male minority. The structure of our economy continues to exclude overwhelming numbers of the poor and Black majority.
 
#FreedomCharter65

The Freedom Charter is explicit in its call that the people share shall in the country’s wealth.
 
#FreedomCharter65

All of these challenges require us to call on the determination and resilience of our forebears to meet them head-on. This time requires us to, again, unite and work to put in place the South Africa we want.

Our already underperforming economy has contracted further as a result of the impact of the pandemic and ratings downgrades. There is a war against women in South Africa. Gender-based violence and femicide are twin scourges that we need to eradicate.

At this point in time, our country again faces enormous challenges. We are in the middle of a global pandemic unlike anything the world has seen in more than a century.
 
#FreedomCharter65

The Freedom Charter is clear that South Africa belongs to all who live in it, black and white. This entrenched commitment to non-racialism should permeate through the very fabric of society.
 
#FreedomCharter65
The Freedom Charter unique. We must know the legacy we have and what we have inherited. We stand on the shoulders of the giants who have preceded us. #FreedomCharter65

The demands of the #FreedomCharter are breathtaking in their commitment to equality, justice & freedom from oppression. They truly represent the will of South Africans to live peacefully in a united, non-racial, non-sexist, democratic & prosperous society

Nearly 3000 people gathered in Kliptown on Sunday 26 June 1955 and, despite relentless harassment and violence from the state machinery, this Congress of the People officially adopted the Freedom Charter.
 
#FreedomCharter65

This simple call to to unify South Africans around a common vision was seen as a great threat by the regime. They understood with perfect clarity that their message of hate and division would not survive once the people were united against them.

The ANC, together with its allies in the Congress Alliance – the South African Indian Congress, the Coloured Peoples’ Congress and the South African Congress of Democrats – made a simple call. This call was “Let the People Speak.”
 
#FreedomCharter65

The 42nd Conference of the ANC in Queenstown in 1943 made a call for convening a congress of the people which would, in the words of the late comrade Joe Slovo “allow each  South African to say for himself what he desires from life.”
 
#FreedomCharter65

South Africa was an oppressive and inhumane place during the early 1950s. The Apartheid regime was becoming even bolder and intensifying its actions to subjugate the people and suppress those brave fighters calling for liberation and equality.

The #FreedomCharter is the lodestar, the bedrock of South Africa’s constitutional democracy and provides a sterling example of how a people, acting in unity and congress, came together and crafted a vision of the South Africa they want.
#FreedomCharter65

Silence about gender-based violence is one of the greatest contributing and enabling factors to this crime. All too often, we know our comrade, our friend or our relative is a perpetrator, but we keep silent. Regarding it as a private or family matter.

We must be positive and reinforce the message that women and girls enjoy equal protection under the Constitution and all the laws. We must confront toxic masculinity and consistently check our own impulses to subconsciously reinforce patriarchal attitudes.

This is the time for world leaders to demonstrate that they care about putting the lives of ordinary people above geopolitical interests. #COVID19

I believe that it is extremely unfortunate that at a perilous time like this, when people are dying and when we should all be working together, sanctions are still enforced. This should be a time of solidarity and compassion.

Iran has expressed its appreciation for South Africa’s support at the United Nations. Iran continues to battle under crushing economic sanctions which are impeding its ability to import much needed medical supplies and foodstuffs.

HE President Rouhani and I have agreed to expand collaboration and knowledge sharing between our two countries. We have also pledged to deepen economic cooperation, particularly between small businesses.
To date more than 5000 people have lost their lives in that country. We pledge our support to Iran during this time and send our most sincere condolences to the government and people of Iran.

Earlier today I had a most wonderful conversation with His Excellency President Hassan Rouhani of the Islamic Republic of Iran. Like many countries across the world, the coronavirus has had a devastating impact on #Iran and has caused serious damage to their economy.

President Maduro congratulated South Africa on the 26th anniversary of #FreedomDay and invited South African businesses to invest in Venezuela and for our countries to strengthen economic relations. Venezuela & South Africa count on each other as key allies for global solidarity.

South Africa reaffirmed our principled position as expressed at the @UN and UNSC that the sovereignty and internal political dialogue amongst all parties in Venezuela must be allowed to continue unhindered to bring political stability and economic prosperity to the country.
President Maduro passed on greetings to all countries on the continent and expressed profound hope that Africa will succeed in winning the war against #COVID19.

We exchanged experiences in the actions taken in the fight #COVID19 and the emphasised the importance of international solidarity in order to defeat the menace of this global pandemic. We agreed that the Ministers of Health will continue to collaborate to share lessons learnt.
I had a call with my Brother, President Nicolas Maduro of Venezuela🇻🇪 yesterday. Our two countries share a close and deep historical bond based on friendship, solidarity and cooperation.

This #FreedomDay let us stand firm and united against this disease, but also against poverty, inequality and hunger. Let the good that has come from this experience – of collective action, of unity of purpose and generosity of spirit, continue.
#FreedomDay | “Solidarity and Triumph of the Human Spirit in these Challenging Times” #COVID19 #StayHome

This deployment is a demonstration of the strategic partnership and solidarity between South Africa and #Cuba and a good example of South–South cooperation. We thank HE President Díaz Canel Bermúdez for responding to our call & we forever remain grateful to the people of Cuba.🇨🇺

Cuba & South Africa share a special bond with strong historic relations spanning decades. Over 732 South Africans, many from previously disadvantaged communities, received years of training in Cuba since the inception of the Nelson Mandela/Fidel Castro medical training programme.

The theme for this year’s #FreedomDay is: “Solidarity and the triumph of the human spirit in challenging times”. It is fitting that on this day we should welcome Cuban health experts who have arrived in our country to support our efforts to curb the spread of #COVID19. 🇨🇺🇿🇦

We both reiterated our support for the World Health Organisation who are coordinating the global fight against pandemic, and called for even greater transparency by all global partners as the world battles this crisis.
I advised of the likely increase of confirmed #COVID19 cases in Africa and the need for readiness on personal protective equipment, medical supplies and equipment.

I spoke to Her Excellency Chancellor Angela Merkel earlier today over the phone to discuss the current #COVID19 challenges. Like we intend to, Germany has taken a risk-adjusted approach to containment after their hard lockdown and we have lessons to learn from their experience.

I had a very productive call with His Excellency President @realDonaldTrump of the United States of America. We discussed the impact of #COVID19 on our two countries. I have passed our condolences to the Government and people of the US on the devastation the virus has wrought.

Wishing Prime Minister @BorisJohnson a full and speedy recovery, and sending our support to him and to the people of the United Kingdom. We are going through a most challenging period but we shall overcome. Our thoughts are with him and his loved ones at this time.

UNSG @AntonioGuterres has expressed solidarity with the continent. The @UN are aware of specific spatial challenges in Africa that make isolation and distancing difficult and have championed the fight for fair & equitable distribution of medical supplies for developing countries.

The @GatesFoundation has supported our health needs for many years. They have offered assistance with innovative mass-based testing kits and research. I spoke to @BillGates and he commended the swift and decisive action South Africa has taken on #COVID19.

I spoke to President Vladimir Putin and asked for technical expertise on infection control, supply of lifesaving  equipment for mobile testing & infection control. South Africa has a long friendship with Russia & they have supported China, Italy & US in the fight against #COVID19

I have convened a special President’s Coordinating Council meeting this morning to discuss progress & challenges on implementation of the national & provincial responses to #COVID19, the lockdown & our economic recovery plan. Attending is the DP, Ministers, 9 Premiers & SALGA.

Ayikho into engasehlula singabantu bala eSouth Africa nalesifo seCorona virus singasehlula uma sisebenza kunye sibonisane ukuthi singaqhuba kanjani na. Sijabulela futhi ukuthi abantu abaningi balana eMzansi Afrika ngempela banomdlandla wokunceda,

siyababonga nabo ukuthi baye babekezela kwaze kwafika usuku lwanamhlanje, sesibakhululile manje bahambile baya emakhaya. Ngithanda ukubonga abantu bakithi ngendlela esiqhuba ngayo noma kunobunzima lapho nalapho sithi masibambaneni ngezandla siqhube ngoba lesisifo singasehlula.

siyababonga ke sibonga nalabo ababalandile amapilots ebhanoyi leSouth African Airways ebalande eChina, amaSosha Kanye noDokotela. Siphinde futhi sibonge nabasenzi base-Ranch Hotel e-Polokwane ukuthi nabo labo basebenzi bakuleyondawo baye bavuma ukuthi bazovalelwa amaviki amabili,
yezinsuku ezingama-51 baye babekezela baze babuya la bangena kwenye iquarantine manje bangena kwenye yesithathu futhi, kodwa bathe bayayamukela ngoba bayazi ukuthi lesifo lesi siyingozi kakhulu,

Lentsha ngihlangane nayo, yajabula kakhulu ukuthi uhulumeni wenze yonke imizamo yokuthi babuye, babuyile futhi abanayo i-Coronavirus, sithanda ukubabonga ngokubekezela, babe kwilockdown quarantine yamaviki amabili nakhona baqale ngenye ilockdown quarantine le eChina,

sizozama zonke izindlela ukuthi umnotho wezwe lakithi siwubeke endaweni engcono ezosebenzela umphakathi wakithi. Sijabule kakhulu kulelisonto eledlulile ngiye ngathola ithuba lokuyohlangana nentsha ebuya eChina.

uma bethola abantu abanaso lesifo bazobakhipha ukuze babekwe endaweni ethize. Lokhu kwalesifo lesi i-Coronavirus kwenzeke ngesikhathi esibi kakhulu kumnotho wezwe lakithi. Umnotho weSouth Afrika ubungahambi kahle manje i-Coronavirus seyenze ukuthi umnotho wethu wehle kakhulu,

Njengamanje lesifo sesifikile nalakuhlala abantu abaningi bakithi, sesifikile naseKhayelitsha, sesifikile nase-Alexander kuyasethusa lokho ke ngoba kunokwenzeka ukuthi sivele sihambe yonke indawo, lamalanga asele awu-16 siyazi ukuthi azobanzima kubantu abaningi bakithi,

Lesifo asikhethi ukuthi ungubani, asikhethi ukuthi unemali noma awunayo imali, asikhethi ukuthi uhlala emakhaya noma emadolobheni, asikhethi futhi nokuthi usumdala noma usemusha masingalenzi iphutha lokucabanga ukuthi lesifo esabantu abathize kuphela.
Abantu abaningi bakithi bacabanga ukuthi no lesifo lesi no ngeke size sifike kubo and nakhona bacabanga ukuthi lesifo siphuma phesheya ngeke sikwazi ukungena la kubantu bakithi.
Sithi singaphumi nje, siphumele ngaphandle ngoba kunokwenzeka ukuthi uma uphumela nje ngaphandle lesifo mhlampe ngabe unaso bese usifaka kwabanye abantu.
kunabanye ke esibafake emthethweni abasebenza ezindaweni ezibiza ngokuthi essential services nabo sibanike imvume yokuthi bangasebenzenza.

Abantu abanemvume yokuthi basebenze ngalesisikhathi amaSosha, amaPhoyisa, oDokotela, oNesi, ama-Social Worker nalabo abasebenza lapho kwenziwa ukudla nalapho kuthengiswa khona ukudla, nalabo abasebenza lapho kuthengiswa khona amayeza noma imedicine,

njengamanje sekunabantu abathathu asebeshonile la eMzansi Afrika, inani labantu abaphathwa ilesifo lilokhu liyakhuphuka kwayizolo besinabantu abawu-1328, yikho nje sithi kubantu bala eMzansi Afrika masizameni ukuthi sisebenze ngalendlela ebekwe uhulumeni

ngoba kwelinye ilizwe kwabonakala ukuthi ibandla elithile liye laqhubeka ngemithandazo kwatholakala ukuthi abantu abaningi baye baphathwa ilesifo seCorona virus sivela lapho kulelosonto,

bangahlangani ezindaweni eziningi bebaningi, siyajabula futhi ukuthi nabamasonto kakhulu ngalesikhathi la siyakhona kuma-Easter baye bavuma ukuthi yebo mabamise lemihlangano yemithandazo emikhulu ngoba bekuzoba kanzima kakhulu if besiqhubeka nemithandazo emikhulu kangaka

kungakho nje sivele sathi asilithathe lelinyathelo noma lungajwayelekile sivale uMzansi Afrika izinsuku ezingu-21. Siyathokoza ke ukuthi abantu bakithi la eMzansi Afrika ngempela hhayi baye bamamela, baqhuba ngalendlela uhulumeni ayibekile ukuthi bahlale emakhaya,

Labo abaziyo esibabiza ngokuthi abahloli (ama-Scientists nama- Reseachers) bathe kith into efanele yokuthi sivale i-South Africa ngendlela esiyivale ngayo basithsele ukuthi uma besimile iviki elilodwa nje bekuzomosheka izinto eziningi, abantu abaningi bebezophathwa ilesifo,
naphesheya maningi amazwe athathe lelinyathelo so akusiyithi kuphela esithathe inyathelo lokuthi sivale iSouth Africa ngoba lesifo sihamba kuyoyonke indawo, kuwowonke amazwe, amazwe amaningi.

Kodwa-ke bekufanele ukuthi sithathe lelinyathelo esilithathile, ukuthi izimpilo zabantu bakithi sikwazi ukuzivikela. Amazwe amaningi nawo athathe lelinyathelo esilithathile, ngakumbi khona la eSouthern Afrika akhona amazwe athathe lelinyathelo,

Uhulumeni uyazi ukuthi isinqumo esasithatha sokuvala i-South Afrika senza ukuthi kube nzima, impilo ibe nzima kubantu abaningi la e-South Afrika futhi iphinde ibe nzima kumnotho wethu la e-South Africa.
Kuyaqala ukwenzeka lokhu, ukuthi sivale iSouth Africa ngalendlela esiyivale ngayo, lento esiyibiza “i-Lockdown” ukuvala i-South Africa. Sikwenze ngoba kunalesifo i-Coronavirus.
Ba ska etsa eng le eng e kantle ho molao. Ba ska lematsa batho ba haeso, ba sebetse hantle le batho ba haeso. Ba ba tataise, ba ba thuse ka tsena e tshwanetseng.

Le bao ba 18 000 bao re ba ntshitseng, ba security ba mapolesa le masole. Re a ba leboha ho mosebetsi ona oo ba ntseng ba o etsa bosiu le motsheare. Bao ba masole le mapolesa re ba jweditse hore ho ntho tsohle tse ba di etsang, ba leke hore ba sebetse ka tsela ya molao.

e tlamehileng hore e be ntho eo re e sebetsang kaofela ha rona re le setjhaba. Re a ba leboha batho bano ba lekang ho thusa. Ke batla ho leboha le bano ba ntseng ba sebetsa, manese a rona, dingaka tsa rona, masole le mapolesa a rona le disocial worker tsa rona.

Ho na le ba bang ba ntseng ba re founela ba batlang ho ntsha ditekenyana tse ba nang le tsona. Ba bang ba kenya di R100 ba bang ba kenya di R1000. Ba bang ba ntse ba kenya tjhelete e ka hodimonyana. Re re re amohela thuso tsohle tse batho ba ka ditlisang ka hobane sena, kannete,

Ba bang ba bona ba re, roma rona re tla inehela nako re lo thusa. Ba bang ba bona ba re, ho na le tseo tse re ka di rekang, re di tlise mmusong hore mmuso o di sebedise ho tshwana le dimasks le dintho tsena tsa ho thesta.

Ha ntse re ya pele, re fumana hore kannete, batho ba bangata ba haeso, ba bona hore bolwetsi bona ba Coronavirus, kannete bo tlisitse bothata bo boholo. Ba tla ho rona ba re, presidente re ka thusa ka tsela efeng na?

Batho ba bangata ha ba na metsebetsi, jwale bolwetsi bona kannete, bo tlo etsa hore ekhonomi ya rona kannete e theohe le ho feta. Empa re tlo leka tsela tsohle hore ekhonomi ya rona re e lokise, re e emise ka tsela e tshwanetseng. Re tla leka ka tsela tsohle.

Re leka hore re etse tjena, hore re tshidise batho ba haeso. Ntho e nngwe e entseng bothata ho rona ke hore bolwetsi bona kannete, ho ekhonomi ya lefatshe la haeso, bo tlo e isa fatshe. Ekhonomi ya rona re a tseba he e ne e ntse e sa tsamaye ka tsela e tshwanetseng.

Ha re fumana hore ho na le batho ba kenweng ke bolwetse bona, re tla batla hore ba bewe dibakeng tse itseng ho etsatsa eng? Hore bolwetsi bona re etse hore bo be contained. Bo ska tsamaya hohlehohle mona ba kena batho ba bang.

Re kena sebakeng se seng jwale sa matsatsi ana a mang a latelang mo re batlang hore re ntshe batho ba fihlang 10 000, ba tsamaya hohle, ba kene dintlong tsa batho hore ba etse ntho ena e re e bitsang test. Ba ke ba leke ho bona hore ke bafeng batho ba kenweng ke bolwetse bona.
Dipakeng tseo ho senang metsi teng, lefapaha la rona la metsi le a leka hore re fihlise metsi dibakeng tseo batho bao ba leng teng.
ri ḓo vha ri khou bvisa vhathu vha ṱoḓaho u swika kha 10 000 uri vha tshimbile Afrika Tshipembe ḽoṱhe vha tshi khou ṱola vhathu,
Ri khou dzhena kha tshiṅwe tshiga zwino, kha maḓuvha a tevhelaho. Ri khou ṱoḓa uri vhathu vhanzhi vha fhano Afrika Tshipembe vha ṱoliwe, ri kone u ṱola uri naa vha na dwadze naa,

Hu na vhaṅwe vhathu vhane vha sa vhe na haya havho, vhane vha sokou ḓidzhulela zwiṱiraṱani, ri khou ri na vhone ri ḓo vha wanela fhethu hune vha nga dzula hone. Hu na fhethu hunzhi hune hu si vhe na maḓi, ri khou lingedza uri ri swikise kha mivhundu ine i sa vhe na maḓi.

ḽa hashu ḽa Afrika Tshipembe.
Ri   khou lingedza nga nḓila dzoṱhe uri vhuleme vhune vhathu vha vha naho vhu songo vha vhuleme vhuhulwane nga maanḓa. Nga maanḓa kha havha vha mabindu vhathu vha mabindu ri khou lindedza nga nḓila dzoṱhe uri ri vha wanele thuso.

nahone kha hetshi tshifhinga nga uri ri khou ita zwithu zwe ra si zwi ḓowele, ndi lwa u thoma ri tshi ṱangana na vhuleme hovhu. Zwi a itea uri ri ita dziphoswo fhaḽaa na fhaḽa, fhedzi ri khou ri vhathu vha ri farele ngauri hezwi zwine ra vha khazwo a zwi athu itea shangoni

khou tshuwa uri dwadze ḽi nga ḓi swika khavho, vhaṅwe ndi matshudeni a vha khou wana pfunzo dzine vha tea uri vha dzi wane, ri a zwi ḓivha uri vhathu vhanzhi vha khou vhona vhuleme nga maanḓa kha nḓila ine ra khou ri vha dzule fhasi vha songo ya huṅwe na huṅwe,

tshelede kha mabindu avho vhane vha shuma kha dzi factories na dzi maini hoṱhe hoṱhe na vhone ri a ḓivha uri zwi khou vha vhaisa ngauri vha khou elekanya uri a vha nga wani miholo yavho wo fhelelaho, vhathu vhahulwane vhane khamusi vha na miṅwaha yo yaho nṱha na vhone vha

Ho sala maḓuvha a 17 zwino ro vala South Africa yoṱhe, ndi maḓuvha anea ḓo ita vhuleme kha vhathu vha hashu ri a zwi ḓivha vhabebi vha ḓo vha vha tshi khou elekanya uri vhana vhavho vha ite mini kha maḓuvha aya, vha mabindu vha ḓo vha vha khou elekanya uri a vha khou ita
Ri songo lingedza uri ri elekanye uri heḽi dwadze ndi dwadze ḽa vhaṅwe vhathu riṋe ḽi nga swike kha riṋe.

Ngauri ri songo vhuya ra elekanya uri heḽi dwadze ḽi nga si swike kha riṋe.  Ḽi dzhena kha muṅwe na muṅwe arali u na tshelede na musi u si na tshelede kana u kana u murema u ya ḓi ḽi wana heḽi dwadze, kana u dzula dziḓoroboni kana u dzula mahayani ḽi a ḓi u swikela.

na avho vha ne vha ita mishumo yo khethiwaho yo ṅwalwaho kha regulations . Arali ra sa ita nga u ralo zwi nga itea uri hezwi muthu a tshi sokou tshimbila hoṱhe hoṱhe dwadze heḽi arali u naḽo ḽi nga kha  ḓi dzhena kha vhaṅwe vhathu.

Vhathu vho fanelaho uri vha bve dzinḓuni dzavho ndi havha vhathu vha khou shuma zwa vhutshilo dzi health workers, maswole, mapholisa na vhenevha vha dzi traffic na vhane vha shuma  hune ha itwa zwiḽiwa, ndi vhone vhathu vhe ra vha tendela uri vha bvela phanḓa na mishumo yavho,

tshine ra khou tshi ṱoḓa ndi uri vhathu vha dzule mahayani avho vha bve fhedzi arali vha tshi khou ya u renga zwiḽiwa, mishonga, vha tshi ya u dzhia mindende yavho vha tshi ya ha dokotela kana kiḽiniki arali vha tshi khou lwala.

Hezwi zwi a ri vhavha nga maanḓa vhanzhi vha khou tevhela zwe ra zwi amba fhedzi havha vhane vha sa khou zwi tevhela vha khou ri vhaisa dzimbilu nga maanḓa ngauri vhone vha khou elekanya uri heḽi dwadze ḽi nga si vha fare and tshine ra khou tshi humbela,

Ri takalela zwenezwi fhedzi hu na vhaṅwe vha sa khou tevhela hezwi zwe ra amba, vha khou bvela phanḓa na zwe vha ḓowela u zwi ita, zwino ho no lovha vhathu vhararu hu na vhathu vha 1 328 vho farwaho nga heḽi dwadze.

Ndi takalela uri vhathu vha fhano Afrika Tshipembe ro ri u vala tshiṅwe na tshiṅwe vhunzhi ha vhathu  vho mboḓi tevhela hezwi zwe muvhuso wa amba zwone. Ro ri vhathu kha vha dzule mahayani , vhunzhi ha vhathu vho dzula mahayani.
Vha ri arali ro vha ro ima vhege nthihi ho vha hu tshi ḓo vha na khombo khulwane nga maanḓa ngauri huvhu vhulwadze ho vha hu tshi ḓo fara vhathu vhanzhi ha itea khombo khulwane nga maanḓa.
Hu na havha vhathu vhane ra vha vhidza uri ndi dzi scientist ndi vhathu vho thanyaho nga maanḓa vho ri vhudza uri  ro dzhia vhukando ho fanelaho ha u imisa tshiṅwe na tshiṅwe Afrika Tshipembe.
Hovhu vhulwadze vhu khou phaḓaladzea kha vhathu vhanzhi nahone hu fanela uri huvhe na zwine ra ḓo zwi ita uri vhu songo phaḓaladzea nga  nḓila ine ya tshuwisa ya nga vhulaha vhathu vhanzhi.
Na henefha kha mashango a Southern Africa heḽi ḽa hashu hu na maṅwe mashango o valaho. Ri tshi sedzisisa zwavhuḓi ri wana uri na maṅwe mashango a seli o ḓi ita zwezwo.

Fhedzi hezwi zwa u vala tshiṅwe na tshiṅwe kha shango ḽa hashu zwo fanela uri zwi itee ngauri vhutshilo ha vhathu ndi hone hune ra fanela u vhu vhea phanḓa ha tshiṅwe na tshiṅwe.
Maṅwe mashango na one o ita zwenezwi zwa u vala tshiṅwe na tshiṅwe kha mashango a havho.
Muvhuso wa hashu u a ḓivha uri hovhu vhukando he ra vhu dzhia ha u vala Afrika Tshipembe zwi khou ḓisa vhuleme kha vhathu vhanzhi, vhuleme hovhu vhu khou konḓisa vhutshilo ha vhathu vha hashu.

Ro imisa tshiṅwe na tshiṅwe nga nnḓa ha izwo zwe ra zwi vhala uri zwi nga bvela phanḓa. Hezwi ro zwi itiswa ngauri hu na dwadze heḽi ḽihulu ḽo welaho shango ḽoṱhe. A ḽi ngo wela shango ḽa hashu fhedzi ḽo wela na maṅwe mashango.

Madekwe ro bvisa mulaedza malugana na hovhu vhuleme ho ri welaho fhano Afrika Tshipembe malugana na heḽi dwadze ḽihulwane ḽa coronavirus. Ndo amba nga uri ndi ḓuvha ḽa vhuraru mulovha ro vala shango heḽi ḽa hashu.
