If we are to meet the aspirations of #Agenda2063 of an Africa free from conflict, war & human rights violations, we must ensure that peace dawns in Libya, and that its people assume their rightful place among the stable, prosperous & peace-loving nations of the world.

Addressing the Libyan Congress of the People in March 1999, President Mandela said: “The men & women of Libya are prominent amongst those who will help make the next century one in which our continent & the developing world as a whole, take their rightful place in world affairs.”

It is goal we all share, and it is a goal we must all work together to see realised.
 
#SilencingTheGuns #TheAfricaWeWant

I wish to stress that the negotiation of a ceasefire, its enforcement & observation is the critical first step in creating conducive conditions for a lasting peace. It will pave the way for an all-inclusive inter-Libyan dialogue, and lead to national reconciliation and unity.

We further support the goal of unification of the country’s institutions, the holding of national elections, and enhancing security, stability and living conditions for the Libyan people. This includes the unification and integration of the Libyan armed forces.
As South Africa we have repeatedly stated our support for this, including recently when we delivered our statement on the situation in Libya during a @UN Security Council debate.
We welcome the deadline set by the UN Support Mission in Libya (UNSMIL) for a draft ceasefire agreement to be reached and finalised in March.

All Libyan parties, community leaders and non-governmental organisations should commit to dialogue. The parties must urgently commit to a ceasefire and thereafter work towards securing a political agreement.

In this regard, we view the implementation of the arms embargo as an important instrument to stem the illicit flow of arms into Libya and the Sahel region. We wish to reiterate that there can be no military solution to the conflict in Libya.

We reaffirm the decision of the 33rd Ordinary Session of the Assembly of the AU calling on all outside actors to immediately and permanently put an end to their interventions that continue to undermine the sovereignty, unity and territorial integrity of Libya.
We emphasise Libyan ownership of this process without the interference of external actors.

We must continue to advance AU-UN collaboration as we work towards a political solution, reconciliation process and lasting peace; a process that must be led by the Libyan people, driven by the Libyan people and upheld by the Libyan people.

We must be firm and resolute that Africa’s problems must be solved by Africans.
 
#SilencingTheGuns #TheAfricaWeWant

The convening of this Contact Group is a resounding affirmation of the fact that it is the Libyan people and them alone who must determine the country’s future course, and that our role is to actively support them in this regard.
 
#SilencingTheGuns

In this, the year that the African Union has dedicated to Silencing the Guns in Africa, we must be at the forefront of efforts to bring the warring parties together.
 
#SilencingTheGuns #TheAfricaWeWant

In spite of this, we continue to stress the need for inclusive dialogue between all Libyan parties to the conflict, in recognition that it is only by sitting around the negotiating table that a durable solution can be reached.
 
#SilencingTheGuns #TheAfricaWeWant

We are disappointed that the much-anticipated ceasefire talks of the Libyan Joint Military Group in Geneva, Switzerland from the 18th to the 24th of February 2020 did not result in a positive outcome.
 
#SilencingTheGuns

As the @_AfricanUnion we note with mounting concern the devastating impact of the conflict on the lives of Libyan civilians, particularly on women and children. In this regard, we call for a ceasefire to be implemented with urgent and immediate effect.

Furthermore, continued political and military interference by external actors in the affairs of Libya undermine the fundamental interests and rights of the Libyan people and their aspirations for freedom, peace, democracy and development.
The ongoing strife in Libya has dangerous repercussions for the security and stability of the region and the continent in general.

On the 20th of February 2020, Tripoli came under heavy rocket fire, breaking the ceasefire that was in place at the time. A strategic port was hit, resulting in the peace talks being temporarily suspended.

Since we met in Addis Ababa, there has been a further deterioration of the peace and security situation in Libya, and this has in turn has worsened the already grave humanitarian situation.
 
Military activity in the capital Tripoli has escalated.

As the Assembly we agreed to establish this Contact Group to provide political leadership and to promote the coordination of international efforts in pursuit of a lasting solution to the Libyan crisis. #SilencingTheGuns

Let me take this opportunity to thank our host, His Excellency President Sassou N’Guesso for convening the inaugural meeting of the @_AfricanUnion Contact Group on Libya, established pursuant to the decision of the 33rd Session of the Assembly of Heads of State & Government
Inaugural Meeting of the Contact Group on Libya #SilencingTheGuns #TheAfricaWeWant #BetterAfricaBetterWorld

In recognition of the tasks set by #ANC54 and the ideals for which our movement was founded, and in recognising the challenges we face and the tasks we must undertake, the #ANCNEC declares 2020 as:
THE YEAR OF UNITY, SOCIO-ECONOMIC RENEWAL AND NATION BUILDING. #ANC108

Our final priority is to build a better Africa, better world
Africa is poised on the threshold of a new era of integration, growth, prosperity and development.
But to seize these opportunities requires a concerted effort to silence the guns. #ANC108

Our seventh priority is social cohesion and safe communities.
We will ensure that our law-enforcement agencies are supported so that they can investigate thoroughly and prosecute effectively without fear or favour. #ANC108

Our sixth priority is education and skills for a changing world
The matric results released this week demonstrate that South Africa has made great strides in improving educational outcomes over the last 25 years, particularly in township and rural schools. #ANC108

Our fifth priority is to eradicate poverty and improve people’s lives.
We will intensify both job creation and other measures to improve the lives of the poor. #ANC108

Our fourth priority is an effective land reform programme.
The struggle to return the land of this country to all the people of South Africa remains a historical and economic imperative. #ANC108

Our third priority is to pursue investment, jobs and inclusive growth. The Freedom Charter’s call that ‘The People Shall Share in the Country’s Wealth!’ ‘There Shall Be Work and Security’ remains relevant.
The creation of jobs remains our central priority for 2020. #ANC108

Our second priority is to build a united and cohesive society.
We must bridge the divides between South Africans, be they economic, social, political or cultural. #ANC108

Our first priority is to build a capable state that serves all the people.
We will continue to restore our public institutions to a higher standard of accountability and service. #ANC108

As we celebrate the 65th anniversary of the Freedom Charter we must give effect to the profound statement that South Africa belongs to all who live in it, black and white. Our priorities this year will be informed by the demands contained in that historic document. #ANC108

We have heard and understood the message that the people’s continued support for the ANC is conditional on the revitalisation of the organisation as an effective instrument of fundamental change. #ANC108
Through their votes in the election last year, the people of South Africa signaled their clear expectation that the ANC undergo a process of renewal. #ANC108

The 108 years of the existence of the ANC have been marked by advances and setbacks, progress and detours, mistakes and corrections. Our movement has shown its ability to unite and heal divisions, the ability to analyse changing conditions and adapt strategies & tactics. #ANC108

In die jaar vorentoe moet ons vordering maak om 'n Verenigde, etiese en sterk ANC te bou wat die mense van Suid-Afrika effektief kan bedien. Ons moet ons samelewing verenig om dit te transformeer, en ons moet ons samelewing transformeer om dit te verenig. #ANC108
We will act with urgency and purpose. We have heard you say that we must hurry up and implement our policies. You have said ‘khawuleza’. #ANC108

We will work together to realise the enormous potential of our youth by tackling joblessness, poverty and inequality; ending hunger and homelessness; and developing the skills that our people and economy need. #ANC108

It speaks directly to the experiences and the aspirations of the people who we have met with and spoken with over the last week. This is a decisive moment for our country as we begin a new decade of hope and expectation, of promise and opportunity. #ANC108
Today, we are releasing the January 8th Statement of the African National Congress National Executive Committee, which sets out the priorities and tasks of our movement for 2020. #ANC108

Kule veki iphelileyo, thina, iinkokheli ze-African National Congress, sihambe ezitratweni satyelela amakhaya abantu bethu kweli phondo. Sithethile na-bantu baseMantla-Kapa ngobomi benu, malunga nobunzima enijongane nabo, neminqweno yenu namabhongo enu. #ANC108

On this day and at this place, we pay tribute to the likes of Sol Plaatje, the first Secretary General of the African National Congress, and to leaders like Charlotte Maxeke, ZR Mahabane, ZK Matthews, Frances Baard, John Taolo Gaetsewe and Mittah Seperepere. #ANC108
The ANC lives. The ANC leads. #ANC108
ANC Fundraising Gala Dinner #ANC108
ANC Fundraising Gala Dinner #ANC108

We have a government that is hard at work to restore our economy. #ANC108
Despite our challenges and difficulties, we will overcome. #ANC108

At the Mayibuye Multi-purpose Centre in Galeshewe for the cake cutting ceremony to mark 108 years of the ANC. In 2018 we embarked on a revolutionary pilgrimage and visited the gravesites of ANC leaders who were there in the beginning. ANC has a rich history and ancestry. #ANC108

We thank the family of Cde Sol Plaatje for giving us the honour to spend time with them on this special morning. We may not be Plaatjes in blood, but we are all Plaatjes in vision, spirit and all that he stood for. #ANC108

During #ANC54, we recommitted to the full unity & renewal of the ANC, with disciplined membership, committed servant leaders who subscribe to the highest values of the ANC. We will rebuild the ANC to be strong, powerful, and continue to serve the interests of the people. #ANC108

To the sacred memory of Cde Solomon Tsekisho Plaatjie. Your intellectualism inspired the vision of the African National Congress. We pledge to you that we will continue on the path you crafted in the beginning. We will restore the ANC to be the ANC that you envisaged. #ANC108

Cde Sol Plaatje’s most famous words summed up the horror and shock of these violent dispossessions: “Awakening on Friday morning, June 20th, 1913, the South African Native found himself, not actually a slave, but a pariah in the land of his birth.” #ANC108
The Natives Land Act divided South Africa into white and Black areas, with Africans being labeled ‘squatters’ and forcibly removed from their land and homes.

Sol Plaatje was instrumental in the formation of the South African Native National Congress in 1912, which became African National Congress in 1923, formed in part as a response to the erosion of African political & economic rights as threatened by the looming Natives’ Land Act.

Today marks the founding of the African National Congress. Cde Sol Plaatje, the first Secretary-General of the ANC, was among those present at the founding conference in 1912. We visited his gravesite this morning to draw inspiration from his life. #ANC108
Wreath laying Ceremony of Solomon Tshekisho Plaatje #ANC

Today we celebrate with @KaizerChiefs, founded 50 years ago by Bra Kaizer Motaung. The South African story can never be complete without the story of this legendary club. We salute you for the contribution made to nation building and fostering social cohesion. #KaiserChiefs50

The African National Congress is in the province of the Northern Cape to mark the anniversary of the founding of the movement on 8 January 1912. We are embarking on buildup activities and mass mobilisation drive towards the January 8 Statement rally this Saturday. #ANC108

History will one day record the pain of a nation that suffered a huge loss of life at a time when conditions could not allow us to grieve and comfort each other or celebrate the lives of our departed heroes whose presence had enriched our lives.
Isilo was deeply loved, trusted and highly valued by the people.

Throughout his reigning days Isilo displayed wisdom, fairness and objectivity in approaching challenges in society. 

He was sensitive to the plight of our people and reached out to lend a hand of support to those in need

This earned Isilo a special place in our hearts
Over all these years we worked with His Majesty we never failed to appreciate his generosity, kind-hearted nature, warmth, caring spirit and his deep respect and love for the people he led

We had to repeat these trips many times during the difficult days of political violence to attend funerals, peace meetings, service delivery events and cultural events. The era of no-go zones had come to pass.

As we joined caucus in legislature in Pietermaritzburg at 11:00, we were still in disbelief of the night gone by as we gave the account to our comrades. 
 
KwaZulu-Natal had turned a corner!!

We reached NND around 22:00

We want to say thank you to all those on the frontlines, for all the hard work and perseverance. #TheAngelWingsProject

We also acknowledge the fact that all the other cadres of healthcare workers rose to the occasion in the fight against COVID-19. We have emerged as world leaders in health emergency repose because of the expertise, courage and and stamina on the field. #TheAngelWingsProject

Although this was achieved under very challenging conditions within our health system, nurses soldiered on persistently and remained at the forefront even where their own lives were at risk. #TheAngelWingsProject

Since South Africa reported its first Covid-19 case on this very day (05 May 2020), we have witnessed the steadfastness and resilience of this cadre of healthcare workers through their great contribution in the response to the pandemic. #TheAngelWingsProject

WHO had designated 2020 the “International Year of the Nurse and Midwife” to celebrate the great work of nurses and midwives, highlight the challenging conditions they often face, and advocate for increased investment in the nursing profession. #TheAngelWingsProject

Thank You for giving a voice to ordinary people so that our professionals can be recognized with the dignity and humility that reflects their work ethic for which they are being recognized today

#TheAngelWingsProject

It is not often that awards are conferred to professionals by ordinary people and yet these inaugural awards have captured the the wonderful spirit of appreciation that so many South Africans from all walks of life have for our health care workers. #TheAngelWingsProject
Today has been a very emotional day as we reflect on the past year living with the Coronavirus. I want to thank you for inviting us to witness this occasion. #TheAngelWingsProject

We want to say South Africa is on course, we don’t have the same fear we had a year ago. Our health workers are currently receiving vaccines. #GreysHospitalVisit

Crunch time came when we saw that every second day the numbers of new patients identified were doubling. It became clear we had to create space to be able to absorb the number of patients that were coming. #GreysHospitalVisit

When the first patient was diagnosed we came here and it really lifted my spirits when the nurses sang and assured us that they were ready to treat COVID patients. #GreysHospitalVisit
It has been a rough year, we have made some mistakes but we have also achieved a lot. #GreysHospitalVisit

I look back on this day as a day that was filled with anxiety and trepidation. I had to call the President and say that “Mr President, this is the call I had wished never to have to make” #GreysHospitalVisit

An additional 500,000 doses are expected to arrive over the next four weeks, supplemented by another 20 million doses of the Pfizer vaccine that is expected to be received at the end of March 2021.
We have managed to successfully secure 9 million doses of the Johnson&Johnson vaccine, with the  delivery of the first batch of 80,000 on course and the vaccination due to begin this week.

The Astra Zeneca doses we purchased have been offered to the AU platform, of which we are part of, and the AU will distribute to those countries who have already expressed interest in acquiring the stock.

The recent announcement around the limited efficacy of the AstraZeneca vaccine, which we had already procured, was certainly disappointing, however we were determined not to be derailed from our commitment to rollout vaccines in February.
We have heard the clarion call made by the people of South Africa to accelerate our capacity to develop and manufacture our own COVID-19 tools, including vaccines.
As government we are actively engaging manufacturers and suppliers of the COVID-19 vaccines through different but interrelated channels.

To ensure that our battle against the pandemic remains grounded on the principles of “solidarity and compassion”, our strategy is that the State will be the sole purchaser of the vaccines for the country, irrespective of the manufacturer and source.
As a matter of fact, we are one of very few countries that is so precise in its vaccination approach by implementing the guidance from the genomics surveillance expertise.
It is also our scientists who are currently guiding pharmaceutical companies as they adapt their vaccines to accommodate the emerging variants.

It was our scientists, enabled by the investments of the Department of Science and Innovation, that discovered the 501Y.V2 variant and in the process alerted the scientists in the United Kingdom who subsequently identified the dominant variant in their country
Our risk-adjusted response and differentiated approach to hotspots has given lessons to other countries that adopted the same approach we pioneered.

We were lauded for our community screening and testing campaign, which not only allowed us to identify high transmission and low transmission areas in our communities, but also allowed us to directly communicate with our community members.

Allow me to commend His Excellency the President for a powerful State of the Nation Address. The address gave an update on previous commitments, a vision for the future and responded to the current COVID-19 crisis.
When the African National Congress took over national governance in 1994, we did so with the express intention of dismantling the shameful legacy of apartheid.

Whilst we face numerous challenges in these extraordinary times, we remain committed to ending the TB epidemic. I trust that with the assistance of our multi-lateral and bi-lateral partners, technical agencies and civil society we will succeed in doing that.
#TBSurvey

We know that, in this country, children are affected by TB and many of them go onto developing chronic lung problems. I therefore hope that the work will continue and that children below fifteen will be included in the subsequent studies. .#TBSurvey

I commend the work that has been done to shed light on TB prevalence in the country and the factors that continue to drive the pandemic. However, I hope the research community will indulge me as I observe that the survey focused on adults >15 years. #TBSurvey

Integrating TB and COVID-19 testing using Gene Xpert technology. The National Health Laboratory Service championed the use of Gene-Xpert for mobile screening and testing units early in the pandemic and this greatly increased our capacity to test using Gene-Xpert. #TBSurvey
Home delivery of medicines for patients by community health workers and inclusion of TB medicines in the CCMDD system. #TBSurvey
Just over 1 in 10 of those tested were found to have TB. These individuals are now on treatment. I would like to encourage people to use this service. #TBSurvey

It guides users  through a series of questions and then advises them on whether they need a TB test or not. I am informed that over 9000 South Africans have screened themselves for TB using the app and over 600 have had a TB test. #TBSurvey

The TB Health Check App has been developed and can be accessed by dialing *134*832*5# or send 'TB' to +27600123456 on WhatsApp. This App provides an easy way for everyone to screen themselves for TB. #TBSurvey

The use of digital technology for TB. We have made a lot of strides in the health informations system space during the COVID-19 response. We will therefore leverage some of these technologies for TB screening, contact tracing and treatment adherence. #TBSurvey
We therefore need to look at innovative ways of providing health services in an integrated manner for efficiency. These should include: #TBSurvey

The impact of the Covid-19 pandemic on health services and TB in particular is well documented. A lot of effort will be required to mitigate the negative impact of Covid-19 and still ensure that we attain our set targets. #TBSurvey

− Continued effective communication with clear messages that reach all our people
− Develop and implement strategies to address stigma and discrimination
− Scaling up access to treatment for TB infection to all eligible people living with HIV, all household contacts and people living with silicosis. #TBSurvey

− Optimising the use of existing diagnostic tests such as Gene- Xpert, urine LAM assay. In addition, expanding first and second line drug susceptibility tests by ensuring that all people who are eligible are tested. #TBSurvey
This would require mobile/ portable equipment with artificial intelligence (AI) solutions to simplify interpretation for clinicians. #TBSurvey
− Expanding the use of chest x-rays for TB screening at facility and community level. This was based on the results of pilot study which is currently being conducted in 6 districts. #TBSurvey
− Routinely testing people living with HIV, household TB contacts and people previously treated for TB, irrespective of symptoms. #TBSurvey

Some of the key recommendations emanating from the TB Survey Report are:
− Increasing access to TB screening and testing services through outreach programmes using mobile testing and x-ray facilities. These services should target the hard to reach populations

What is encouraging is that we have established a solid foundation for resilient emergency response systems. By implementing the recommendations, we will reinforce and elevate some of the key strategies we have learnt from our COVID-19 response. #TBSurvey
This report has been released while we are in the midst of a raging COVID-19 pandemic, which has, in itself, highlighted some of the key issues within the TB Prevalence survey report. #TBSurvey
The social science must guide us to ensure our interventions are meaningful and impactful. #TBSurvey

4. Men, the elderly (>65years) and people in the age groups 35 - 44 years are least able to access TB services
We need to analyze the dynamics that have resulted in this finding for these age groups. #TBSurvey

The work of advocacy will need to be adopt a multisectoral approach- we, as government, are ready to forge the necessary partnerships with civil society, social partners and colleagues in communication to spread the word throughout the land. #TBSurvey
Previously, we focused on symptomatic patients and those living with HIV. We now need to encourage everyone to screen and test for TB to achieve elimination. #TBSurvey

3. A higher proportion of HIV negative people have asymptomatic TB than People Living with HIV
This has been a key finding which will require a shift in the way we achieve proactive health seeking behaviour.  #TBSurvey

2. People with TB symptoms delay to seek care
Late presentation for care results in advanced and complicated TB disease leading to avoidable hospitalisation and deaths. In addition this increases the chances of transmission to close contacts. #TBSurvey

1. There are many people with undetected TB in the communities
The implications of this is continued transmission. To break the cycle of transmission we need to extend services to communities through outreach programmes and sustain infection control practices from COVID-19
These are some of the findings which highlight key aspects of our TB response: #TBSurvey

There are lessons on community engagement and multi-sectoral partnerships that we can learn from provincial experiences, which we can take to scale. This should include the expansion of the social protection network to reach poor, vulnerable and disadvantaged groups. #TBSurvey

Access to health services is a constitutional right. As government, our commitment is to realize a long and heathy life for all our citizens. This survey was undertaken to ensure that our services are responsive to the lived experience of our communities. #TBSurvey

We should however not forget the social drivers and barriers which continue to fuel the epidemic. Interventions must integrate an effective strategy to deal with socio-economic determinants, through a coordinated effort with all stakeholders that empower communities. #TBSurvey

The continued prevalence of TB has been mainly driven by the concurrent HIV epidemic, however, much has been gained in  reducing the burden due to our high coverage with antiretroviral treatment. #TBSurvey
As a high burden country, South Africa continues to battle a TB epidemic. In addition, our rates of drug resistant TB, though declining, continue to pose a public health risk. #TBSurvey
Phaahla: Only if we work together, can we defeat this. #TBSurvey
Phaahla: some of the Covid-19 interventions can be used in our handling of TB. We must make use of the challenges of Covid-19 to help us tackle TB. #TBSurvey
Phaahla: The advent of Covid-19 has affected access to TB treatment. Some people avoided public spaces and treatment for fear of contracting the virus. #TBSurvey
Phaahla: As a country we have made great progress in the treatment of TB & HIV-Aids. #TBSurvey
Phaahla: the aim of this report is to help us reduce the risk of transmission of HIV. #TBSurvey

There is a special arrangement on section 21, which doctors able to apply for. We are aware of the outcry, there is a team that will be looking at it. #GPvisit19Jan

As it stands ivermectin has been registered for use in animals. Our guide is WHO, they have not recommended the use of ivermectin. We need to ensure that the correct trials have taken place, before SAHPRA can approve the use. #GPvisit19Jan
We must also say throughout the whole world, there is a great burden on manufacturers. South Africa has not delayed. #GPvisit19Jan
The availability of vaccines is our first priority. We’ve actually signed up for the J&J vaccine, we are still going through negotiations though. There are others #GPvisit19Jan

On vaccines; I would like to say to the health workers in particular, one of the most important things is the administration of the vaccine. Personal immunity is for the frontline workers. Herd immunity is reducing the risk of spreading the infection. #GPvisit19Jan
Gauteng has started showing a slight downward trend. It is still too soon to celebrate. We are waiting to see what happens in another week or so. #GPvisit19Jan
We would like people to continue wearing their masks etc. as they have been doing so well. #GPvisit19Jan

At this point, we’ve got over 51 000 health workers who have tested positive for #COVID19 and just under 600 that have passed on. It is very sad for us and we do wish to convey our condolences to their loved ones. #GPvisit19Jan
It doesn’t mean the virus is more severe, to contain the virus we need to continue with what we have been doing. #GPvisit19Jan

The problem of exhaustion is real. It has hit us more , to be honest because this surge came faster than we expected. It has partly to do with the level of complacency in society. We have also seen that there is a new variant that is more transmissible. #GPvisit19Jan
I’ve been impressed to see the level of participation of all different levels, including management to handle the situations that arise. #GPvisit19Jan
We went to KZN yesterday, tomorrow we will visit Limpopo. #GPvisit19Jan

We have visited Steve Biko. We even engaged the chairman and secretary of the union, on the shortage of PPE. They’ve got a system and it is working, of late it is not coming up as an issue. We would also like to thank the unions.#GPvisit19Jan

We came here to understand what the situation is and how things are going. We also came to thank the staff. We want to express our sincere gratitude, we appreciate it and you are the ones that are making the difference. #GPvisit19Jan.
Being briefed at Charlotte Maxeke hospital. #GPvisit19Jan

It is therefore important to say they must continue their work in a safe environment with PPE, we also want to say thank you to the unions for this. #KZNvisit18Jan

Our focus now, is whilst we want to make sure there is good management at hospitals, we need to begin to create an awareness that there is going to be a very important need to embrace the vaccines. #KZNvisit18Jan

We must all wear masks, ensure distancing, hand washing and sanitising. If you have gadgets, such as the media does, keep sanitising those too, as we are constantly touching them. #KZNvisit18Jan

Speaking on Newzroom Afrika and the SABC this morning, addressing concerns which emerged after Thursday’s announcement that an agreement had been reached with Serum Institute of India (SII) to procure a vaccine this month

@MorningLiveSABC we are within the right time to acquire the vaccines. We will also acquire the number of vaccines needed for 2/3rds of our population. I just want to assure all South Africans we are on course.

@MorningLiveSABC the estimation takes us to about 1,5 million. It is a whole package; public and private sectors, doctors, nurses, general workers, security etc. It is across the spectrum that will be vaccinated.
@Newzroom405 we have spoken to Serum Institute, our President has also spoken to the Prime Minister of India. We have our agreement and will receive the vaccines. There is no issue on our end.
@Newzroom405 The availability of the vaccine is a real boost in our fight against #COVID19.
@ukhozi_fm Kubalulekile ukugeza izandla nokusebenzisa ama sanitizers. Kubalulekile nokuma nigqagqane lokhu kosiza noma igciwane lingashintshashintsha ukuthi sivikeleke.

@ukhozi_fm Kubalulekile ukuthi abantu bazi ukuthi ukusetshenziswa kwezimfonyo, kubalulekile uma bephuma behlangana nabantu bezigqoke ngazo zonke izikhathi. Noma umuntu esendaweni enesiminyaminya kungenawo umoya oshayayo aqaphele.
@ukhozi_fm Sisebenze nenhlangano I covax eyabheka imjovo ewu 9 , bathi bazosibhekela ekuwona ozosebenza ngendlela umgomo. Kumanje basawubheka ukuze begculiseke ngo mgomo.
@ukhozi_fm Asithathanga kude ukuthola imgomo, isikhathi sisakhona ukuthola imgomo. Izinhlelo zomgomo zisa khona. Kade siyisebenza indaba yokuthola imgomo.

@ukhozi_fm Kunomuthi I (dexamethasone) uma umuntu ephethwe ilesifo amasosha omzimba ake ephume elwe naleli gciwane, ephazamise ezinye ezindawo ezisemaphasheni nase mzimbeni. Bese ngaleyondlela kubanzima ukulwisana negciwane ugcine ube nezikhwehlela.
Kubalulekile ukuthi uma yenziwa, yenziwe ochwephesha.

@ukhozi_fm Kukhona abanye odokotela abathi kukhona umshini abawusebenzisa ukuzibheka lezi khwehlela phakathi emaphishini mese bayazi khipha, okuyi broncoscope. Ngokucwaninga esilutholile leyonto noma ungayenza akusho ukuthi iyona ndlela abantu ekufanele belashwe ngayo.

@ukhozi_fm Leyonto yenzeka ngoba usuke uxakeke esifubeni, kube nezikhwehlela ezimbanjeni emaphashani. Okwenza ukuthi umuntu mayekhwehlela kungakhwehleleki ngoba ucinaniswe ilezi khwehlela nga phakathi.
@ukhozi_fm Ucwaningo lusaqhubeka, ukuthi ume wangenwa ileli gciwane kungenzeka uma libuya leligciwane abukaqini ubufakazi ukuthi umzimba ungalamukela ngenye indlela.
@ukhozi_fm Sithole ukuthi noma lingayona ingozi kakhulu, lingena kakhulu nangokushesha kunakuqala. Lingena 70% kakhulu bebe baningi abantu abagulayo.

@ukhozi_fm Amagciwane awama virus anakho ukuhamba, ehamba eshintsha. Uthi umzimba usukwazi ukulwa nalo lishintshe khona umzimba ungeke ulinqande. Nase Ngilandi, nase Brazil lishintshashintshile ayi ngoba kuyigciwane elisha.

Kwezinye izindawo baqalile, kwenziwe ukuthi kungaka caci ukuthi imaphi ama vaccine angasebenza bona base bevele bekhokhe imali. #VaccineStrategy
Kodwa ngobuningi bazo kugcine kungacacile kuthina. Ukuthi imuphi ozogcine uphumelele. #VaccineStrategy

Sidinga ukuthi wonke umuntu agcine aze ethole ukugonywa ukuze lesisifo singamngeni. Ngaleyondlela besilusebenza kakhulu loludaba. Inkinga yalo mgomo ukuthi , inkampani beziningi kakhulu ebezizama ukwakha umgomo okuwona ozophumelela.  #VaccineStrategy
Lokhu siyazi ukuthi kwakuyinto vele esiyishilo ukuthi iyona ndlela esizozivikela ngayo kulesisifo. Ngoba noma selapheka sibhebhetheka ngamandla. #VaccineStrategy
Sifisa ukwazisa umphakathi ukuthi uhlelo lwanamhlanje besizochaza ngesimo senqubekela phambili odabeni, lolutholakala koku goma ukugomela isifo seCovid. #VaccineStrategy

“The funds that will come from the private sector and medical schemes will be done in social solidarity. Once we have agreed on a vaccine, then we will know the exact amount involved.“#VaccineStrategy

DDG, Dr Anban Pillay: 
COVAX is working hard to bring the date forward, but there is no firm date yet. We’ve also been in bilateral discussions and are fairly confident we will have vaccines in quarter one. #VaccineStrategy
DDG, Dr Anban Pillay: We’re working hard to procure a sufficient supply of vaccines in the shortest possible time. We are a part of the COVAX facility. #VaccineStrategy

DDG, Dr Anban Pillay: The approach we will be using is phased; the first phase will be our frontline health workers. Phase two will be essential workers, persons who are in congregate settings, and persons who are over the age of 18 who have comorbidities. #VaccineStrategy

DDG, Dr Anban Pillay: The vaccine rollout will be led nationally, there will be one procurement approach and we will then work with our provincial colleagues and the private sector for distribution. #VaccineStrategy #VaccineRollout

DDG, Dr Anban Pillay: 
When we supply, we need to monitor and track the stock and the vaccine uptake use and coverage. Vaccine must also be monitored for perceived adverse events so we need an effective monitoring system for that. #VaccineStrategy #VaccineRollout
As announced, new MAC advisories have been made public. Please find those links below:
We are in sensitive discussions. I have been involved in some of these discussions and can mention a few of them, Astra Zeneca, Moderna, etc. #VaccineStrategy
To optimize availability of stock for ourselves we are negotiating with all the manufacturers and pursuing those who are indicating appetite to make vaccines available sooner. #VaccineStrategy

The process is now at a stage where the Council for Medical Schemes has engaged various medical schemes and I have signed amendments of regulations to allow for vaccines and other therapeutics to be part of the prescribed minimum benefits. #VaccineStrategy
Additionally we have embarked on Public Private Partnerships with very good outcomes and we have approached medical aids to be part of the co-financing.#VaccineStrategy

We are targeting minimum of 67% of the population to achieve herd immunity and the approach will be a phased rollout of the vaccine beginning with the most vulnerable in our population. #VaccineStrategy

We have set up structures to expedite financing, sourcing and procurement
and therefore the issue of the vaccine strategy will get undivided attention from the department and government. #VaccineStrategy

The vaccines will need to be made available quickly so that most of our citizens are
covered by the end of the first year of rollout - this year. #VaccineStrategy
The only way of being able to deal with the #COVID19 pandemic is the provision of immunity through vaccination. We have been trying to follow what the best way is to deal with this. #VaccineStrategy
We have always said the second wave is going to be coming and the only way we will be protected is by developing herd immunity through vaccination. #VaccineStrategy

Watch Live: New Year's Eve candle lighting ceremony to  commemorate and remember the lives lost through #COVID19 this year #NYEcandlelighting
@kznhealth
But this is why it becomes ever more important to focus our minds collectively on these simple interventions that do save lives. #NYECandleLighting

I must echo the President’s plea that we remain absolutely focused on what each and every one of us can do now to protect ourselves and each other. We know that, in particular, wearing of masks and social distancing are very difficult to do all the time. #NYECandleLighting
Therefore it is important to continue wearing a mask, social distancing, washing hands and sanitising. #NYECandleLighting
The other fact is we do not have a vaccine right now. The virus will not wait until these matters are resolved: no matter how fast we work. #NYECandleLighting

However, I am concerned that the dominance of these issues takes away our focus on the things that will save our lives now. The fact is the virus will continue to mutate and there will always be a new variant discovered- that is only a matter of time. #NYECandleLighting

Vaccines have also dominated the conversation and we appreciate that everyone shares our sense of urgency to procure and rollout vaccines equitably, beginning with the most vulnerable in our population. #NYECandleLighting

But more importantly, health care workers are not just labour for the health care system- they are active members of society, breadwinners, community leaders, counselors and role models. #NYECandleLighting
We may lose these precious resources for longer if they become ill and need to be treated and isolated for longer. We may lose them forever if they succumb to #COVID19. #NYECandleLighting
Every time a health care worker becomes infected with COVID, we lose at least 10 days of labour, so desperately needed during this time.#NYECandleLighting

But we must remember that as the rate of transmission rises so too do the infections amongst health care workers rise. To date, we have recorded a cumulative 43 124 health care workers who became infected with #COVID19. #NYECandleLighting
Our health care workers continue to bravely fight this war even though they have been pushed beyond their call of duty. #NYECandleLighting
28 469 South Africans are known to have succumbed to COVID-19 this year- amongst those were 436 public health care workers who paid the ultimate price in the frontline. #NYECandleLighting

A New Year's Eve candle lighting ceremony will be held to commemorate and remember the lives lost through #COVID19 this year.

The impact of #COVID19 vaccines on the pandemic will depend on several factors. Learn more about these factors in this video: #VaccineStrategy
Before #COVID19 vaccines can be delivered, many steps must be followed to ensure effectiveness and safety. Learn more about the process in this video: #VaccineStrategy

When a lot of people in a community are vaccinated, the pathogen has a hard time circulating because most of the people it encounters are immune. Learn more about herd immunity in this video: #VaccineStrategy

In general, vaccines contain weakened or inactive parts of a particular organism (antigen) that triggers an immune response within the body. Learn more about #COVID19 vaccines in this video: #VaccineStrategy

Siyafisa ukuba nibe namaholidi amahle, sibambisane, sivikelane ukuvukile ukubhebhetheka kwe gciwane le Covid-19. #SARSCOV2MediaBriefing
Singakwazi ukulinqoba leli gciwane masingayiqaphela imgomo ebekiwe. Kubalulekile ukuthi sizame ukuzivikela #SARSCOV2MediaBriefing
Into ebalulekile ukuthi sizoqhubeka sililaphe ngendlela ebesenza ngayo. Kuzomele siqhubeke sifake izifonyo, sigeze izandla singahlali ezindaweni eziyisiminyaminya . #SARSCOV2MediaBriefing
Sibona abantu abasha sekuyibona abagulayo kakhulu, akusafani njengoba leli gciwane lisaqala. #SARSCOV2MediaBriefing
Into esihluphayo ukuthi leligciwane lisheshe labuya. Futhi nangesikhathi esihleli ngaso ngama holidi. #SARSCOV2MediaBriefing
Akusho ukuthi igciwane elisha kodwa sizoqhubeka sililaphe. #SARSCOV2MediaBriefing
Okokuqala esifuna ukukusho , ochwephesha sebe bone ukuthi igciwane le Covid-19 linokuguquka. #SARSCOV2MediaBriefing

Health Minister Dr Zweli Mkhize on Friday announced that a variant of the SARS-COV-2 Virus (COVID-19) – currently termed the ‘501.V2 Variant’ –  has been identified by genomics scientists in South Africa.
The youth is urged to take care and find alternative ways of having safe fun this festive season.

We cannot go through what we went through in the early days of the AIDS pandemic when mothers and grandmothers were burying their children- this is the most heartbreaking phenomenon. The youth is urged to take care and find alternative ways of having safe fun this festive season.
Our message out of this variant; This situation can be contained depending how well we adhere to behavioural changes such as mask wearing, hand washing, social distancing and sanitising.

It cannot be that our youth can only adhere to lifesaving measures by being policed. We call on parents, caregivers and our youth to understand that this is now not just a matter of thinking about others but you yourselves are now equally at risk of dying from COVID-19.
Our youth are not wearing masks and are clearly so intoxicated that they have thrown caution to the wind and do not care to observe the rules under the state of disaster. #SARSCOV2MediaBriefing
Our clinicians have also warned us that things have changed and that young, previously healthy people are now becoming very sick. #SARSCOV2MediaBriefing

Last week I made an announcement that we have entered into our second wave and that it is mostly young people who are testing positive for COVID-19 in recent weeks: this continues to be the case. #SARSCOV2MediaBriefing
Before that happens there is no new action needed and no evidence to change the approach. #SARSCOV2MediaBriefing

There will also be further research to ascertain if the current vaccines be effective on the new variant— we shall continue with the vaccine program as there is no evidence to do otherwise and scientific research will clarify that. #SARSCOV2MediaBriefing

Reports based on surveillance and intensive monitoring continues to guide our response which is driven by  will declare new districts as hotspots as they reach the threshold and continue to monitor how these increases impact on our health service and health care workers
Mkhize: This discovery does not necessitate additional measures. There will be no basis to change purely based on this report.#SARSCOV2MediaBriefing

This research underlines the need for all of us all to loyally adhere to the practice of Non pharmaceutical interventions which work as effectively in any pandemic of this nature including #COVID19 as we have known it and is just as effective to a mutant variant of the same virus
Mkhize: There is no evidence to suggest a need to change in clinical treatment and patient management of #COVID19 in the second wave to date. #SARSCOV2MediaBriefing
Mkhize: Nothing will beat the rigid implementation of wearing of masks use of hand sanitizer and washing with soap and distancing. #SARSCOV2MediaBriefing
Mkhize: It is important to reiterate that while this mutation is a cause for concern there is no reason to panic. #SARSCOV2MediaBriefing

Mkhize: We appeal to all the media and medical and scientific community to focus on the facts and avoid entering into speculation or issue unproven statements and generate panic and disinformation. #SARSCOV2MediaBriefing

Mkhize: We have noticed a degree of complacency with mask-wearing and hand sanitizing. The second wave is increasing during this season but we believe it is most likely to increase after this season. It may well have another bump where numbers are showing an increase.

Mkhize: We knew it was coming but none of us expected for it to come as quickly as it did. There was no specific projection. It comes at a time when the behaviour over the festive season is likely to worsen the spread of the virus.
Karim: “We don't know where it originated. What we do know is that we first found it in Nelson Mandela Bay” #SARSCOV2MediaBriefing
Karim: “We are seeing a much higher proportion of the new variant than the rest of the world. “ #SARSCOV2MediaBriefing
Karim: The higher viral load in swabs may translate to higher efficiency of transmission. #SARSCOV2MediaBriefing
Karim: This new 501.V2 variant has become dominant in South Africa. This new variant has 3 mutations. #SARSCOV2MediaBriefing

Karim: “The second wave is showing early signs that it is spreading faster than the first wave. It is not clear if this second wave has more or less deaths. We have not seen any red flags looking at our current death information” #SARSCOV2MediaBriefing
Karim: “The second wave has now hit all provinces with some early signs of it spreading faster than the first wave.” #SARSCOV2MediaBriefing
Karim: “What we are seeing now is that the rate of increase in cases is similar as the first wave but the second wave has now over shot the peak of the first wave.” #SARSCOV2MediaBriefing
The evidence that has been collated, therefore, strongly suggests that that the current second wave we are experiencing is being driven by this new variant. #SARSCOV2MediaBriefing

Clinicians have been providing anecdotal evidence of a shift in the clinical epidemiological picture- in particular noting that they are seeing a larger proportion of younger patients with no co-morbidities presenting with critical illness. #SARSCOV2MediaBriefing

This genomics team, led by the Kwazulu-Natal Research Innovation and Sequencing Platform, or KRISP, has sequenced hundreds of samples from across the country since the beginning of the pandemic in March. #SARSCOV2MediaBriefing

We have convened this public briefing today to announce that a variant of the SARS-COV-2 Virus- currently termed 501.V2 Variant has been identified by our genomics scientists here in South Africa.
#SARSCOV2MediaBriefing

An update on the #Covid19 vaccine with DDG Dr Anban Pillay, Prof Helen Rees from the South African Health Products Regulatory Authority and Prof Jeffrey Mphahlele of the South African Medical Research Council. @MorningLiveSABC
Rees: “South Africa has a tradition of being very open to vaccines. The more information we get out there, the better.” #COVID19VaccineUpdate @MorningLiveSABC
Pillay:”What has happened that through the WHO, the COVAX facility has been established. That has been done to ensure equality for access to vaccines.”  #COVID19VaccineUpdate @MorningLiveSABC

Pillay: “The developing countries have largely been at the back end of receiving vaccines largely because the manufacturers of these vaccines are looking for funding and will turn to countries like the US and UK for financing.” #COVID19VaccineUpdate @MorningLiveSABC
Rees: “safety monitoring is being done under extremely rigorous conditions.” #COVID19VaccineUpdate @MorningLiveSABC

Rees: “SA has been one of the very few African countries who participated in vaccine trials. All of these trials are very closely monitoring by regulatory authorities.” #COVID19VaccineUpdate @MorningLiveSABC

Mphahlele: “We are quite confident that the safety and efficacy of the vaccines reported so far are quite satisfactory. The safety will continue to be monitored even after the rollout.” #COVID19VaccineUpdate @MorningLiveSABC
Pillay:”A dossier will be ready early January; we can then expect rollout thereafter. They have advised us to plan for a rollout early in the second quarter.”#COVID19VaccineUpdate @MorningLiveSABC

Pillay: “The COVID vaccines are currently in a regulatory assessment phase across the world. We have participated in the Covax agreement so we will hear from Covax which vaccine has been allocated to SA.”#COVID19VaccineUpdate @MorningLiveSABC

Tune into @MorningLiveSABC shortly, to watch a discussion on #COVID19 vaccines in the country. Panelists are Dr Anban Pillay from @HealthZA , Prof Helen Rees from Health Products Regulatory Authority and Prof Jeffrey Mphahlele of the South African Medical Research Council.

#NHI facilities will have to be of the same standard, as they will have to follow the rules of the Office of Health standards Compliance to be part of the NHI. #UHCDay2020
The #NHI is based on the principle of social solidarity where we will look after each other in times of medical need. #UHCDay2020

The #NHI was established to provide support for the nation so that every citizen can have the financial and medical support they need to live a healthy, happy life.
#UHCDay2020

The comprehensive healthcare services the NHI will provide are bound by the philosophy of holistic approach to healthcare spanning from preventative strategies all the way to convalescent and palliative care. #UHCDay2020

The objective of the NHI is to achieve universal access to quality healthcare services in South Africa, in accordance with the constitution. It is based on the principle of social solidarity where we will look after each other in times of medical need. #UHCDay2020

The NHI was established to provide support for the nation so that every citizen can have the financial and medical support they need to live a healthy, happy life.
#UHCDay2020

The NHI is the South African way of providing equitable access to high quality care for everyone.
#UHCDay2020

#UHCDay2020
The NHI is SA’s gateway to univeral health coverage. What healthcare service will you be entitled to under this system?

I therefore wish to take this opportunity to join the global community in reaffirming the commitments that were made last year at the United Nations High Level Meeting on Universal Health Coverage in New York. #UHCDay2020

The manifestations of which were high awareness of the disease, community mobilization and buy in, active citizenship and a government response based on evidence through high consultation with all key stakeholders. #UHCDay2020
Ultimately it was through the multi-sectoral working relationship that successful expression of social compacting was achieved. #UHCDay2020
We paid special attention to strengthening the primary health care system through our community testing and screening campaigns and mobile testing units, amongst other strategies. #UHCDay2020
For the first time in our history, we approached a public health crisis as one unit, through pooling of resources. #UHCDay2020
As South Africa, we have endeavoured not to waste the proverbial good crisis as we sought to use the #COVID19 pandemic to inculcate elements of Universal Health Coverage. #UHCDay2020

the need to heal the divisions of the past and to establish a society based on democratic values, social justice and fundamental human rights; and the need to improve the quality of life of all citizens and to free the potential of each person. #UHCDay2020
The preamble of the NHI Bill recognizes the socio-economic injustices, imbalances and inequities of the past; #UHCDay2020

We need to create more jobs, to deal with the high level of unemployment. It has to be taken as an issue that requires huge attention. #JPMorganConference
For any form of recovery we need a thriving infrastructure. #JPMorganConference
It is important in the next phase of reconstruction and economic recovery. We need to manage rising debts and stabilise SOE’s. #JPMorganConference

The core issue we have to face as a country (like many other countries) is our GDP has shrunk significantly. We need close cooperation between government and the private sector. Areas of policy uncertainty need to be dealt with sensitively. #JPMorganConference
All of this has shown us we need to move towards #UHC. Better resources, infrastructure etc. for all will assist us with any future health emergencies #JPMorganConference

As we go into the festive season there is huge movement across provinces, large gatherings, festivals etc. We need to find a way to manage this, so it does not become super spreading events. #JPMorganConference
We’ve invested in infrastructure; beds, ventilators, oxygen etc. We believe this will benefit us as we move into the future with our health systems. #JPMorganConference
We need to wear our masks, social distance, sanitise and wash hands. #JPMorganConference

As we go into the festive season we need to encourage people to change the way that they will celebrate this festive season. It is difficult, as we are not used to it. #CelebrateSafe #JPMorganConference
Podcast: South Africans need to change their behaviour during the festive season to prevent the spread of #COVID19. #CelebrateSafe

Prof Morgan Chetty hands over the Award, In recognition of outstanding services in the healthcare during #COVID19 on behalf of #KZNDHC
Humanity as a whole appreciates all the work you have done as our unsung heroes on the frontline of this invisible enemy. You have not flinched. #KZNDHC24
We say thank you for your dedication. You have continued throughout this pandemic. We see you , your hard work - it has not been left unnoticed. South Africa is grateful to you. #KZNDHC24
This evening I want to salute all health workers. #KZNDHC24
The difference that has made those survive, is the resilience of health systems and especially the health workers throughout the globe. #KZNDHC
Throughout all of this #COVID19 has destroyed large economies, disrupted nations, with unemployment and loss of food security #KZNDHC
We have seen a number of people losing there lives. Over one million people have lost their lives to #COVID19. #KZNDHC24
We are also looking at local manufacturing. We need to build our own pharmaceutical research manufacturing. #COVID19 exposed our vulnerability in this area. #KZNDHC24
We have learned a lot about solidarity and cooperation so we remain a part of the global initiative to save lives. #KZNDHC24
We need patients who are engaged and informed. Patient activism is going to be important in the future.#KZNDHC24
There is no space for corruption in the #NHI and in public healthcare system. #KZNDHC24

#COVID19 has given us a springboard from which we can move into the future. #KZNDHC24
We have moved to strengthening our ICT system that is centralised. We want to be able to monitor patients by having access to all records. #KZNDHC24
It has become important to discuss digital transformation in health. The continuity of care is ensured through reliable electronic patient records. #KZNDHC24
We have also used the crisis well to make inroads towards the NHI. The gains we have had in fostwring public-private cooperation is something we must strengthen and build upon. #KZNDHC24
We have seen how in a short space  of time the need to be flexible and embrace innovation as we embrace this pandemic. #KZNDHC24

We need an approach that is going to help us in the outbreak in the Eastern Cape and the Western Cape. We need to know that the new normal includes wearing masks, sanitising and social distancing. #ECVisit27November
We need to intensify communication, to make people understand that if they do not adhere to the measures, the numbers will rise. #ECVisit27November
Our approach on initiation in the Eastern Cape is that there has to be a risk adjusted strategy. We will take a report from traditional leadership to the NCC next week. #ECVisit27November
The public healthcare facilities have all the necessary expertise, and people should use our healthcare services. #ECVisit27November
We have called on the NHLS to assist in speeding up the waiting time for test results so patients can be directed to the treatment needed. #ECVisit27November
We have investigated this problem and realised the issue is a shortage of staff - porters, cleaners, & general staff. We have intervened to make more staff available. #ECVisit27November
The observation wards is what has caused a problem. This is where people stay while they wait for their Covid-19 results. #ECVisit27November
PE provincial hospital has 70% bed capacity. Dora Ngiza and Livingstone has available beds. #ECVisit27November
There’s a sense that hospital beds are full. The reality is that hospital beds are not full.#ECVisit27November

The issue that caused a huge outcry in the first surge was PPE. That issue has been addressed. The tool used by management to track availability of PPE has now been handed over to union representatives who can now track PPE availability. #ECVisit27November
The pressure is being felt on the staff during Covid-19. The faigue, the psycho-social strain on our staff is huge. #ECVisit27November

The media have highlighted the issue of hospital beds. We have looked at this during this visit. We had a meeting with CEO’s, clinicians and nurses of hospitals in NMB. There are challenges here which arisw from the historical underfunding of health services in the province.
In the hospitals, we save lives of those infected. In the community, we defeat Covid-19. This is where the real fight is. #ECVisit27November

In the Eastern Cape, we looked at three areas: case management and  how hospitals are coping with the surge, customary initiation & the issue of behavioural change and the community involvement in the fight against the infection. #ECVisit27November
The Western Cape officials are working on a strategy for the garden route. #ECVisit27November

We are concerned because we are entering the festive season. People come together during the festive season and have parties & are usually in close proximity. They share glasses and cigarettes. #ECVisit27November
Numbers in the Western Cape are now highter than KwaZulu-Natal. #ECVisit27November
We have come to support the province because of the rising pressure here. #ECVisit27November

We have seen the number of people admitted in hospital has increased, the numbers of people recorded to have lost their lives has also increased and the percentage of people positive has also increased. #ECVisit26November

Nelson Mandela Bay has continued to fester and in effect our concern is that something has to be done. We have seen the numbers of positive cases increasing in Nelson Mandela Bay and Eastern Cape. #ECVisit26November
Indeed, it is a concern that we are seeing in a few other areas. The whole country has got bubbles of small cluster outbreaks which we are seeing but they are transient. #ECVisit26November
We are here because there is clearly a resurgence in the Nelson Mandela Bay. #ECVisit26November
This is a working visit and so I just want to give you a sense of what we are going to focus on. #ECVisit26November

He will provide whatever information and or clarity that may be required from him as the former ANC TG by the commission.
Dr Mkhize thus acknowledges that the Commission into State Capture has the powers to fully investigate these matters. He remains fully committed and in support of the work of the commission.

Dr Mkhize still stands by those previous statements and it therefore serves no further purpose in our view for him to be mudslinging with Mr Montana in the media instead of subjecting these allegations to a formal and independent process.

In fact, in February 2018, Dr Mkhize also provided a statement to the Public Enterprise Parliamentary Portfolio Committee chaired by Ms Zukiswa Rantho at the time, with a statement giving a detailed account and response to these unfounded and false allegations by Mr Montana.

Dr Mkhize and the ANC have previously issued statements on this matter refuting the allegations that it had appointed individuals to receive and channel monies on behalf of the ANC, flowing from the PRASA Swifambo tender.

This is the same spirit that we must carry in fighting all other social and health ills facing our society, including gender based violence. 

Dr Zwelini Mkhize
Minister of Health
End...
We have been reminded to care more, love more, emphathise with our families, friends, colleagues and even those we hear about in the media.

We must also take heed of the major lessons from the COVID-19 that is despite the anxiety, the psychological trauma, the physical suffering and grief from lives we lost, COVID-19 has reawakened our deep values of Ubuntu in us all.

As we continue to monitor the development of a vaccine, the only weapon we possess as a country is our social behaviour and constant adherence to health protocols. All of us must take this responsibility and always encourage those around us.
We must mention that the rate of new infections and deaths will inform the recommendations that the Health Department makes to the National Coronavirus Council.
We are now encouraging all provinces to pay attention to these increasing numbers and quickly mount a response, including contact tracing and quarantine.
We await further reports from the WC Health response teams who are now required to target the sub-districts with a high increase of new cases over the last two weeks.
We have noted that the single biggest cluster outbreak has been identified to be in the Southern Sub-district in the Cape Metro, and this has been associated with a super-spreader event in a BAR.

The Western Cape Provincial Health Department has identified specific clusters that are responsible for the increase in cases, and has advised that each of these clusters has been investigated and a detailed outbreak response is being mounted.
The Province recorded a 42% increase in new infections. According to our resurgence plan, we define this significant spike in new cases in the Western Cape as a resurgence.
We are also seeing concerning increases in some of the provinces. To illustrate this, in the last 7 days, there was a marked increase in the number of new cases in the Western Cape.

I wish to bring to the attention of all South Africans that our epidemiological reports are showing that in the country, over the last 7 days there has been an increase of 9.1% in new cases. Similarly, over the last 14 days, there has been an increase of 10.7%.
You will recall that a few months ago when we witnessed these trends, it wasn’t long before we started experiencing a burden in our health system.
As government, we have a responsibility to alert you when we see concerning trends. It would be irresponsible of us to ignore “small flames” that we see redeveloping in some parts of the country.

This morning, after reading and analyzing our country’s epidemiological reports, as the Minister of Health, I cannot help but be concerned. Fellow South Africans, when we emphasize that the risk of a resurgence remains high, we do not do so to instill fear in you.

He uses such an opportunity to reflect on the battle and also to think ahead for when he rejoins the army. Like a soldier, I find myself in that position as we continue to fight this battle against COVID-19 as a country.

I’m also very pleased that my wife has been discharged from hospital today and will now be joining me for quarantine at home.

In a war, when an injured soldier lies down to recover, injuries do not remove his mindset from the set goal to win the battle.
I want to assure you that we are improving each day. I remain in quarantine at home, I am resting and recuperating with only a cough remaining from my previous symptoms.

Message From Dr Zweli Mkhize 

21 October 2020

I wish to take this opportunity to appreciate all the well wishes that my wife and I have received from you, my fellow South Africans, colleagues and friends from all over the world.

I will use this quarantine period to rest and recharge because our task to improve the health services of our country and the lives our people even post COVID-19 remains of paramount importance. 

Dr Zwelini Mkhize
Minister of Health
End...

Let us not dare regress. Whatever we do and wherever we go, we have to keep in mind that there remains a risk of a second wave. This virus only spreads through movement and contact of people. Therefore we must all play our part. We must protect ourselves and those we love.

I want to beg that we do not neglect wearing our masks, social distancing and washing / sanitizing our hands.

As country, we’ve made significant strides in our fight against this pandemic.

I am now in quarantine at home and both my wife and I remain optimistic that we will fully recover from this virus.

I wish to take this opportunity to urge all South Africans to continue adhering to health protocols.

Our close contacts in the past week have been a few of our family members and some of my Health Ministry team. We have informed them and advised them to immediately isolate in their homes and be tested.

I was feeling abnormally exhausted and as the day progressed, I started losing appetite. My wife had a cough, was dizzy and extremely exhausted. Given her symptoms, the doctors advised that she must be admitted for observation and rehydration.

DR ZWELI MKHIZE TESTS POSITIVE FOR COVID-19

18/10/20

I wish to inform the public that this afternoon my wife, Dr May Mkhize and I have tested positive for COVID-19. 

We decided to go test yesterday when I started showing mild symptoms.

This theme also suggests that, unless we work together for a common good, our efforts will forever be in vain.
It is against this backdrop that South Africa will commemorate World AIDS Day under the theme, “We’re in this together, Cheka Impilo!” #WorldAIDSDay2020

The global theme as set by UNAIDS for this year is ‘Global Solidarity, Shared Responsibility.’ It calls for greater solidarity and collective responsibility among nations to take measures that end HIV and AIDS as public health threats. #RotaryFamilyHealthDay

Along the way, we lost some 247 of our frontline workers in the war against COVID-19: I wish to convey my sincerest condolences to the families, friends, colleagues and communities who lost these precious members of our society. #RotaryFamilyHealthDay
You have persevered, fought and prevailed- many times going beyond your call of duty to ensure that we emerge victorious and for that I thank you. #RotaryFamilyHealthDay
To all health care workers, let me take this opportunity to express appreciation for your efforts during one of the toughest public health care eras in history. #RotaryFamilyHealthDay

We remind caregivers that it is very important to always have the child’s road to health booklet (also called the clinic card) when you go to the facility, so we can track the progress of your child and quickly pick up any failure to thrive. #RotaryFamilyHealthDay

I implore our nurses and doctors to warmly welcome all children who may have missed their immunizations during the lockdown period so that no-one is deterred from visiting the facilities to catch up their immunizations. #RotaryFamilyHealthDay
I call all on mothers, fathers, grandmothers, grandfathers and care takers not to fear our facilities and ensure that your children are taken for immunisation. #RotaryFamilyHealthDay

Both male and female condoms, MAX and MAXIMA, and a compatible lubricant, are distributed for free in public health facilities and non state facilities so there is no excuse for not using a condom. #RotaryFamilyHealthDay

If you take your treatment well without defaulting, you will remain virally suppressed with a strong immune system and this plays a crucial role in protecting you from contracting other diseases, including COVID-19. #RotaryFamilyHealthDay
Knowing one’s HIV status will assist in management of the disease if one is HIV positive. You can get treatment and live a long and healthy life. #RotaryFamilyHealthDay
As we approach World AIDS day, we need to remind ourselves that HIV/ AIDS is still a pandemic in this country, more threatening than COVID-19. #RotaryFamilyHealthDay

This is why we came up with the campaign called Cheka Impilo(Know Your health Status). This campaign is designed to remind you that the power of healing in in your hands and that we are here to reach out, guide and assist you in every way so you can reach your full life potential

We therefore urge that if you are started on treatment for any chronic condition during this programme, that you continue to use the services that government has made available for you so you do not become sick or disabled. #RotaryFamilyHealthDay

If you do test positive for HIV, or screen positive for TB, STIs, or non-communicable diseases, you will be able to treat these illnesses early and enjoy good quality of life despite the diagnosis. #RotaryFamilyHealthDay

Today I would like to call on all individuals, families and communities to take this opportunity and go to their nearest health care facility to screen and test for HIV, TB, high blood, sugar and others. #RotaryFamilyHealthDay

In addition, the Rotarians are well known for their fight against Polio and for the promotion of immunisation for children.
These services are available in public health facilities for free on a daily basis. #RotaryFamilyHealthDay
The main objective of our partnership with Rotarians  is to provide an enabling environment for health seeking behaviour. #RotaryFamilyHealthDay
those who are young, healthy and working will contribute towards the fund for the benefit of those who are too elderly, sick or disabled to be able to work. #NHI #RotaryFamilyHealthDay
All South Africans will share the responsibility of financing the system and we will cross-subsidise  one another in an exercise of social solidarity #NHI #RotaryFamilyHealthDay

There will be no distinction between a private or a public facility and every South African will expect to receive the same standard of care regardless of their social standing. #NHI #RotaryFamilyHealthDay

The NHI is a health care financing system that is designed to pool funds such that there will be one national purchaser of health goods and services for all South Africans. #NHI #RotaryFamilyHealthDay
We took every opportunity to adopt the machinations contemplated in the Bill to manage COVID-19 and stay on the path towards Universal Health Coverage. #NHI #RotaryFamilyHealthDay
Prior to the COVID-19 pandemic, we had introduced the NHI Bill to Parliament in July and the public hearings had been concluded towards the end of 2019. #RotaryFamilyHealthDay
The principle behind Universal health Coverage is that no one should be denied access to quality health care because of socio-economic circumstances. #NHI #RotaryFamilyHealthDay
It is imperative that we embark on an aggressive “catch-up” drive to ensure that we capitalize on the infrastructure gains made during the COVID-19 pandemic. #RotaryFamilyHealthDay

We are aware that, due to the combination of lockdown regulations and the fear of contracting COVID-19 in facilities, our people shied away from seeking what may have been deemed to be non urgent or non essential health services. #RotaryFamilyHealthDay
Prior to COVID-19, we were already facing a triple burden of HIV, TB and non-communicable diseases.#RotaryFamilyHealthDay
We welcome the opportunity to attracting our communities back to our facilities to test for and manage various conditions such as HIV, TB, hypertension, diabetes and cancer. #RotaryFamilyHealthDay
We welcome this opportunity to kickstart a campaign of rebuilding rapport with our community members. #RotaryFamilyHealthDay

The timeliness of this year’s programme could not be more critical as we emerge out of the COVID-19 surge and refocus our energy towards the attainment of Universal Health Coverage. #RotaryFamilyHealthDay

The strength of NHI is also about prevention, in knowing how to deal with the environment & prevent diseases. #PhelophepaTrain
We stand ready to support you and enable you to continue and expand your reach as this can only buttress our goals as outlines in the various intervention strategies. #PhelophepaTrain
and that this indeed does form the basis of the National Health Insurance we envisage as our tool for attaining Universal Health Coverage. #NHI #PhelophepaTrain

I want to reassure you all here at the Phelaphepha Train that government shares your commitment and passion for bringing health care closer to the people through a primary health care model #PhelophepaTrain

It is very possible to be cured of breast cancer and to save one’s breast, and life, if the cancer is identified early. It is also important to examine your armpits (or axillae) for unexplained lumps which could also be a sign of breast cancer. #PhelophepaTrain

It is also extremely important for women to examine their breasts frequently at home and to take opportunities to have their breasts screened by health professionals with a view to test early if a problem is identified. #PhelophepaTrain

We must re-enforce the message to women that is is extremely important that one knows the family history of all cancers in the family as there are some cancers that put one at risk of having breast cancer as well. #PhelophepaTrain

This year we commemorate Breast Cancer Awareness Month under the theme “ Give Hope. Save Lives” We do so understanding that, worldwide there are about 1.38 million new cases and 458 000 deaths from breast cancer each year. #PhelophepaTrain
I was also very excited to learn that there are also dental, eye and psychology services that are carried out from this train. #PhelophepaTrain

This train, for instance, offers all of these screening and testing services including pap smears and a special machine called SureTouch which is like a mammogram that looks for potential masses in the breast. #PhelophepaTrain
We implore all our citizens to test for HIV and to screen for TB, hypertension, diabetes, breast, prostate and cervical cancer. #PhelophepaTrain

I therefore wish to take this opportunity to reassure the public that we remain ready to serve you, our people, with services and tools to protect yourselves from the complications of unmanned chronic conditions. #PhelophepaTrain

I am now told that, since citizens have become more confident to venture out and seek medical attention, that you have noticed a rise in persons presenting with elevated PSA’s or clinical evidence of breast cancer. #PhelophepaTrain
We have been concerned to record drops in facility head counts of people presenting for HIV, TB, Diabetes, Hypertension and Cancer Screenings. #PhelophepaTrain
I salute all the health care workers who make the sacrifices daily on this train & in all the healthcare services countrywide. #PhelophepaTrain

I wish to thank you for the critical work that was done on this train and thank the staff for selflessly traveling across the terrain of our beautiful and varied land for the sole purpose of bringing hope and healing to our people. #PhelophepaTrain

Let me congratulate this institution for the sterling work done in KwaZulu Natal, North West and Gauteng; screening and testing citizens for #COVID19 and taking critical messages of empowerment to the people. #PhelophepaTrain

I am therefore extremely pleased to be here and celebrate the work of the Phelophepa Health Care Train: an instrument of hope and a shining example of effective primary health care delivery. #PhelophepaTrain

We dealt with this issue truly as a SA health system. It now only remains for us to learn from this critical lesson- that it is only by pooling resources and through multi-sectoral collaboration that we can combat any attack on our national state of health.#PhelophepaTrain

We, together with the private sectors, immediately moved to pool resources and consolidate ourselves into one army, one health system with one coherent response. This is the very basis of the #NHI. #PhelophepaTrain

Indeed, it crystallized the importance of the tenets of the #NHI and the fact that we have actually delayed implementing a system that is absolutely crucial to enable us to respond quickly and effectively to an onslaught such as the Coronavirus.#PhelophepaTrain
The pandemic brought home the stark realities of the shortcomings of our current system.#PhelophepaTrain
Now we need to turn our attention back towards other programmes, & the most important is the implementation of the National Health Insurance.#NHI #PhelophepaTrain

As a nation we have done extremely well to fight against the #COVID19 surge and, if we continue to stay vigilant and adhere to non-pharmaceutical interventions we can, through our actions, mitigate a potentially devastating second wave.#PhelophepaTrain
