This offensive sensationalism can only be a side show to taint my name and does not in any way add value to the work that the law enforcements are doing. 

Dr Zweli Mkhize
ANC NEC Member 

End...
I for one, take serious exception to insinuations, irresponsible and false comments made by some that I personally received monies from Mr Sodi.

Matters relating to Mr Sodi and his companies are now before the courts. This legal process should therefore be allowed to run its course without being muddied by mischief and misinformation that drags individuals names, where there is no evidence.

Therefore there is no parliamentary requirement for me to declare all the donations that were received by the ANC during my tenure as TG. 

It is also worth mentioning that where unlawfulness and wrong-doing has been found, the law enforcement agencies must investigate this.

At the time the ANC received these donations, I was the Treasurer General, with the specific role of raising funds for my Organisation. I was not a Member of Parliament and in any event did not benefit directly from these donations from Mr Sodi.

I have also noted the senseless statement by the DA that it will report me to parliament because of these donations made to the ANC. In the process of doing so, it would assist the DA to make an attempt to properly understand the Rules of Parliament.

I further confirm that outside of having noted Mr Sodi as a donor to the ANC during my tenure as TG, I have no personal, professional or business relationship with him. I have never been party to any of his business dealings nor have I interacted with him at a personal level.
Furthermore, I wish to emphasise that all the donations we received made voluntary, they were never transactional or linked to securing work from government.

I once again state categorically that the above payments were deposited directly into ANC’s official bank accounts, I therefore can only assume that the name Zweli Mkhize was used by the donor as a reference, given my capacity at the time as the Treasurer General.

(This information has been verified with the ANC Finance Office today):

R  3   million   - 28 Feb 2014
R 3.5 million   - 03 April 2014
R 1.5  million   - 29 Sept 2015
R 150 000       - 08 January 2016

That is how we would contact people or companies and invite them to our events. 

I further wish to confirm that during my tenure as the ANC TG, Mr Sodi either directly or through his entities made the following donations to the ANC

In fact, when I took over as the TG, Mr Sodi’s contacts were available in the ANC Donors database as one of the people who had previously donated to the ANC. This database was compiled and kept by the finance office through various public fundraising events that the ANC held.
I can confirm that during my tenure as the ANC Treasurer General, Mr Sodi, just like many other business persons, companies and organizations made donations to the African National Congress.
I wish to categorically state I have never received any funds from Mr Sodi, either personally or through a third party intended for my personal benefit.

STATEMENT BY DR ZWELINI MKHIZE ON EDWIN SODI’S DONATIONS TO THE ANC

2 October 2020

I have received various media queries regarding the payment of R6,5million made by Mr Edwin Sodi and wherein my name, Zweli Mkhize, has been put as a reference.

His Excellency President Cyril Ramaphosa requires that we create a legacy for the health system from the #COVID19 pandemic; the legacy that will find expression in the National Health Insurance. #NHI #WorldEnvironmentalHealthDay
We can never allow the virus to run rampant, causing massive loss of life. #WorldEnvironmentalHealthDay
We must proceed with the same level of vigilance and care, understanding that the risk of being forced back into hard lockdown remains very real. #WorldEnvironmentalHealthDay

As the country moves to alert level  risk of complacency amongst our community members can become our biggest drawback and result in a second wave that is more devastating than the first. #WorldEnvironmentalHealthDay

We are currently in an extremely fortunate position: the #COVID19 disease burden in our country is decreasing, our health system is breathing, and many people have recovered. #WorldEnvironmentalHealthDay
This pandemic has compelled us to mount a multi-sectoral, well integrated response that favours multilateralism over nationalism. #WorldEnvironmentalHealthDay

#COVID19 has once again reaffirmed the reality that diseases know no borders and no country is immune to the socio-economic devastation that follows the arrival and spread of a new and unfamiliar pathogen. #WorldEnvironmentalHealthDay
The role of the officials at the Ports of Entry has been central to the #COVID19 response, mainly because South Africa is the transit hub for many African countries. #WorldEnvironmentalHealthDay

At this point, I would like to take this opportunity to recognize and thank all the Environmental Health Professionals, especially the frontline workers, who have been on the ground from day one. #WorldEnvironmentalHealthDay

Hand hygiene, social distancing, the safe handling and sale of foodstuffs, environmental cleanliness, and the management of waste are also amongst environmental interventions we are concerned with. #WorldEnvironmentalHealthDay
From a health perspective, the environment must be enabling for communities to adopt safe practices to prevent further spread of the virus. #WorldEnvironmentalHealthDay
This was most evident in the midst of the #COVID19 pandemic response, where the work of Environmental Health Practitioners became even more critical. #WorldEnvironmentalHealthDay

The science of environmental health is based on the premise that prevention is better than cure, as this profession is concerned with the key environmental factors that are at the heart of public health dynamics. #WorldEnvironmentalHealthDay

It is critical that as we pause to shine a spotlight on environmental health that we use the opportunity to reassess our health needs and devise mechanisms for action driven interventions. #WorldEnvironmentalHealthDay
It is my conviction that the declaration of this day came after a realisation that the fight for health for all will be won or lost in the public health space. #WorldEnvironmentalHealthDay
I am aware that the commemoration of this day is a hallmark of the environmental health fraternity calendar in the country #WorldEnvironmentalHealthDay

We have built unity and 
co-operation & we remain committed to quality patient safety and we will continue to ensure our healthcare workers remain safe as well. #worldpatientsafetyday2020

Compassionate care starts with compassionate management. This day is a tribute to all our frontline workers, a recognition of your dedication and a statement of our intention to continually improve the protection available to you. #worldpatientsafetyday2020

It focuses on educating and training health workers to manage COVID-19 cases and implement occupational health and safety protocols. And it recognises the importance of communication among health workers. #worldpatientsafetyday2020
It also seeks to promote mental health of health workers through psychological support and to provide necessary social support. #worldpatientsafetyday2020
The strategy aims to protect the physical health of health workers through prevention and mitigation of #COVID19 infections by providing a safe physical environment. #worldpatientsafetyday2020

#worldpatientsafetyday2020 is a fitting opportunity to launch a national Strategy to protect the health and safety of health workers which seeks to protect both the physical and mental health of frontline health workers and acknowledges their need for social support.
Our health workers are infinitely precious and, as government, we asserted that their protection is non-negotiable. #worldpatientsafetyday2020

I also welcome this commemoration as a moment to express our profound gratitude to our health workers for the risks that they have taken and continue to take as we navigate our way through the #COVID19 pandemic. #worldpatientsafetyday2020

World Patient Safety Day in 2020 directs our attention to the importance of keeping health workers safe. It provides an opportunity to reflect on our management of health worker safety and to strengthen our collective ability to protect our workers. #worldpatientsafetyday2020
Safe, quality care should not be the preserve of the elite, nor should it be an aspiration for some distant future: it should be the DNA of all health systems. #worldpatientsafetyday2020 #NHI

Our National Health Insurance (NHI) seeks to provide all South Africans access to quality essential health services – that is, services that are supported by effective systems, are people-centred and are capable of delivering safe care.#worldpatientsafetyday2020 #NHI
South Africa, along with other countries, is moving towards Universal Health Coverage and striving to achieve the Sustainable Development Goals by 2030. #worldpatientsafetyday2020 #NHI

Building knowledge is one of the objectives of World Patient Safety Day. Another important objective is to engage the public more actively in our efforts to enhance patient safety and reduce patient harm. #worldpatientsafetyday2020
Clearly, we need a sharper understanding of the factors contributing to patient harm and better insight into approaches that would enhance patient safety. #worldpatientsafetyday2020
Your wellbeing, as health workers, and the safety of patients across the country are inseparable and must be addressed comprehensively. #worldpatientsafetyday2020

The theme was chosen because the COVID-19 pandemic has revealed the significant challenges and risks that health workers around the world confront in the line of professional duty.#worldpatientsafetyday2020

Today we are celebrating the second World Patient Safety Day under the theme: Health worker safety: a priority for patient safety with a call to speak up for health worker safety. #worldpatientsafetyday2020

I with to express my humble gratitude to the nursing community for making my job easier as Minister of Health. I want assure you that I share your aspirations of a better world through the work that we do to secure a healthy population for quality of life and prosperity for all.
I am pleased to say that much work has been done to promulgate and subsequently proclaim various sections of the Nursing Act. #SPNPConference

The Department of Health will very soon publish the STRATEGIC DIRECTION FOR NURSING EDUCATION AND PRACTICE which outlines a roadmap for strengthening nursing and midwifery in South Africa for the next five years.#SPNPConference

I must congratulate the provinces for collectively employing 13 135 nurses across the categories during this time. Now that they have proven that it is possible to achieve such numbers in such a short space of time. #SPNPConference
Indeed, these key focus points align perfectly with the objectives of the Presidential Health Compact, The Quality Improvement Plan and, ultimately, the National Health Insurance.#SPNPConference

• Recruiting more nurses into leadership positions;
 
• Conducting research that helps determine where nurses can have the greatest impact and
 
• Sharing of best nursing practices
 #SPNPConference

To recap, the five key areas focus for the #NursingNow global campaign are:  
• Ensuring that nurses and midwives have a more prominent voice in health policy-making
 
• Encouraging greater investment in the nursing workforce;
 
(Continued...)

In December last year I had the privilege of launching the  #NursingNow campaign- a three year campaign initiated by the global nursing community with the sole objective of improving health care delivery to our people.
 #SPNPConference

By shining a spotlight on the state of Nursing and Midwifery, the WHO catalysed a series of events to galvanize worldwide action for focused and purposeful health systems strengthening through fortifying human resources for health. #SPNPConference
May I convey my heartfelt condolences for the loss of your co-workers, friends, family and loved ones.#SPNPConference

We thank you for braving the threat of being infected yourself, and even of death. To date, over 31,000 health care workers, many of them nurses and midwives, have contracted Coronavirus and we have tragically lost 240 colleagues. #SPNPConference
These Herculean achievements have been possible because of the passion, dedication and sheer diligence of our nurses and midwives. #SPNPConference

Mothers affected by COVID-19 have given birth to healthy babies. They are breastfeeding and physically bonding with their children, laying foundations for wholesome upbringing and solid building blocks for a healthy and prosperous society. #SPNPConference

Today, we cautiously but optimistically breathe a sigh of relief as we continue to see our detected cases, hospital admissions, deaths and even excess deaths declining. Our recovery rate is now almost at 90% and our mortality rate has remained stable at around 2% #SPNPConference

We convey our deepest condolences to the family and friends 

Hamba Kahle Uncle George Bizos
South Africa salutes you

May his soul Rest In Peace

He served our country with distinction, honour and integrity. 
He remained a moral icon, a revered legal guru and a role model until his last day in this world.

We join the whole of South Africa to mourn the passing of the stalwart of our struggle.

He shall forever be respected for his contribution to the South African jurisprudence and the transformation of the judicial and legal system and the birth of a new constitutional order in our country.

He fearlessly defended the leaders of our struggle such as President Albert Luthuli, Nelson Mandela, Oliver Tambo, Walter Sisulu and many more. Using his legal acumen as Defence counsel he came to burst the myth that the apartheid legal system was invincible.
A respected human rights activist and brilliant legal brain, Bizos chose a niche from which to attack the apartheid institution by challenging every unjust law and every act of oppression.
These compatriots dedicated their lives to serving our nation, fighting injustice and patiently chipped away at the apartheid rock until it cracked into irreparable splinters.

South Africa grieves at the news of the peaceful departure of an elder statesman

The passing of Advocate Bizos closes a chapter of the generation of our heroes who were the midwives of the South African democracy we enjoy today

South Africans need to continue with containment measures in order to prevent a second wave.@MorningLiveSABC

There are a number of issues still to be looked at, such as immunity, studies on the climate and COVID19 surviving in saliva and demographics. There is research being done on all of this, but it’s still early to confirm what is being said. @MorningLiveSABC

Excess deaths are not all COVID deaths. When our numbers were very high, the number of excess deaths were also high, we are tracking these excess deaths. Unnatural deaths during lockdown, reduced drastically. We are seeing those increase now again. @MorningLiveSABC
We refined the testing strategy during the peak to testing of those with symptoms, co-morbidities, contacts, those in hospital etc. Those numbers of people have decreased. @MorningLiveSABC
@MorningLiveSABC We are not ready to open everything immediately. We are moving in that direction, the economy does need to be opened, however we will ease into the decrease in restrictions.

@MorningLiveSABC the numbers are reducing. We are not over the worst yet, we are worrying about the resurgence. Globally we are now at number 7, this tells us 2 things - 1 the numbers are declining in SA, 2 Globally the numbers are still increasing.

The surge that we saw happened when we moved from level 4 to level 3. We would’ve expected the same to happen when we moved to level 2. It has not happened ’ve not discounted this as other countries have shown resurgence after showing a plateau. @SAfmRadio #SAfmSunrise
It’s important to say we are going through the research on herd immunity, it might be a bit early to say. There are a number of factors that will also be confirmed with time. @SAfmRadio #SAfmSunrise
We mustn’t try to predict that there will be no second wave, instead we should behave in a way to prevent a second wave from occurring. @SAfmRadio
The risk of resurgence still exists. South Africans need to be aware that whilst we’re decreasing restrictions, we still need to wear masks, sanitize, etc. @SAfmRadio
@SAfmRadio we’ve seen that hospital admissions have been reduced, the number of people on ventilators have been reduced.

We’ve gone through a crisis and this will be good for us going into the future. It has assisted us in reorganizing at a district level, which will assist with the implementation of NHI. #POWERBreakfast
We do appreciate the work of all our healthcare workers. We are very grateful. #POWERBreakfast
Testing is focused on those that come into hospital or are showing symptoms and healthcare workers etc. #POWERBreakfast
For about 3 weeks now we’ve been on a steady decline. We’ve seen other countries where they’ve had almost no cases and then there has been a second wave #POWERBreakfast

@Powerfm987 The numbers of recoveries have increased to about 88% and this is encouraging. South Africa was also number 5 in the world during the peak, we have now dropped to number 7. #POWERBreakfast

On behalf of the ANC, the comrades and fellow ex-combatants we wish to convey our deepest condolences to his family, Rosa and all the children, Anand and other siblings , Comrades  Sandy, comrade Charlotte, the community. We thank you for giving him to serve our nation.
We have lost a humble  servant of our people, a courageous soldier  who fought gallantly and never betrayed our cause but remained steadfast and loyal till his last breath.
He was a disciplined soldier and a man of principle who respected all those who led him and those  whom he led with equal measure.
He was articulate and always managed to simplify difficult concepts and to win the confidence of those around him

That is what Lt Gen Ramlakan dedicated his life to. If we achieve those dreams his struggles will not have been in vain.
Comrade Vejay was produced as a well rounded cadre of our movement. He was a doctor who respected the ordinary people in our community.

On his passing let us remind all those in positions of power that the struggle cannot be over until we entrench good governance, eliminate corruption, achieve true non-racialism, non-sexism, equality and justice prevails.
We salute all those dedicated health workers who have remained committed to the service of our nation. As minister and part of government we undertake to do everything to protect our health workers.
While we embrace the optimism of receding surge, we mourn the lives of those we lost to an invisible enemy, which has needed a combination of skills of health workers as soldiers in the forefront.
We bid him farewell under circumstances constrained by the restrictions imposed to contain the COVID 19 pandemic.
He leaves us at a time when our country is facing several crises that require honest and principled leadership. Leadership that will confront challenges with courage without seeking popularity.
Leaders need to be all reminded that the ANC was created as a movement for all our people not as a passport to high positions or self enrichment but as an instrument for liberation from oppression.

He was in the struggle for the long haul but it was service to the people. He was not driven by greed, and self interest and never got consumed in factional tendencies that have revealed our movement to be barely recognizable.
Nothing gave him as much joy and feeling humbled as the Surgeon General, to be the physician in charge to look after our icon, the father of our nation President Nelson Mandela.
Vejay’s passion as a doctor was never missed. He was overawed as he served with leaders of our movement that he had been singing about and knew them as part of his slogans but now was in their midst.

Comrade Vejay believed the Universal Health Coverage will be achieved in our lifetime. We owe it to his memory to ensure that those of us who survive should never rest until the National Health insurance is achieved; otherwise our struggle for freedom would have been in vain.

This is where the seeds of the NHI were sown. Access to affordable quality health care for all irrespective of the individuals ability to pay or membership of medical aid, remains the ideal that bound us together as activists, medical students and freedom fighters.

It was clear to us as medical students that the first step in improving the quality of life of our people is to rebel against the national oppression and racial discrimination , overthrow the apartheid regime and ensure all our people have a right to vote.
Comrade Vejay was amongst those students who faced the batons and dodged bullets at Natal University.

For him, no task was a burden and no sacrifice was too high, for he loved his people even as he understood that his call to duty carried a risk to his own life. He had chosen a lonely life in which he would never rest.
When called upon to serve his people, he stepped to the fore. When volunteers and activists were required for grass roots mobilization, he was amongst the first to be counted.
He was a patriot who loved his country and vowed never to rest until his people are freed from apartheid slavery.
Comrade Vejay was a patriot who loved his country and vowed never to rest until his people are freed from apartheid slavery.

Following the launch of the App in the morning, The Department of Health will host a technical briefing to afford the media and public an opportunity to engage Department officials, technical experts and legal experts on the merits of the system.

The COVID Alert SA app will strengthen the existing contact tracing methods to help break the transmission of COVID19 as South Africa seeks to prevent a resurgence of cases since the easing of restrictions to level 2.

*MEDIA INVITATION: COVID Alert SA POST LAUNCH TECHNICAL BRIEFING*

On 2 September 2020, the National Department of Health will launch a powerful new mobile application, COVID Alert SA, to strengthen South Africa’s digital contact tracing efforts.

For Further Information:
Mr Popo Maja
Spokesperson, National Department of Health
072 585 3219

This will be followed by a technical briefing at 10 am on the same day to afford the media and the public an opportunity to engage Department of Health officials, technical experts and legal experts on the system.
END…
The COVID Alert SA app will be launched and available for download in the morning of 2 September 2020.

with someone who has since tested positive for COVID-19. The more people that download it, the better it will work. Learning how to keep everyone safe from COVID is one of the challenges the world faces. I hope that the new COVID Alert app will make a contribution to doing so.”

The app has passed legal muster for implementation through consultation with Justice Catherine O’Regan, the COVID-19 designated judge.
Justice O’Regan said: “The COVID Alert SA app is based on privacy protecting technology to alert users when they have been in close contact...
The Department is grateful to its partners for their contribution, including the Banking Association of South Africa and its members as well as mobile networks Cell C, Telkom, MTN and Vodacom.
COVID Alert SA was developed at no cost to the Department, through a partnership with world-class developers at Discovery Health, Apple and Google.
For every 100 infections we are able to prevent using this technology, we could prevent as many as 15-20 hospital admissions and, save two lives.”

We request everyone to download the app, and those confirmed positive to report their diagnosis so that their contacts can be notified. The app is designed to reduce the impact on the health system and save lives, while preserving privacy at scale.

Mr Gaurang Tanna, who led the app development team within the Department of Health said: “This is a crucial public health intervention to help us suppress COVID-19 and prevent resurgence. It works best when many people download the app.

This technology allows us to effectively break the chain of transmission by dramatically reducing the time between exposure and knowing one has been exposed so that one can take action by self-quarantining and testing when necessary.”

COVID Alert SA provides us with additional armament to achieve suppression of the virus and prevent outbreaks from occurring again by eliminating the time-consuming steps it takes to achieve contact tracing manually.
While the trajectory of the epidemic in South Africa has stabilised, such a resurgence remains a real and present danger in our own country.
Says Director General of Health, Dr Sandile Buthelezi: “Global experience has demonstrated the risk of a resurgence once restrictions on social and economic activity are lifted.

Bluetooth-enabled contact tracing apps allow a greater number of contacts to be traced more rapidly, including strangers whom an index case may not be able to recall or identify. The App is zero rated to facilitate optimal citizen uptake.

When the user does so, all other users with whom they have been in contact for the past 14 days will immediately be notified of their exposure and prompted through the care pathway. At no point in this process is the identity of any user revealed.

Over time, each user builds an “encounter history” of those they have been in contact with.
When a user tests positive, they are requested to report their diagnosis anonymously in the COVID Alert SA app.

Using Bluetooth, the COVID Alert SA app emits a randomly generated code that is picked by other users when two phones come into proximity of one another. This unique identifier changes frequently and cannot be linked to the identity of any user.

developed by Apple and Google to enable contact tracing through mobile phones. The app is fully privacy-preserving, in line with the requirements of the API, and does not collect any personally identifiable information or trace a user’s location.

The COVID Alert SA app will complement and strengthen these existing methods, as a powerful tool to enable the instant notification of contacts following a positive test.
COVID Alert SA is built on the exposure notification Application Programming Interface (API)

To date, the Department has deployed teams to conduct manual contact tracing in every district. Subsequently, the WhatsApp-based COVIDConnect service was launched which allows index cases to anonymously notify their contacts as prompted by the system.

@BioAfricaCON We know that the possibilities are endless and this pandemic has shown us that there is hope for this country and for our fellow Africans as innovators put shoulder to the wheel to make quality health care available to all our people through all possible avenues.

@BioAfricaCON Africa is filled with intelligent, energetic, and ambitious minds. We commit, as a Department, to nurture and grow this capability as we incubate professionals that will advance the ideals of the National Health Insurance.

@BioAfricaCON Another example of local ability are the locally developed fetal heart monitors. This kind of production is a step in the right direction to address key health indicators, such as neonatal mortality rates.

@BioAfricaCON Having experienced the constraints of global shortages of testing kits and PPE’s, I look forward to seeing young minds testing their capacity in these new opportunities and breaking new ground through local manufacturing.

@BioAfricaCON 
I want to turn my attention to how our health industry has responded to the #COVID19 pandemic through the power of biotechnology. In particular, how we use advancements in medical technology to ensure that we are positioned to advance the cause of UHC.

@BioAfricaCON It has been gratifying to see how our own Universities have stepped up to the challenges in the wake of this pandemic. One thing we are certain of is that with a focused approach our Universities and Research Councils can partner with industry to service our needs.
We speak to Dr Nicholas Crisp, a consultant for the National Department of Health, about how the #COVID19 pandemic has affected the future of the NHI in South Africa.

We hope this clarifies the position.

Ends..

Regarding the request for the minutes of the meeting, for purposes of respecting process and confidentiality, we will not release the minutes to the media unless and until they are approved and this is agreed on by the meeting participants.
We attach the attendance register and confirmation of attendance from NEHAWU.

On this unfortunate and incorrect statement by NEHAWU this evening, the Department can only assume that the right hand may have missed what the left hand was doing in so far as this participation in the meeting of 22 August 2020 is concerned.

The Department and the Minister will certainly not interfere with this. 

Having said that, the Department of Health’s commitment to engage with the health workers U nions and address issues raised remains.

It must also be clear that these engagements and the work that is being jointly done does not in any way hinder a legal right of any union to hold a protected protest against an employer as recognized in our labour laws.

We must never lose sight that this is ultimately for the protection and safety of health workers, which is a commitment the Minister and the whole government has consistently made throughout this pandemic.
This leaves us with a task of ensuring that these undertakings are fulfilled and there is constant engagement with the Unions, including through the occupational health and safety committees.

We must also clarify that we do not in any way assert that engagements with the unions were “rosy”. However, there was a clear way forward that the National Department of Health and Provinces committed to.

All of them confirmed attendance and were indeed part of the meeting. NEHAWU even followed up by asking for login details. 

The meeting was productive and the NEHAWU representative participated robustly & constructively in the meeting, and this is appreciated by the Department.

We have also been taken aback by this blatant denial by NEHAWU and wish to once again set the record straight. All organized labour representatives (including NEHAWU) representing health workers were sent an invitation to the meeting.

and the media in a statement released today saying that they (NEHAWU) were part of the meeting held by the Minister and the National Health Council with Unions representing health workers o 22 August 2020.

Welcoming the first 16 of 43 experts dispatched by the World Health Organisation to assist South Africa in its fight against #COVID19. @WHO

From left to right: Dr Owen Kaluwa WHO Representative to SA, Nardos B Thomas UN Resident Co-ordinator, Dr Zweli Mkhize, Dr Matshidiso Moeti WHO Regional Director for Africa and  Dr Joe Phaahla. #WHOSurgeTeamSA

“We believe having the team from @WHO benefits us, as @WHO is at a vantage point, by having global access - which will assist us in the fight against #COVID19.” Dr Joe Phaahla, Deputy Minister of Health.

This is a crisis, we call for Ubuntu ... Umuntu ngumuntu ngabantu - I am because of you. We appreciate the support from WHO. We look forward to a time when we can say we did it, united. #WHOSurgeTeamSA

At the end of #COVID19 we want our surveillance systems to be strengthened at a district level. To deal with Diabetes, Hypertension etc.  as we move towards Universal Healthcare, in our case National Health Insurance #WHOSurgeTeamSA

The work of battling a pandemic does not begin and end and therefore we will be encouraging fluidity and agility and welcome the fact that they will be looking at our situation with fresh eyes and may be able to identify or offer a perspective we might not have considered.

16 team members have now arrived in the country and when the team is complete there will be 43. Those that are already with us have begun an orientation period to ensure there is optimal alignment of programmes.#WHOSurgeTeamSA
With the threat of resurgence remaining very real, we would not want to repeat recent history witnessed in some countries and allow a second surge to wreak even further destruction.#WHOSurgeTeamSA
We are only now considering easing some of the restrictions and we do expect that as restrictions ease, so will the rate of transmission increase.#WHOSurgeTesmSA
We have received queries why there would be a need for the surge team if we are past the surge. I would like to emphasize for our people that we are not past anything: ..

It is from this organisation that one of the most important definitions of our civilization was forged: the WHO defines health as “a state of complete physical, mental, and social well-being and not merely the absence of disease or infirmity.” #WHOSurgeTeamSA

When we consider the socio-economic devastation pandemics can cause, it is without doubt that one of humanities greatest achievements was the establishment of the World Health Organisation in 1948. #WHOSurgeTeamSA

Our people were highly anxious about the stories they were hearing from China and there was great concern about what would happen to millions of South Africans who suffer from these ailments. #WHOSurgeTeamSA
Before the advent of Coronavirus, South Africa was already faced with a triple burden of HIV, TB and non-communicable diseases. #WHOSurgeTeamSA

The devastations of past pandemics are part of our fabric even in modern times- so many of our experiences, customs an traditions were forged during these times of crisis.
 #WHOSurgeTeamSA

I want to thank the Cuban Ambassador to SA, the Cuban embassy here & the embassy of SA in Cuba. #UpdateCubanDrs
Thank you  to our President  for leading and driving this partnership which saw the implementation of a critical programme of boosting human resources for health during the #COVID19. #UpdateCubanDrs
You have joined South Africans in the Thuma Mina call. You are comrades in combat.#UpdateCubanDrs
We thank you for answering the call during one of the toughest seasons experienced in modern times and we hope that this has been a fruitful and inspirational period for you all. #UpdateCubanDrs

We are very privileged to be joined by members of the Cuban Brigade here today. It is an honour to be amongst compatriots who have tirelessly worked in the frontline alongside our own fellow countrymen in the health care sector.#UpdateCubanDrs
improved processing of data and contributed to improved data reporting that feeds into the daily situational report on COVID-19 in the province. #UpdateCubanDrs
The deployments were based on areas where it was identified there was a shortage of human resources. Their presence has reduced workload and pressure on staff members, provided much needed relief,...

In Limpopo, eight medical officers have been deployed into various facilities in five districts to boost Case Management. Three Clinical Engineering Technologists, one hygienist and one biostatician are stationed in Capricorn District. #UpdateCubanDrs
The Northern Cape department of Health has attested to the invaluable contribution of the #Covid19 personnel from the Brigade. #UpdateCubanDrs

In the Northern Cape the Brigade are doing outreach services in critical areas of need. They are Clinical Leaders to the management teams and assist in the screening, testing and quarantining of patients.#UpdateCubanDrs

They are mainly working in quarantine and isolation sights, ward-based contract tracing, epidemiological surveillance and in hospitals where there has been noticeable nosocomial spread.#UpdateCubanDrs
In Gauteng Province, Members of the Cuban Medical Brigade are distributed throughout all five Districts and some have been doing work with the central office. #UpdateCubanDrs
The Biomedical Engineers have been critical in the design, installation, adjusting, repairing and provision of technical support for biomedical equipment. #UpdateCubanDrs

The Medical Officers have been resourceful in Primary Health Care as this is their specialty. Their Data analytics and information management has been key in assessing the impact of intervention strategies. #UpdateCubanDrs
The Eastern Cape was allocated 12 Medical Officers: 4 Biomedical Engineers, 2 Epidemiologists, and 2 Biostatitians. #UpdateCubanDrs
The brigade has been deployed throughout the country. Their expertise has been utilised across the provinces. #UpdateCubanDrs
What is being done today, is an extension of the past. In our hour of need, we wwre able to call on our Cuban brothers and sisters.#UpdateCubanDrs
We shall forever be indebted to Cubans for giving up their resources, their flesh and blood, to help fight apartheid. #UpdateCubanDrs
This is not the first time Cuba has supported South Africa. Cuba sent young women and men to serve in the jungles of Angola to help us fight injustice.#UpdateCubanDrs

He was a visionary who held high hopes for our country and an innovator who always harboured dreams of a better South Africa and spent time figuring strategies to take this nation to the future of his ideals.

Says Minister Mkhize, “South Africa has lost one of her best sons- confident, knowledgeable, articulate and inspiring. One of the top thinkers, a brilliant mind, an outstanding academic and a pioneering researcher.

Prof Pepeta was completing a PhD in Paediatrics from the University of Stellenbosch. His postgraduate qualifications included a Diploma in Child Health, Fellowship of the College of Paediatricians, and a Certificate in Cardiology from the College of Paediatricians.

Prof Pepeta held an MBChB from the University of Transkei (now Walter Sisulu University), a Master of Medicine in Paediatrics from the University of the Witwatersrand as well as a Fellowship of the Society for Cardiovascular Angiography and Interventions (USA).

His main life purpose, in recent years, has been the establishment of the Medical Faculty at the Nelson Mandela University in the Eastern Cape. He worked tirelessly on this mammoth task and finally accomplished this feat recently.
A committed public servant, Prof Pepeta dedicated his life to healthcare in Eastern Cape working for various public hospitals in the field of Paediatric Cardiology.

when in June 2020 he ascended to the role of Chairperson.
Prof Pepeta was a seasoned health specialist and academic, and served as the Executive Dean of the Faculty of Health Sciences at Nelson Mandela University in Port Elizabeth.

He had replaced Dr Clarence Mini, who also passed away in May this year after contracting the virus. Prof Pepeta had been an ordinary member of the Council for Medical Schemes since his appointment by the Minister of Health in November 2017, ...
Prof Pepeta succumbed to COVID-19 after battling the illness for several weeks. His funeral was held on 12 August in Bizana, Eastern Cape.

Statement on Professor Pepeta’s passing  - Last week, The Minister of Health, Hon Dr Zwelini Mkhize, learnt with shock and sadness of the passing of recently appointed Chairperson of the Council for Medical Schemes (CMS), Professor Lungile Pepeta.

We want people to continue to come to clinics and hospital. Immunization is important, stocking on chronic medication and treatment of diseases like diabetes, hypertension etc. #KZNVisit

We want to thank all South Africans that have followed containment measures. The practicing of these measure has assisted in the downward trend. There are still many not following these practices, so we appeal to those to please wear a mask, wash hands and sanitize etc. #KZNVisit
We have to ensure that our healthcare workers need to be protected. We need to make sure the infection does not pass from patient to healthcare worker and vice-versa. #KZNVisit
Another field hospital will be completed here, providing 220 beds. These two hospitals will be serving Clairwood and the southern suburbs of Durban. #KZNVisit
I used to work here at Clairwood hospital. It was a dreary looking hospital. I’m happy to note it has a refreshing appearance. There are 190 beds available here. #KZNVisit

We’ve heard of the challenges, such as Northdale Hospital. This was unacceptable, we are aware that actions have been taken. A message to management is, we want them to take their actions seriously and quality of care must be provided. #KZNVisit
Bed occupancy is still fairly low in KZN. This means as the surge comes around we will be able to cater for it. #KZNVisit
One thing that has been helpful both in WC and Gauteng is a bed administration bureau. This records bed availability and then patients are directed to the relevant hospital. #KZNVisit
The one province that remains with high numbers still increasing, is KwaZulu-Natal. The focus now needs to be here. The province therefore needs to be ready. #KZNVisit

In Gauteng we found the admission wards were where the bottleneck was. We have not reached bed capacity. Nasrec field Hospital has 500 beds, during my visit only about 150 of these beds were filled.

Situational report on South Africa's efforts to fight #COVID19. Read the full address here:

#ListenToTheDoctor
It’s time to stand together & be united, says Dr Jeanetta Moilanen from Bosmont Clinic in Johannesburg.

#ListenToTheExperts
The risk of developing severe symptoms of COVID-19 may be increased in people who have underlying comorbidities. Listen to Prof Lucille Blumberg, deputy director, NICD.

The @WHO will be sending 43 experts to South Africa, to bolster the country's response to #COVID19. 
#HealthUpdate
Specimens which will be tested for #COVID19 will now be taken from those who pass away suddenly while at home. This will improve our reporting of deaths caused by the virus. #HealthUpdate
Healthcare workers on the forefront of our fight against #COVID19 are a priority. More is being done to keep them safe. #HealthUpdate
There has been positive news in South Africa's #COVID19 epidemiology. Positive cases are not increasing as rapidly and more people are surviving ICU. #HealthUpdate

These are some of the urgent interventions put in place to ensure the safety of healthcare workers on the frontline of South Africa’s fight against #COVID19.
Read more here:
WHO recommends the following to new mothers with suspected or confirmed COVID-19 when it comes to breastfeeding. #WorldBreastfeedingWeek
The real risk of experiencing the “second wave” of the pandemic remains, so containment measures must never be abandoned. #HealthUpdate

We can never over-emphasise the importance of good human behaviour and the impact it can have on flattening the curve. The containment measures being implemented are assisting however, we must not be complacent. #HealthUpdate

Update on vaccines: Currently we are participating in the ChAdOx-1 study and in the COVAX project to be part of the global research initiatives as well as the access to vaccines programme. We also wish to pursue the possibility of manufacturing vaccines locally. #HealthUpdate

We have no doubt experienced challenges and glitches. This is in no way unique to our country. I therefore want to submit, with all humility, that up to now our government has displayed its readiness and has thus far coped with the surge.#HealthUpdate
Bed and Oxygen Capacity: We have not breached our bed capacity and many of our field hospitals are not filled to capacity and we continue to monitor this as we manage the surge. #HealthUpdate

All provinces are to ensure that OHS committees are fully formed and functional within the week and must meet at least once a week. In these meetings staff and unions must ventilate all issues and if resolution is not satisfactory, the complaints must be escalated to the MEC’s.

Unions have been raising their concerns about workplace safety, the availability and quality of PPE and the mental and physical wellbeing of their members. We also recognize the critical role-plays by Unions in representing their members’ views and concerns at the workplace.

I viewed these allegations in a serious light and have decided to appoint a team led by Professor Taole Mokoena together with other medical, nursing and legal professionals, to conduct an urgent investigation and provide me with a report in 14 days from the commencement date.
There were also allegations that this was due to lack of sufficient supply of PPE and doctors being made to work in unsafe environments at the facility.#HealthUpdate
a few days ago my office brought to my attention that there were public reports that a doctor had passed away at George Mukhari Academic Hospital due to COVID-19 related illness.#HealthUpdate

We have even received reports that some may be dying after being infected due to the lack of sufficient PPE or due to sufficient PPE not be provided and/ or failure or neglect by management to adhere to prescribed workplace safety protocols.#HealthUpdate

Healthcare worker safety: The Department of Health therefore notes, with concern, increasing allegations of health care workers contracting the Coronavirus on the line of duty due to lack or poor quality of personal protective equipment.#HealthUpdate
The containment measures such as mask wearing, sanitizing and washing hands etc. are important. The indications are that the containment measures are assisting  #HealthUpdate
Western Cape, Gauteng and Eastern Cape seem to have had their surges and are starting to taper off. It does not mean we are out of the woods. #HealthUpdate
In response to the report on excess deaths. We will now require all sudden deaths & deaths that occur at home , that a specimen be taken. #HealthUpdate
We want to take this opportunity to give an update to public. As we present today we have gone beyond the 500 000 confirmed number of cases. #HealthUpdate

#COVID19 Statistics in SA as at 04 August.
As of today, the total number of confirmed #COVID19 cases is 521 318, the total number of deaths is 8 884 and the total number of recoveries is 363 751.
Mothers who have suspected or confirmed #COVID19 should continue breastfeeding while practicing  good respiratory hygiene.

We call on all men & women to support natural breastfeeding in any environment whether it be work, in public places, in gatherings, churches or even at home when other people enter into that space.#WorldBreastfeedingWeek
Women must be able to feed their babies anywhere,anytime, without feeling any shame in doing so.#WorldBreastfeedingWeek

Breastfeeding is a natural phenomenon- a beautiful reflection of humanity’s foundation. African culture has always embraced, indeed normalized, breastfeeding and this is a culture we need to reinculcate in modern society. #WorldBreastfeedingWeek

To access all breastfeeding support resources and information, please visit  One can also join the caregiver community on  for more breastfeeding information or to enter monthly competitions. #WorldBreastfeedingWeek

We have just launched Season 2 of our Side-by-Side radio shows. These radio shows are broadcast weekly in 10 official languages and aim to provide caregivers and community members with information on the full range of care that children require, ensuring they develop optimally.
It is important for us to support first time and young mothers. #WorldBreastfeedingWeek

We will continue with our efforts to support and empower mothers and primary caregivers with information on their parenting journey, even during these difficult times, from pregnancy stage until the child turns 5 years old. #WorldBreastfeedingWeek

I would therefore like to encourage all health care workers to contact the nearest Breast Bank if they require breast milk for their patients and to assure them that there is adequate stock at this stage. #WorldBreastfeedingWeek

Donated breastmilk is a critical resource in managing children who cannot breastfeed for various reasons but whose optimal treatment includes the administration of breastmilk. The vast majority of these patients are premature babies who benefit enormously. #WorldBreastfeedingWeek

Our facilities all have a triage mechanism whereby patients with flu-like illnesses are separated from patients presenting for other reasons. This is to ensure that access to quality health care is not compromised during the #COVID19 surge. #WorldBreastfeedingWeek
I urge all mothers, fathers and caregivers not to default on their children’s vaccination schedules for fear of visiting a facility and contracting #COVID19.

SA’s recommendation of optimal infant feeding is in line with the global recommendation for infant feeding. Breastfeeding should begin within the 1st hour after birth, and all babies,regardless of the mother’s HIV status-should be exclusively breastfed for the first 6 months.
There is a clear link between malnutrition and lack of breastfeeding. Furthermore, our current levels of exclusive breastfeeding- 1 in 4 children (32%) is not good enough.#WorldBreastfeedingWeek

Among the reasons why there is an increase in malnutrition especially in children under five is because many mothers wean their children to quickly, large due to socio-economic pressures on women in modern times.#WorldBreastfeedingWeek
Breastfeeding is nature’s way of protecting the physical and mental wellbeing of mothers and babies in the first critical years of life.#WorldBreastfeedingWeek

Breastfeeding provides protection against postpartum haemorrhage after the baby is born. The long term benefits are that chances of getting breast cancer, ovarian cancer and endometrial cancer are reduced.#WorldBreastfeedingWeek

Breastfeeding can protect children from many other illnesses and conditions such as diarrhoea, chest infections, diabetes, and heart disease. Nearly half of diarrhoea episodes and one third of respiratory infections are due to lack of breastfeeding. #WorldBreastfeedingWeek

A baby’s immune system is not yet fully developed and requires the immune protection from breastmilk. This life saving protection is more important than ever right now during the #COVID19 pandemic.
#WorldBreastfeedingWeek

Research evidence has shown that the virus is not transmitted through breastmilk or by giving breastmilk that has been expressed from a mother who is confirmed/ suspected to have #COVID19.
#WorldBreastfeedingWeek

Many are worried and asking many questions whether the coronavirus can be passed on through breastmilk and how can they protect themselves and their babies. I can assure you that the #COVID19 virus has not been found in breastmilk . #WorldBreastfeedingWeek

We have not filled all field hospital beds or all ICU beds yet. However we also have an agreement with private sector that should the need arise for more beds, we will work together.#QuestionTime @Newzroom405
Cuban doctors are serving in all provinces. They are making a difference. We have also brought in medical students to work together with them.#QuestionTime

The plan for the Eastern Cape, a plan has been submitted to myself, the Premier and MEC. The plan entails what needs to be done in the relevant facilities. The province has renovated and added additional beds. These interventions are going to make a difference.#QuestionTime

What we expect is that the numbers are still likely to increase. We expect in terms of the models that in August and September we will still have high numbers. Each province has got its own trajectory.#QuestionTime @Newzroom405

If we are not practising social behavioural changes, #COVID19 will continue to spread. The numbers will always grow depending on how well as a community we can break the cycle.#QuestionTime @Newzroom405

As we head towards surge, it is very important that all South Africans keep their masks on, sanitise and practice social distancing. #LSDHVisit
We can be stronger than the storm. #LSDHVisit
It is an important call to save the nation. Thank you to our healthworkers.#LSDHVisit
Our beds are not full in Gauteng. We are expecting more beds on stream in the next few weeks so we are prepared. #LSDHVisit

There is no need to discriminate against those that have #COVID19 we need to be accepting of this, it can happen to anybody in any house. We continue to do everything to move ahead of the surge. #LSDHVisit
If you need treatment our institutions will do everything to ensure that you come out well.#LSDHVisit
#COVID19 is going to be with us for a while. We need to adjust and we do this by wearing masks, using sanitizer, washing hands and social distancing. It is very important #LSDHVisit
While the infection spreads and people are being tested, we must remember there have been people who have already recovered. We can be stronger than the storm. #LSDHVisit
At Nasrec, there is a 90 year old patient and a 12 year old. An 84 year old patient has been discharged after recovering. #LSDHVisit
If you suspect distress in your chest, someone described it as a feeling of having an elephant sitting on you chest- you must realise your oxygen supply is being affected by the infection.#LSDHVisit

We appeal to south africans to take #COVID19 seriously, wear a mask, sanitise your hands. We are still hearing of people moving around without masks and hosting parties. This is very serious.#LSDHVisit
We expect the numbers in KwaZulu Natal to increase and for KZN to be the province with the second highest numbers after Gauteng. #LSDHVisit

Our healthworkers are beginning to feel the opening up of space in our hospitals. And that is positive. Additional beds in all our hospitals will continue to ease the burden on some facilities.#LSDHVisit
We thank all our healthworkers. They can call us at anytime for assistance. All volunteers who have been recruited will be compensated.#LSDHVisit
We believe our efforts and the competence of our clinicians is allowing us to keep our mortality rate low. #LSDHVisit
Oxygen tanks at hospitals like this one in Lenasia is important. We are watching our peak. The numbers may be less than what had been predicted but we cannot be sure.#LSDHVisit

The numbers are increasing & this has put pressure on our hospitals. There are blockages but the triage system is assisting us. There are field beds available. Nasrec has a capacity for 1500 beds. We can still absorb many more patients there. #LSDHVisit
Lenasia south district hospital was recently upgraded to cater for the growing needs of the communitiy as well as the for the #COVID19 pandemic. #LSDHVisit
On a walkabout of the newly renovated Lenasia south district hospital.
Briefing the media during a visit to the Nasrec field hospital, south of Johannesburg. #NASRECVisit

The private sector will also assist with patients needing high care, should the need arise.
#NASRECVisit

Our clinicians are quite on top of the game, The decisions of admission are up-to the Clinicians. If people are reined away it will not be due to lack of beds, but because they do not meet the admission criteria. #NASRECVisit

We are watching and looking at the trends and certainly Gauteng is at the top of rate of infection. KZN is taking over now and we’ll need to reach out to them so they don’t get caught up with the numbers. #NASRECVisit
The interventions are the response to changing patterns. There is no formula, there is no text book. The day to day action is what makes a difference. #NASRECVisit
Arrival at NASREC field hospital in Gauteng Province to assess readiness for the #COVID19 surge. #NASRECVisit

Among the many causes that Nelson Mandela championed, he was a powerful voice for access to life-saving vaccines in Africa.

#MandelaDay
Madiba’s intervention at the international Aids conference in Durban in 2000 was a watershed moment that marked the beginning of his total commitment to the fight against HIV/Aids.

#MandelaDay
Four out of five South Africans depend on the public health care system that Madiba championed. Phelophepa cuts through our countryside nine months a year delivering low-cost medical care to the rural poor.
#MandelaDay is celebrated the world over as a day of service that recognises the late, great Nelson Mandela's birth anniversary.

Tested positive for Covid-19? Here’s some sound advice from Joburg general practioner Dr Marlin McCay on how to take care of yourself, & protect those around you.

The windows only need to be opened in such a way, as to create a flow of air. We feel fairly comfortable due to these studies, as there have also been studies on the value of ventilation for TB in taxis. #GPVisit14July

There is a study that was done in the flow of air, by Matose & Munyaradzi. They determined you just needed to open a certain number of windows on either side. We have suggested putting in stoppers on the windows, so the commuters aren’t uncomfortable with all windows opened fully
There is a degree in which the windows need to be opened to create a flow and ventilation in the taxi that will allow the droplets to move out the taxis, if any. #GPVisit14July

With regards to taxis- we have looked at the sustainability of the taxi industry. We have reached out to look at mitigate negating steps. 1- everyone going into a taxi, must wear a mask. The issue of hand sanitizer and thirdly the windows need to be open. #GPVisit14July
We are not yet at a point where we have a vaccine. There are trials going on across the world and We are watching all the research. #GPVisit14July

We would like to encourage all volunteers. We do need their services and we are grateful. If there are PPE shortages , staff members are encouraged to come forward so it can be addressed adequately #GPVisit14July

Ideally workplaces should open when transmissions are low. However in our case the issue of job security, food security and the economy means we have to adjust to living with the  importance of social behavioral change is integral. #GPVisit14July
We have been attending to the concern of the shortage of beds. The blockage is when patients are waiting for their status. The quarantine sites have beds that are available to be used. #GPVisit14July
National and provincial offices are going into the areas, to attend to issues. Such as shortages of staff, infrastructure and rollout of beds #GPVisit14July
Arrival at Dr George Mukhari Hospital as part of the oversight visits in Gauteng. #GPVisit14July

#COVID19 Statistics in SA as at 13 July 2020.
As of today, the total number of confirmed #COVID19 cases is 287 796, the total number of deaths is 4172 and the total number of recoveries is 138 241.
We need to unite, follow the guidance of our President, and fight this virus together. #SocialClusterBriefing #NewNormal #HealthInput13July
I pay tribute to all healthcare workers and frontline workers, and all those who made it possible to make protective gear available to them. #SocialClusterBriefing #HealthInput13July #NewNormal
#SocialClusterBriefing #HealthInput13July #NewNormal
We have to change our behaviour everywhere. Large gatherings are not allowed. #SocialClusterBriefing #HealthInput13July #NewNormal
We must continue to protect those with co-morbidities and the elderly. #SocialClusterBriefing #HealthInput13July #NewNormal
#SocialClusterBriefing #HealthInput13July #NewNormal
Early administration of oxygen is something we are working on, in all hospitals. #SocialClusterBriefing #HealthInput13July #NewNormal

The national emergency intervention team is looking at increasing the number of beds. We are confident we can provide enough beds before the surge. #SocialClusterBriefing #HealthInput13July #NewNormal
#SocialClusterBriefing #HealthInput13July #NewNormal
People must continue to get their treatment for other illnesses like TB, HIV & cancer. Immunisation must continue. #SocialClusterBriefing #HealthInput13July #NewNormal

We have to stress that continuous isolation and quarantine of infected people remains our biggest weapon in containing the spread of the pandemic. We will later in the week announce the changes in quarantine days. #SocialClusterBriefing #HealthInput13July #NewNormal
We must embrace people who have tested positive for #COVID19, and offer them support. #SocialClusterBriefing #HealthInput13July #NewNormal

A large number of people contract the virus without showing any symptoms and recover on their own, without testing. That is happening in all countries. #SocialClusterBriefing #HealthInput13July #NewNormal

Our models are getting more refined. The data shows the surge will come in July, Aug & Sep, but at a lower level than what had been predicted. That is due to the steps that have been taken to contain the spread of the virus. #SocialClusterBriefing #HealthInput13July #NewNormal

Economic activity has been opened to save our people from unemployment. A lot of activities take place after hours and outside of the workplace. The curfew was announced to limit the number of people who get infected. We can have the surge at a lower level by taking these steps.

Research suggests that while an alcohol ban could ease pressure on hospitals, it can also reduce intimate partner violence in many households across the country. Find out more here: #SocialClusterBriefing #HealthInput13July #NewNormal

Projections show that we could alleviate the pressure on hospitals by stopping thousands of alcohol-related trauma cases in only the first week after the alcohol ban. Find out more here: #SocialClusterBriefing #HealthInput13July #NewNormal

The data behind the alcohol ban shows that there was a significant reduction in alcohol-related trauma cases at our hospitals. However, the number of cases increased significantly when the ban was eased. Find out more here: #SocialClusterBriefing #HealthInput13July #NewNormal
Many have welcomed and supported the alcohol ban. We are very concerned about the high alcohol consumption in the country. #SocialClusterBriefing #HealthInput13July #NewNormal

Ideally people should not be close to one another in a taxi. We saw the need for mitigating steps, hence for long distance, the 70% capacity. When it is 100% there are specific guidelines to follow. #NewNormal #SocialClusterBriefing #HealthInput13July

Taxis transport about 16 million people daily. We had to look at the best way of getting our people back to work. Studies in China show close proximity and air filters enhance the spread of the virus. What we also discovered is the importance of ventilation in confined spaces.

There are 52 districts which can be regarded as hotspots. #COVID19 is spreading and we are losing our loved ones and our family & friends are being infected. It is important for everyone to change their behaviour and take responsibility, & stem the tide of the pandemic.

As health we have come to give clarity on the President’s announcements last night. We monitor the movement of the infection every day, we hold special meetings & consult the different departments in between. #SocialClusterBriefing #HealthInput13July #NewNormal
Social distancing is one of the key practices proven to prevent the spread of #COVID19. Remember to keep a 1.5m distance from others. #NewNormal
Droplets which carry #COVID19 can linger on surfaces. Make sure to disinfect regularly touched surfaces in your homes and workplaces.#NewNormal
Maintaining regular hand hygiene is important in preventing the spread of #COVID19. Wash your hands with soap and water or use an alcohol-based hand sanitizer. #NewNormal
Remember, wearing a cloth mask in public is essential in protecting yourself and others from contracting #COVID19. #NewNormal
It is now compulsory to wear a mask in public. Protect yourself and those around you. #NewNormal
The responsibility of protecting one another from #COVID19 lies in the hands of all South Africans. #NewNormal
On Youth Day this year, we warned that amidst rising #COVID19 infections, the only way to fight the spread of the virus would be to reinforce behavioural changes. #NewNormal
Several warnings against failure to adhere to precautionary measures against #COVID19 have been issued . You can make a difference! #NewNormal
The need to balance lives and livelihoods explained. #NewNormal
The fight against #COVID19 is in our hands. Reiterating the power of social behavioural changes in a media interview on 6 June. #NewNormal
More than 3 months ago on 31 March, calling for a change in social behaviour at a media briefing in KwaZulu-Natal . #NewNormal

#TshwaneVisit Our priority now is increasing bed capacity and managing the distribution of beds, so we can save as many lives as possible.
#TshwaneVisit As we go about our daily work and routines, we must ensure we adhere to the precautionary measures against #COVID19
#TshwaneVisit A renewed call to fight #COVID19 by changing the way we behave. Wash hands, practice social distancing & wear a mask.
#TshwaneVisit Reiterating the importance of wearing a mask.
Our priority is to save lives, not dig graves.
What are the nine pillars of government's differentiated approach to fighting #COVID19?
#ZweliMkhize: I was briefed in what the province was doing. It is well within their rights to address their challenges.#TshwaneVisit

#ZweliMkhize: We can only assess its success once its in use. The issues of procurement is in the hands of the provincial government. The question was whether the motorcycles meet that standards of ambulances and the answer is no. #TshwaneVisit

#ZweliMkhize: The EC scooters- the provincial government informed us they were addressing the issue of reaching rural areas. They looked at a mechanism to support health workers. These are also being used in Rwanda and Tanzania. Support for rural area nurses is important.

#ZweliMkhize: The demand for tests is always increasing. We have conducted two million tests. We have improved the backlog significantly. We should not underplay the hardwork done by laboratory staff.#TshwaneVisit
#ZweliMkhize: We have been informed of the shotage of staff and we will be deploying additional staff from nursing agencies to complement staff. #TshwaneVisit
#ZweliMkhize: We convey our condolences to those who have lost loved ones. We share in your grief.#TshwaneVisit
#ZweliMkhize: Your dedication and resilience is an inspiration to South Africans. We salute you as our heroes. #TshwaneVisit
#ZweliMkhize: I will be distributing gear from the solidarity fund to all the provinces. We will work with the unions to oversee the distribution and quality of our stock. #TshwaneVisit
#ZweliMkhize: We want to pay tribute to our health workers who have braved it all and went out to save our nation.  We assure you that we will make sure that you are protected. #TshwaneVisit
#ZweliMkhize; It is important to support one another. We must also go all out to treat those who are infected. We can behave in a manner that can reduce the spread. #TshwaneVisit

#ZweliMkhize: We need to find a way to balance re-opening our economy and saving our people. We are focusing on bed capacity ans saving lives. We can still make sure that we can contain this virus. #TshwaneVisit
#ZweliMkhize: We need the support of our citizens. We must focus and work together. To walk around without a mask is dangerous to ourselves and the people around us #TshwaneVisit

#ZweliMkhize: Social behaviour is fundamental in fighting #COVID19. We call on our communities to work together to encourage behavioural change. It is important that screening and sanitisation continue on all our transport routes #TshwaneVisit
#ZweliMkhize: We are acknowledging that we have to co-exist with #COVID19. We have to take lessons from other countries #TshwaneVisit

#ZweliMkhize: The lockdown couldn’t stop person to person  will increase as people are moving more freely now. It gave us as much benefit as it could. The surge is coming as expected. It is happening at a lower rate than what was predicted.#TshwaneVisit
#ZweliMkhize: The advent of Dexamethasone is part of our protocols now. Its is safe and useful in treatment.#TshwaneVisit
#ZweliMkhize: The team is also working on oxygen points. Nasrec will have 1000 oxygen points. We will also increase the number of ventilators. #TshwaneVisit
#ZweliMkhize: We have a team looking at adding 2000 additional beds to field hospitals in Gauteng.#TshwaneVisit
#ZweliMkhize: Most of the patients will be asked to go to the tent. The public need to understand this is a way of assessing their #COVID19 status. #TshwaneVisit

#ZweliMkhize: Triage centres which are marquees allow us to seperate #COVID19 positive patients from those who are negative. 
#TshwaneVisit
#ZweliMkhize: There is going to be lots of pressure on hospitals and beds. The pattern taken by the spread of the disease has meant we have had to make some changes to our strategy.#TshwaneVisit

#ZweliMkhize: The surge is upon us. We are here to see the level of preparations. Gauteng has surged to be the province with the highest number. This is not surprising. We have to be vigilant.#TshwaneVisit
We are already working together with industry on the supply of oxygen. They are beginning to divert supply to hospitals. #TshwaneVisit

The lockdown helped and it reduced the numbers. We eased lockdown for various reasons- one being to address the challenge of food and income security. Secondly our own models indicated you may not be able to get more benefit after a certain period. #TshwaneVisit

We want to make sure that we increase the number of  must work together with all the agencies and recruit. We must balance the numbers of those who are on leave due to isolation or quarantine and those who must be recruited. #TshwaneVisit
We can’t defer non-Covid issues, so increasing bed capacity has to take into account all the other services that must continue. #TshwaneVisit

We haven’t reached capacity yet but from last week we raised the issue of increasing bed capacity. Daily updates with the province are received on how many more beds have been added. We also need to make sure we increase capacity for PUI’s. #TahwaneVisit

The numbers are increasing- we are right in the storm. We need to be determined to keep the numbers of fatalities as low as possible. Wherever you are, you are not fighting your own  are fighting on behalf of the whole nation. #TshwaneVisit

We do appreciate all that you have done, our health care workers are all important. We have to do everything to try and make sure that everyone is well trained, well protected and their mental health supported. #TshwaneVisit
Arrival at Tshwane district hospital to assess preparedness for the surge in Gauteng Province. #TshwaneVisit

#ZweliMkhize: South Africa is officially in the eye of the storm as cases increase drastically on a daily basis. 
#Parliament08July

#ZweliMkhize: As a nation we have every reason to be united in this fight against #COVID19. As government, we have said, we cannot fight this #COVID19 enemy alone. We need all political parties, social partners and every citizen to come on board. #Parliament08July

#ZweliMkhize: This pandemic that is attacking us globally, will cause us lifetime scars. It steals from us, from some, lives, others jobs, others businesses. It spares no race, no gender or social class. #Parliament08July

#ZweliMkhize: As a country and the world at large, we are now in this reality where we must live with knowing that some of us cannot even bury our loved ones because of restrictions or even because we ourselves have been exposed. #Parliament08July

#ZweliMkhize:  its no longer a matter of announcing numbers of confirmed cases. We are now at a point where it’s our fathers, mothers, brothers, sisters, close friend and comrade that are infected. #Parliament08July

#ZweliMkhize: The Dept. is working with the National Treasury and partners to conduct an audit of the oxygen reticulation infrastructure in all our hospitals. These audits are being conducted with a priority focus on the Eastern Cape, KwaZulu-Natal and Gauteng.#Parliament08July
#ZweliMkhize This means that fewer people were infected in May and June than was previously predicted even under the optimistic scenario.#Parliament08July

#ZweliMkhize: Model projections indicate that while the epidemic is predicted to peak nationally at a similar time to the previously projected optimistic curve (that is mid-August), it does so at a lower level.#Parliament08July
#ZweliMkhize:We salute you as healthcare workers, we do appreciate you and your contribution to the nation #Parliament08July

There has not been any decision taken (to have another lockdown) and certainly the NCCC does not take lightly a decision of that nature. There may be need in some areas for restrictions, it may not be national but localised. But no such decision has been taken as yet. @SAfmRadio
Our biggest challenge is getting people to understand and take precautions. @Radio702
Dexamethasone is not a new drug, however we are excited about the breakthrough. The key issue however is prevention. @Radio702

The tests lying on the road was disappointing, it seems to be the courier company, we’ve asked these services to be suspended. We cannot have this type of negligence. We are grateful to those who spotted and reported this matter. @Radio702

EC has a number of challenges, part of it is to strengthen their management capacity. We have deployed officials to assist. I have seen improvements in the past 6weeks. We do know there are challenges of staffing. @Radio702

People with Co-morbidities must continue to take their medication and try to get a multi month supply of medication. Where possible they should work from home, if not to seclude themselves at work. @Radio702

Wc started surging numbers very quickly. WC in June went up by 40 000 people, but in GP as of last night we close to 3000 per day. The problem is too many people getting sick at the same time. We want to plead to people to use the masks, hand washing,social distancing etc
