More than 6000 additional medical personnel have been employed to assist in the fight against #COVID19. #ECVisit23June
Government has made significant roads in increasing the country's ventilator capacity for the fight against #COVID19. #ECVisit23June
As at June 23, more than 4000 people are in hospital for #COVID19 and are receiving different levels of treatment. #ECVisit23June

#HealthcareHeroes
Sister Lynn Bodibe tells us why taking your TB medication regularly is important.
#COVID19 modelling is theoretical and can be influenced by our behaviour as South Africans to take precautions in preventing the spread of #COVID19. #ECVisit23June
We need to change our behaviour in order to prevent the spread, and mortality rate, of #COVID19
It is up to all South Africans to play a part in fighting #COVID19. #ECVisit23June
We have to rely on social behavioural change as a key tool in preventing the spread of #COVID19.
Greeting and welcoming the first nurses to be enrolled to work at the Field Hospital. #ECVisit23June
Opening the Rev. Dr Elizabeth Mamisa Chabula-Nxiweni Field Hospital in Eastern Cape to bolster the province’s #COVID19 response.
On a walkabout of the field hospital also looking at innovative ventilation solutions. #ECVisit23June
Phase 1 has been completed now.  VW presents plans for phase two and phase three. #ECVisit23June
We thank VW as a company, the provincial government, the mayor, the premier, and the provincial health department for the work they have done in making this facility available.#ECVisit23June
We need to look after ourselves, our neighbours, everybody who has co-morbidities. It is up to South Africans to deal with this fight. #ECVisit23June

There are lots of comorbidities which increase the risk of #COVID19 patients. We are taking the role of comorbidities in individual deaths into account. Our teams are working on how we standardize the release of death results.#ECVisit23June

Dexamethasone has been used for a number of years. We are excited to source Dexamethasone at the stage when patients are on ventilators. It only works for people who are on ventilators or on oxygen and does not mean people can neglect precautions.#ECVisit23June
We are focusing on the Eastern Cape and Gauteng after moving from the Western Cape, prioritising the elderly, the vulnerable ans those with symptoms.#ECVisit23June

Our testing strategy has enabled us to complete over 1,2 million tests in just under 4 months. 
We have also reduced the backlog from 101 000 to 46 493. Our testing capacity ranks among the best in the world.#ECVisit23June
We cherish our health workers. We will do everything to provide training and PPEs to our health workers. #ECVisit23June
For those health care workers who are still battling on, we wish them a speedy recovery and we are indeed very pleased to say that 1 993 health care workers have recovered.#ECVisit23June
As at 16 June 3 583 health care workers acquired #COVID19 and of those we have lost 34 soldiers to this war. #ECVisit23June
Our call for all medical personnel to take in posts remains. We nees retired medical personnel to cone in board. We thank the Cuban doctors for their support. #ECVisit23June
Two weeks ago we thought we would run out of beds in the Western Cape and we called in the private sector. We need to make the message strong that we can’t let our foot off the pedal. #ECVisit23June
We have done everything on government policy and decisions. Now people must behave according to their own conscience. We must now rely on that. #ECVisit23June

We have the formula to be able to reduce the pandemic and this is what we must continue doing. The kind of reluctance to take up quarantine must be addressed. There are people not following on the message of social distancing and masks. #ECVisit23June

As we have cleared the backlog of the Western Cape, we see the numbers reducing. We strengthened quarantine in the Eastern Cape. We need to make sure we are not missing any movement phenomena.#ECVisit23June
Wherever you are as a health worker, please know that SA appreciates you. #ECVisit23June
I pay tribute to my health family, to all healthcare workers, who have had to face the challenges of infected individuals and put their lives at risk. #ECVisit23June

It was important to get the support od  religious leaders agreed to stop large gatherings, it helped us tremendously. The next phase is on the shoulders of each and every South African, and on communities. #ECVisit23June

There wasn’t a way we could keep a perpetual lockdown forever. Currently, a number of vaccine trials are going on, but none of them are expected to give us a vaccine in the months to come. Therefore, we have to rely on a change of social behaviour. #ECVisit23June
The pandemic is going to be with us for a few years. We have to rely on social behavioural change to beat this virus. #ECVisit23June
Flattening the curve is a continuous, everyday battle. In lockdown we managed to reduce the movement of people. #ECVisit23June

All the preparations that we had put in place, we will make use of at this point. Although we started with differing and flattening the curve, we did get acknowledgement from the WHO which pointed out the advantages of our proactive community-based strategy.#ECVisit23June

We then resolved to embark on what is called the differentiated approach. Now that we have reduced the restrictions and started opening up, we are seeing that the numbers have started to increase. We are moving towards a devastating and decimating storm.#ECVisit23June
As we looked at the different parts of the country we have been able to implement a strategy to effectively deal with each area. #ECVisit23June
It is possible to defeat this scourge. It is important to understand this is a dangerous pandemic. We have been able to identify low transmission areas and hotspots.#ECVisit23June

The President also announced that as a country we had embarked on an intensive community screening campaign and to this end we  have deployed just over 50 000 community health care workers who have successfully screened almost 20 000 000 South Africans.#ECVisit23June

We have successfully increased our #COVID19 bed capacity to above 27 000. 
We have identified over 400 quarantine sites with a capacity of just under 38 000 beds across the country. #ECVisit23June

This not only assisted to dramatically reduce the spread of #COVID19, but it also gave us an opportunity to expand our health infra-structure and therefore we delayed the doubling time to 15 days during level five lockdown and it is now at around 12 days during.#ECVisit23June
After witnessing a doubling time of two days, we were compelled to institute a hard lockdown. #ECVisit23June
We can improve these numbers if we cooperate and work together. South Africans must adopt the necessary behavioural changes needed to keep our mortality rate low. #ECVisit23June
These figures are much lower than the 20% we had initially projected and represent a public health response that has placed emphasis on proactive and preventative medicine. #ECVisit23June

As it stands, South Africa has 2 888 patients who are in isolation in general ward, 262 patients who are in high care, 539 patients who are in ICU, 218 patients who are on ventilators and 566 patients who are on oxygen. #ECVisit23June

The models are  the models are, it is not the models that determine where we end up, it is our own conduct and determination to fight the pandemic that lends us to the situation we find ourselves in. #ECVisit23June
A few days after our first confirmed case, I made what appeared to be an unpopular statement…that it is possible that we could go up to 60-70% of our population becoming infected. #ECVisit23June

Our total recoveries, at 53 444, assures us that more than 50% people who have been infected have recovered and we contain to be optimistic that the number of recovered patients will continue to rise. #ECVisit23June

As we reported the total numbers of confirmed #COVID19 cases in South Africa, which are now at 101 590, it is also significant is that we have now seen a rapid rise in daily numbers of cases, of late exceeding 4000 a day. #ECVisit23June

I would like to take a moment to pay homage to Rev Dr. Elizabeth Mamisa Chabula-Nxiweni for the legacy of excellence and compassion she has embodied in health care, we hope this field hospital will come to represent all these virtues. #ECVisit23June
It is my wish that this initiative is the beginning of a lasting legacy that will positively impact the lives of our people for generations to come. #ECVisit23June
A total of 3 300 beds, along with the oxygen reticulation have been established in record time.#ECVisit23June

VW is a well known brand in this country: it is the largest German investment in SAand is a major contributor to foreign direct investment,technology transfer and skills  project is indeed a reflection of solidarity by two nations to save humanity.#ECVisit23June

This fight against #COVID19 has taken its toll on our people financially. This has also had an impact on their social lives. We therefore look forward to this multi sectoral MAC’s advice to government on how we can move forward to provide social and economic relief.- Dr J Phaahla
I’d like to also thank Minister Zulu for her guidance and support, we are going to continue to work together in this fashion and be supported by this MAC.  #MACLaunch
I am really pleased to be joining, you, Minister Zulu, in this partnership of Health and Social Development. This can only augur well for the prosperity of our nation. #MACLaunch

Minister Zulu has had her work cut out for her, steering the social relief ship during this national crisis. As a doctor who has witnessed first hand that ill health begins when there is a social injustice. #MACLaunch

As we re-opened the economy, we appreciate that behavioural change needs buy-in from communities, and community leaders.
I am pleased to be joining you Minister Zulu in this initiative.
It is important to acknowledge the role of civil society in this battle.
#MACLaunch

This MAC is inspired by you, fellow South Africans, who have made so many sacrifices. That collective discipline and cooperation helped us to flatten the curve and save many lives, it helped us balance our resources.
#MACLaunch
This MAC on Social Behaviour has been convened jointly by myself and the Minister of Social Development, Ms Lindiwe Zulu in the spirit of multi- sector collaboration. #MACLaunch

The world is going through what we are going through. Our hard won freedoms were to afford us the opportunity to be the masters of our own fate. As President Cyril Ramaphosa said, “South Africa,it is in your hands.” We can choose how this story is going to go.#MACLaunch #COVID19
We can turn the tide against this enemy. As a country we can maintain control over the Coronavirus. #COVID19 #MACLaunch

It has changed the way we do things: the way we dress, the way we we wash our hands, the way we greet or show affection. It has disrupted our social lives and threatens to sink economies. It has forced humanity to choose between life or external trappings. #MACLaunch

It is imperative that we do not fall into despair as we combat #COVID19. We can never be complacent, never found wanting. The Coronavirus has decimated some of the strongest health care systems and called on humanity to entirely reassess its way of living. #MACLaunch
We pay special respects to these young lives today and extend our condolences to the families and loved ones of our fallen compatriots.#MACLaunch

We too have lost young soldiers in the fight. Since the advent of the pandemic on our shores, we have lost 123 fellow South Africans 39 years or younger with 29 of those under the age of 30.#MACLaunch

Today, as a nation, as humanity, we face an unseen  enemy that knows no race, no religion, no border, no government, no king, no peasant. It only knows human, and how to get from one to the next one. #MACLaunch

We can choose how this story is going to  we are here to make that  are here to choose this as a story of emancipation.

A number of measures are being put in place to address the backlog of #COVID19 testing in Eastern Cape. #ECVisit12June
Thank you to the media. You have helped South Africans to understand this issue. We can defeat fake news which can dampen our efforts to fight #COVID19. #ECVisit12June
It is about Ubuntu - I am because of others. This is the request we have, as South Africans we are compassionate and we can work together during this time. #ECVisit12June

As government we need to work together, what the President has said for us to go into the districts and work with society to flatten the structure. Ultimately each and every South African must take responsibility. Its about you making sure that you are not the source of infection
Thank you to the provincial health teams, and all the managers in health across the country, who are working hard to resolve challenges. #ECVisit12June
I would like to thank and congratulate SAHPRA for the huge amount of work done to assess and validate prospective testing kits and other health products @SAHPRA1
There has to be stronger targetting now. We must make sure that everyone who needs to be tested or treated is able to get the service they need. #ECVisit12June

We have targeted Western Cape to deal with the backlog and we are happy to report turnaround time for tests in the Western Cape has been reduced to 24 hours. We are now focusing on this backlog in the Eastern Cape. #ECVisit12June

We have reached a landmark number of testing in both public and private labs. We are also trying to source more diagnostic test kits. We must commend all our workers in both public and private laboratories. We appreciate the work of the laboratory services. #ECVisit12June
SAHPRA is already working on the fast tracking of the agents that can be used to combat the virus. We have also noted that @WHO has discouraged the use of chloroquine. #ECVisit12June

People have also explored different ways of how we normally do certain things. We are appreciative of the community and religious leaders who are delaying the opening of their congregations. #ECVisit12June
As we move forward we are going to be seeing more cluster outbreaks, as people will be sitting together at work etc. #ECVisit12June

The frequent washing of hands and using sanitizer as well as wearing masks, is very important. The mask on its own is not adequate to stop contamination. Therefore all these behavioral changes need to be considered too. #ECVisit12June
10 000 community health workers are available throughout the country for a program to treat people who suffer from diseases like diabetes. #ECVisit12June
While we are concerned about #COVID19, there are other diseases out there that we must not neglect. The overall health of our people is important. #ECVisit12June

The Supply of chronic medication closer to people’s homes is a part of our plan. We are also starting a program to train healthcare workers to treat people with non communicable diseases.#ECVisit12June
While we are facing the challenge of #COVID19, we must strengthen our healthcare system. We must use #COVID19 to improve our services as we move towards the NHI. #ECVisit12June
It can be converted to an ambulance or even a mobile clinic. This is the kind of innovation we would like to encourage across all provinces. #ECVisit12June
We have been introduced to the motorcycle project and want to congratulate the MEC for the initiatives- we believe this is a pioneering project. #ECVisit12June
Next a viewing of the mobile clinics that will bring health care closer to communities. #ECVisit12June
Testing out one of the units now available as part of the scooter project! They have off-road capabilities and are  equipped with waterproofing and drip stands. #ECVisit12June
Today, we launch the Scooter Project in Eastern Cape. These multi-purpose units are extremely versatile and can transport patients or deliver medication in rural communities. #ECVisit12June

In East London this morning, receiving 200 range-topping walkie talkie devices from Altron Nexus. This secure communications device has a cross-country range and has endless advantages in SA's #COVID19 fight. #ECVisit12June

Western Cape is the epicentre of South Africa's #COVID19 epidemic. There are a number of interventions put in place to curb the spread of the virus. Check out some of the facilities now ready for #COVID19 cases. @WesternCapeGov

As of today, the cumulative number of confirmed #COVID19 cases is 58 568, the total number of recoveries to date are 33 252 and we have reached a milestone in testing,1 028 399 tests have been conducted cumulatively.
We have started implementing a tracking and tracing platform which we will announce in the next day or two. We will use it here in the Eastern Cape to catch up. #ECVisit11June

Today we have reached the landmark of 1 million tests that have been done in the public and private sector countrywide. At this point I want to pay tribute to all the laboratory staff as well as the Drs, nurses and healthcare workers. #ECVisit11June

There are challenges with tests but we must not underestimate the fact that we have carried out a lot of tests. The delay in a test should not undermine the treatment a person receives. #ECVisit11June
Teams in sub-districts will help us to  assist the elderly & those with co -morbidities. Treatment for other infections must continue (TB, diabetes, HIV etc) #ECVisit11June
We need to protect the senior citizens, we also need to be cautious with those people that have co-morbidities. A large number of the deaths were people with Co- morbities. #ECVisit11June
#COVID19 has exposed our challenges in the way we live and do our work. We need to address them. #ECVisit11June

We need to engage the communities and traditional leaders. We need to also deal with the issue of stigma. People need to disclose their symptoms and those that are positive need to disclose their status. #ECVisit11June
From the point of view of the report I’m comfortable that you are moving on the right track, just need to act with speed now. #ECVisit11June
Identifying cases and isolation are key. There is no short cut. We want to break the cycle of infection. #ECVisit11June

Leadership must be in the districts where the action is. We have welcomed the decision by the President. We need this kind of support. The closer we are together, the more helpful it will be. #ECVisit11June

The numbers in OR Tambo are increasing, and we are now looking at it as a hotspot. In reality we would like to see the districts divided into sub districts and focus on the particular areas. #ECVisit11June #FlatteningTheStructure

The numbers in the Eastern Cape are rising, whilst we know the numbers are increasing we’d like them to increase at a slower rate. The risk now is as we are moving to the lower levels, the cluster outbreaks are going to increase. #ECVisit11June
In lockdown we wanted to increase staffing. The provinces have done that. We are going out to see which doctors and nurses need to be employed. #ECVisit11June
We have to start adjusting to a new way of life, where every person protects themselves and those around them.#ECVisit11June
We need community stakeholders. The battle is now in the community. People need to take responsibility for the way they behave.#ECVisit11June

We need to change our behavior. The use of masks- a cloth mask is adequate, one just needs to wear it properly. Mask wearing alone, is not enough. Wash your hands regularly, sanitize and keep surfaces clean. All of this reduces infections. #ECVisit11June
This is not the time to be complacent. Some people have the wrong impression of easing the lockdown, they think you can behave anyhow now that level has  is not the case. #ECVisit11June
The numbers are going to continue to grow, our intention is not to stop the virus from spreading,but reducing the rate at which it does. #ECVisit11June
We are doing everything we can to support the provision of PPEs. We also want to thank all the stakeholders assisting. We need to work together as partners and fight a common fight. #ECVisit11June

We would like to encourage a closer working relationship between the staff and management as well as Labour and unions. If there is a shortage of PPE we need to communicate and manage it. #ECVisit11june

The cloth face masks need to be worn properly. It must not be in your pocket or hand, but needs to be covering your nose and mouth. We want to reserve the specialized masks for healthcare professionals. #ECVisit11June

We as health workers have been trained to deal with infections. It is important that we are protected when we do this. There are different levels of protection for different levels of exposure. #ECVisit11June

It is important to make sure that everyone is well protected and it is also important for people to understand the level of protection they require, so people don’t demand PPE that is not suitable for their work environment. #ECVisit11June
The public and media  needs to be kept informed of what we are doing. It is important for them to also see what is being done. #ECVisit11June

We have sent you a number of doctors from Cuba and the military health. It is time for action, it is time for movement. #ECVisit11June #COVID19SouthAfrica

Its now at a community level. We want to see behavioural change in communities. Our message today is we need to keep a  must contain the disease, make sure people are treated when they need treatment, and also strengthen the message of behavioural change.#ECVisit11June

We need to entrench our sub-district models where we deal with the containment more intensely. We need to do things differently. That message has to go out from community leaders.#ECVisit11June #COVID19SouthAfrica

How much of this crisis will be able to help us to deal with long term solutions for healthcare in our country? We are going to need the infrastructure and more doctors for the NHI. #ECVisit11June #COVID19SouthAfrica
I am pleased to hear the municipality will be donating some land here and we are going to discuss plans for this. #ECVisit11June #COVID19SouthAfrica
There are challenges with staffing here. The district manager will stay here and give us feedback later when I return from Mthatha.

We are looking at the preparedness for the surge in #COVID19. I am happy to see the work done in this regard, the extensions, refurbishments etc. are all encouraging.
We must continue treatment for diabetes, TB, heart disease and mental health. These were present before #COVID19 & will be there afterwards too. #ECVisit11June #COVID19SouthAfrica

We have a crisis that is forcing us to fill all the gaps we can find, in terms of infrastructure, staff, management. We must ensure people find the services capable of dealing with an influx of patients.#ECVisit11June #COVID19SouthAfrica

As Covid-19 cases spiked in the Eastern Cape last month, we deployed medical experts to assist the provincial team. Dr Kerrigan McCarthy led the team of experts which looked closely at cluster outbreaks in the province.
It is important to raise understanding of what protocols need to be in place in schools. Every child must wear a cloth mask, which can be made at home.

The purpose of creating “hotspots” is to be able to take all the measures that are necessary to control the rise of infections. Every sub district in each metro in the Western Cape that has been identified will have wall to wall surveillance by experts.

Anyone is welcome to express their views, but if there are inaccuracies in what they say, that must be corrected. This is a major challenge for South Africa. There is no need to politicise it or grand stand it.
Community testing is crucial to understanding the spread of the #COVID19 pandemic. It also means our healthcare professionals are able to respond approprately to the spread of the coronavirus.
The unity of South Africans and respecting the guidelines are going to be important now in our fight against #Covid_19
Routine health services should be fully opened and run full services with attention to catch up on childhood immunisation, contraceptive services, antenatal care, diagnosis and care for HIV.
We may introduce additional measures in hotspots to contain the spread of the virus.

We have good cooperation across the provinces. Each hotspot must have its own team of  hospitals are important. They will ensure people with mild symptoms are in quarantine and prevent the spread of the infection.
If combined action in hotspots does not work to contain the spread of infection, we will then consider lockdown of the area.

Teams of experts will work in hotspots to make sure they look after the health of individuals in those areas. Experts will concentrate on a very small catchment area. They will try and keep as many people away from hospitals by getting them treated by teams of GPs and nurses.
Behavioural changes remain , social distancing and wearing masks remain standard measures to contain the spread of the  for vigilance have been identified.
A district level alert system will help to monitor those who need to practice extra caution. Emerging hot spots must be watched vigilantly. We must focus on the emergence of new infections.

We need to make sure there are stringent measures according to each district. We are asking for vigilence and close monitoring in areas identified as hotspots. There must be containment measures for people with co-morbidities.
The Cuban reinforcement team has been deployed in all provinces.  The military brigade will also be deployed to assist.

The number of hospitalised patients  is highest in the Western Cape. We are going to see more hospitilisation in all the provinces. We have quarantine sites planned in all provinces, so those with mild symptoms can be placed here.
We must focus of contact tracing, 44042 contacts have been identified through tracing. To date 93% of contacts have been monitored in South Africa.
33% of tests have been done in Gauteng. The numbers of tests in all provinces is quite large.

We have done 59 677 tests so far and almost 12 922 yesterday. 
2999 of yesterday’s tests have been from community testing.
The number of deaths is showing an upward slope, with the most numbers in the Western Cape.
We are now dealing with internal transmissions. We have seen a 25% increase in positive cases in the last week.
Flattening the curve is an everyday effort. We need people to be aware of the dangers of #COVID19
The lockdown helped to flatten the curve and gave us time to prepare health services.

There has been a lot of speculation as to whether the hard lockdown has worked to hinder the rapid spread of #COVID19 in SA. Let us look at some of the accomplishments made in this time to flatten the curve and build our healthcare system.

Farewell comrade, Farewell brother. We are sending you to all our heroes, you’ve also been a hero. You’ve been a revolutionary, a patriot and a people’s Dr. #RememberingDrClarenceMini

We work with a whole group of medical experts with different views. We remain confident that the approaches taken are for the best. We need to work together and be strong. We must hold each other’s hands until we see this outbreak through. #RememberingDrClarenceMini
I think the work done by the President has been outstanding. He is always ready to listen. He wants to know the scientific basis of our decisions #RememberingDrClarenceMini
We want you to be strong. To the children, you will forever carry the dignity, brilliance, professionalism of your dad with you. You are fortunate to carry his name as your dad.
We need to accept that the whole world is going through a difficult time and a lot of people are going to get #COVID19
To Nancy, thank you for the love and the care that you demonstrated for your husband. #RememberingDrClarenceMini
The NHI has to come, by the time it comes this aspect of government medical schemes needs to change.#RememberingDrClarenceMini
The quality of our health services is indicative of the dignity of our people. #RememberingDrClarenceMini

When we needed to sit down and re orientate the NHI back in 2009, he was the man we would call. He was very passionate about it. A man of  integrity, who never changed his beliefs.#RememberingDrClarenceMini

He took over the medical association which was collaborating with the government, & he changed that organization. He became a leader among the new transformed medical assiciation. #RememberingDrClarenceMini
He was a man that believed in our nation and the bright future ahead of us. #RememberingDrClarenceMini
He was handsome, confident, friendly and kind. A man who was a real patriot. He loved our country and people, and he proved it. He was a true revolutionary. #RememberingDrClarenceMini
He was always dignified and formal, friendly and kind. He loved our country. He was a true revolutionary
I did not come today as a minister, i came today as a friend. #RememberingClarenceMini

We are also making preparations for President Ramaphosa’s visit on the 15th.
We’ve also agreed that we will look at further collaboration with the private sector (Hospitals, specialists, practitioners etc.)
We are going to look at what additional support the province needs. We will be reinforcing the team. We will deploy the Cuban specialists, as well as additional medical practitioners.
This means it’s going to require that these areas will need stricter restrictions.
To break the cycle you have to ensure that whoever is positive is isolated and whoever is associated is quarantined.
Anyone who is positive must be isolated and this is happening. Now we are going to ensure that everyone who is positive will be hospitalized.

We are however sharing capacity. Public and private sector laboratories are working together, But the only thing I want to say to the private sector is that I don’t like their price (we’ll discuss that at the right level)
In relation to the issue of tests, I’ve called around both public and private laboratories - they are all suffering from the constraints of the availability of test kits.
There are a number of areas with cluster outbreaks. We can confirm that number of daily testing has increased. However there is a shortage of reagents and test kits globally.
We need to ensure that we are able to test our community and find those that are positive. In the case of the WC, it’s been 24-30% of the specimens come from the WC
The mortalities here are associated with age and co morbidities, like they are in the rest of the country.
The picture that has been painted by the epidemiologists and NICD is clear in indicating the spread, the age, gender etc are similar across the country.
I have received a briefing from seven experts in the province and i am satisfied with the plans put in place.
We urge that health workers be given the flu vaccine. We want them to be well trained and well protected, as the frontline workers.

There is a need for us to prioritise our healthworkers, to ensure they are well trained and well protected. We have formed an Occupational Health and Safety Committee to work together with public and private sector, amongst the issues to deal with is the issue of PPE.
We want to thank all health workers most profusely and sincerely. We want to thank police and army as well. We appreciate everyone and their hard work all the time.
Almost 50% of the positive cases are in the Western Cape. This is a matter of concern to us. We thought it was important to come and just share on the concerns

Visit to Rustenburg in the North West to receive a donation of PPEs from Sibanye Stillwater & Old Mutual. An opportunity to pay tribute to health workers & address some issues, among them, field hospitals & the umhlonyane herb.

Madagascar herbs: We received a call from the government of Madagascar, who asked for help with scientific  scientists would be able to assist with this  will only get involved in a scientific analysis of the herb. We are not at that point yet.
We must be able to maintain a balance. It is a battle we face every day.#COVID19 may be here for another two years.

We have a total of 511 health workers who have tested positive. 26 of them are hospitalized & we have lost 2 of them, a doctor and a nurse. 149 health workers have recovered. The contribution of the protective gear is therefore very important.

All mine workers must be screened, and where necessary, must be screened. It is more helpful to be proactive. We can save staff and the whole mine if we screen miners. We encourage all mining companies to work with the provincial government on this.
I pay tribute to al our health workers. They have done a great job. We bow our heads and salute you. We appreciate all the work you are doing. Both public and private health workers are one.
We can now spot where the problems are coming from. We have learned lessons from other countries & we have an advantage.
There is no contradiction here. Life is complex. In terms of our scientific focus, we were able to push the peak. If we were to prolong the lockdown, it would not have delayed the peak substantially.

At the end of the day, everything is about people. It is only when our people are healthy, that we will have a thriving economy. Improving our economy starts with the good health of our people. Good nutrition, hygiene and sanitation are at the core of our people being healthy.

Our health workers are like soldiers who go to war. They must be well trained, well armed and well protected. We want them to be confident that they are well trained, that they understand how they don’t get infected, and how they protect others.
We have seen the numbers increasing. We said that many of us will get the infection. Our role has been to slow down the rate at which the infection gets to us.
I am pleased that most areas have gone all out to open field hospitals. This contribution adds to our facilities.
The main message is about partnership. Everyone must play a role in the fight against #COVID19. Our partners today are Sibanye Stillwater and Old Mutual.
The pressure of having to look for food and the loss of income are factors which have led to people breaching the lockdown regulations.
We’d like to thank the media for their consistency & hard work in making sure important messages reach our people across the country.

The health department recommends cloth masks to help contain the spread of the coronavirus. You can make your own mask at home, with or without a sewing machine. 
#ClothFaceMask (2/2)
After the lockdown has ended, we need to continue with social distancing, regular washing of hands and mask wearing.

Cloth masks: they can be effective also noting there is also short supply of surgical/n95 masks therefore not necessary to wear unless you’re in a highly infective environment(Frontline healthworkers.)

Screening: We ask questions and check temperature and for presence of symptoms. (We start with screening.) If you’re displaying symptoms then you are tested- this is where a specimen is taken from the back of your throat.
I think we need to appreciate all the hard work the health workers are doing during this time. A large number have been assisted and screened. Those displaying symptoms are being tested.
So far the experience recorded is once you’ve had the infection, one does not get reinfected.
Most of the cases in Western Cape are in Cape Town Metro, Same as in Johannesburg, Durban and Mangaung. (The Metros)
If you go to a private Dr/ private lab for a test you will pay. If the recommendation came from a public hospital you will not need to pay for testing.

When we reduce large gatherings (Church, Football, etc) all of this reduced the spread. The number of new infections is not increasing as much as it would’ve been. The borders have also been closed preventing new imported infections.

On the #COVID19 situation, the disease is new, so we act as we learn. As we speak now we have records of research. People who exhale air while wearing a mask that are infected reduce the spread of the infection.

KZN has a high death toll, more than 6 patients have died from one institution. We need to get into why this is so. We have now decided the hospital needs to be closed down and an investigation needs to be launched.

Cloth face mask recommendations: #MasksCOVID19 #ClothFaceMask @COVID_19_ZA @HealthZA
The unity that has been shown during this time has begun to show green shoots. It is possible that we may be able to buck the trend and chart our own path.
The meetings were constructive and we appreciate the cooperation of all those involved.
Not everyone will need the full gear of PPEs. There are guidelines in place, and these will be followed.

We met with a large number of unions. We were able to agree on the issue that protection of staff is the most important, no memeber of staff will be forced to go to work without the respective gear that they would need in their designated position

We have had successful initaives with the business fraternity. I am able now on a dashboard to see the level of stock. We can check the country’s readiness on PPEs, and we can order stock from other countries.

With a mask We can protect the next person, Dont keep touching the mask, Don’t keep removing the mask and Treat the mask as potenially infective. Ensure regular washing of the mask, we will make the guidelines available.

Use of masks
We recommend widespread use of cloth masks. Individuals can make their own masks. There shouldn’t be a need for everyone to be wearing surgical/N95 masks. Let’s reserve those for the frontline workers treating patients.
We must have a new culture of social distancing and no hugs, kissing or shaking of hands
Contact tracing, screening and test referring will be our strongest way going forward
We want to call on everyone to cooperate with the screening processes.
A large number of tracers are  are 13488 tracers
Contact tracing is important. We need to go around them to test. We need to scale up the screening of patients in various communities. 456074 people have been screened thus far in provinces.
We are checking hospital admissions. There has been no explosion. The numbers of deaths do not show a huge explosion.

One person can change the trend of infection. Internal transimission is slowed due to the lockdown, however when we open those pockets that’s when the problem will come, so we will anticipate a few more peaks.

We have now parted ways with the countries with rapid spread. For South Africans let’s be ambitious and say together we want to part ways with the trends of the west and Europe. I’m not saying we are there, but let’s try as South Africans to unite and follow the leadership.

If you look at the numbers, we all start with the same numbers (an increase of 42%) With the lockdown we have stopped the importation if the virus. We have aborted the immediate peak and are no longer following the rest of the countries (as you can see in the turn of our line)
There is a lot of good lessons in the way China has dealt with it. The leadership of @WHO needs to be commended. We want to say that we support the DG of WHO for the leadership they have given.
Looking at the impact of lockdowns in other countries. The red line depicts the exponential increase in the way it is happened
We want to thank The President, NCC and Ministers. It is important to know there is scientific basis and support for the extension of the lockdown announced by the President.

Breakdown of Deaths
GP 3
WC 6
Kzn 12
FS 3                                                        it is important to note, Except for two cases, Deceased are ages 63 upwards. We are also seeing people with co existing diseases succumb quicker
Our healthworkers are fighting in a heroic way and number of recoveries is 410 people
As at today number of confirmed #COVID19 cases are 2003, the number of tests conducted are        73 028 and the number of deaths is now 24
The most important thing is to acknowledge the leadership of President Ramaphosa.
People have taken heed of the President’s call and are staying at home.
Today is a special day. I pay tribute to all church leaders and congregations for helping us in the fight against #COVID19
The issues that brought me to the province, was to get the briefing with regards to the private hospitals and the report from the province.
Our meeting with private hospitals has been very fruitful and there is a clear understanding. We will be met with cooperation going forward we will handle this together
There is clear cooperation with the private hospitals and private labs. We are operating as one system, both public and private sectors.
There is a particular responsibility of government over particular resources.
We should be able as government to determine the price that we need to pay. It needs to be understood that government has an obligation for the whole nation.
The relationship between the public & private health sectors is important. We need to pool together on the basis of need.
Provincial Dept. of Health must investigate the infections . We want to know exactly what happened
There is no problem of compliance here. As of 2 days ago 66 people were tested, of that 48 were staff.

As far as St Augustines in concerned, the hospital has been closed. There are no new outpatients. The fumigation process has started. The hospital needs to contain the patients within and monitor the Patients Under Investigation.
There have been concerns about a number of hospitals. We looked at a hospital in Ladysmith, and this week, St Augustines. Other hospitals are also being monitored.
Compliance is expected. It is mandatory for private hospitals to cooperate.
When we get complaints, the health dept will step in. We do not need the authority of the private hospital to step in. We are the service provider & regulator, so we can step in.
All private hospitals will adhere to Standard operating procedures and clinical guidelines of NICD
Meetings with private sector included national group leaders. The way we are responding to the pandemic is that public & private sector must work as one team.

Happy Easter weekend to you all.

Get your children involved in the fight to contain Covid-19, says Soweto-based paediatrician Dr Yazeed A Seedat.
As stock comes in, we will start preparing for the period after. So we are preparing ahead. We don’t even have a hundred people in hospital at the moment countrywide.

We have not had enough patients to exhaust the pre-existing stock. Everyone is anxious. Healthcare workers are nervous. But it is possible for them to point out where the shortages are, so we can move stock around.
The number of patients who are being treated, are slowly recovering. Mass testing has also started in all provinces.

We hope the fumigation process will start soon there. We have also assigned specialists there. We must always be on the lookout. The infection can seep in from any institution. We must now trace all the contacts. It is a matter of serious concern and we are dealing with it.

We are concerned about developments at St Augustine’s Hospital. 66 tested positive over the past few days. About 48 of them are staff. The Provincial dept. is engaging the hospital, with a view to closing parts of the hospital down

As at today, the total number of confirmed #COVID19 cases is 1749. There is also another death, bringing the total to 13 deaths. It was a male who had stage 4 prostrate cancer at Parklands Hospital. We convey our condolences to the family of the deceased
On behalf of the government & unions & all my staff, thank you to the Motsepe Foundation.
Health professionals must take all the precautions from being infected. Our staff are our primary soldiers in this fight.
No member of staff will be forced to work in an area where they do not feel adequately protected. We need our staff to be protected and to be safe.

With regard to NEHAWU: We are saying we have enough stock for a few weeks. With additional stock coming in, we will have enough for another 6-8 weeks. We met other health unions. We will show them our plans on PPE’s.
We have not completely run out of equipment. There are different provisions for different areas.
We want to assure all unions and staff that our healthcare workers’ safety are of paramount importance.
Two key areas of fighting this infection. One is lockdown,sanitation, hygiene. The second is to make sure the sick get better. Here our health workers are key and in the frontline.
Stock will last 6-8 weeks. We will then work on being self-sufficient.
Our government’s relationship with India & China has helped these consignments to come through to our shores.
The partnership between us and the private sector has been beneficial. Expect more consignments to come in because of this partnership.
Thank you for your swift action and generous donation, Patrice & Precious.
PPE’s are an important contribution. We check our stock every week with manufacturers and suppliers. This stock was intercepted. We were able to pay upfront using the Motsepe foundation’s donation.
We are excited & encouraged to receive a donation from the Motsepe Foundation. Top of the list is 200 thousand surgical masks.

We are still awaiting confirmation on the two KZN deaths. I raised them because you have heard about them.

The whole world is facing constraints when it comes to PPE. We are doing everything when it comes to this matter. For now we have enough, we have reached out to other countries for additional support too
When it comes to modeling. I always fear when we state a projection it is taken as fact, so I avoid these. For planning it is a good tool, but for media it can be distorted when reporting.

On what we have asked the provinces to do. Everything has been put in place. When we started we didn’t know that the outbreak would be highest in Gauteng, Western Cape and Free State, this virus is a moving target.
Yesterday we reported 7 deaths, today is a further 2 ... that brings the total number of deaths to 9

We have seen the enthusiasm and preparedness by the colleagues. We are in a good course. The key however is how we make sure the lockdown works. We need to flatten the curve and ensure that when flu season starts we need to be ready before that time comes
We have indicated as well that whilst we have a lockdown it’s too early to make any postulations on what should happen regarding the lockdown.
We have approached the President to request reinforcement from a number of countries such as Cuba and China
We had an opportunity to ask fairly pertinent questions for example there are differences between us and them (we have a number of citizens with TB and HIV)
They indicated that 20% of their patients become serious and of that 5% are admitted to ICU. They also indicated the importance of testing and screen at an early stage

Earlier we had a very interesting and informative discussion with experts from WHO and in Shanghai. They took us through the case definition, how they dealt with the testing and manifestation of the virus in patients. They also went into detail on in patient treatment
We would like to convey our condolences to the families and friends of these individuals. We would also like to thank the health workers who are working tirelessly every day
1505 positive cases of today, that means there are 43 new cases. We also want to report sadly 2 more deaths from KZN - An 80 year old male and 81 year old female.
We must address the issue of additional beds, so we are prepared.

We have been discussing since President has announced, that we are going to roll out the testing. We have identified  areas of priority. We are ready to give additional support and re-inforcement to the areas that need assistance.

The Western Cape has now seen a number of cases. They have shown me the geo mapping. The importance of this tracking is beyond one patient is the contacts by association which allows you to look into the social dynamics of the infected person. This is significant in the spread

In terms of recovery we are close to 45.
We reported 5 deaths,we are still waiting for clarification and verification on 2. We will keep you updated.
We are ready to fight, we are prepared. We must not be lulled into complacency.
I’ve been pleased to see the number of patients have been reduced in the hospitals. So we are calling on all hospitals to do the same
The President has said that he wants to see the beds being made available. Here we can see they’re available. I’m very encouraged and would like to say keep up the good work

We want to say to our people we can fight this infection. We can defeat it. We need to flatten the curve. That is going to be very important for us. People stay at home when asked to , create social distancing, wear masks  and wash/disinfect hands regularly
The total number of positive cases is now 1462. There is a restraint in numbers which we think is due to the lockdown.
We want the team to keep up the good work

We would like to say thank you to the Premier, the MEC, the HOD and all others involved. During the day we visited the Operations centre and the infectious disease control team. I’m impressed by the tracing team who have almost located all the contacts on their list
Dr Pierce introduces a concept that they will roll out at Universitas- A peep unit, which is utilized by military. They are also able to produce 300 peep masks per day.

We are forward planning,in order to be prepared rather than not having a plan in place

Right now we don’t have a crisis. So we are preparing and focusing on what might go wrong. Whilst looking into the future we must not confuse you into thinking that the worst is actually going to happen. We need to have a balance
We are not in a position to update on the deaths at the moment. We will update at the next briefing
Those who aren’t able to self-isolate we will try to assist by moving them elsewhere.

There are certain precautions to take when wearing a mask. We are trying to help and improve the situation. We are assisting where we can. People must try to ensure good social distance however this isn’t always possible so a mask can be worn in this instance
We are in touch with SADAC Ministers - as we speak here today, the NICD is a reference for all AFRICAN countries
We will do everything to ensure our health workers are protected. We must also work together with community leaders and groups to protect our communities from any criminals or charlatans.
Just remember the virus has no boundaries. It doesn’t mean if you’ve dealt with it now there won’t be another wave. Just look at China

We are not making an exaggeration when we say the calm before the storm. We are saying if you let go of these conditions and when you see the flu season coming, it may change this. The issue is , we must not be complacent
On Friday we will have meeting with experts, clinicians and MEC’s as well as a video conference with experts from China.

Early testing and early identification and early isolation is an important issue. Transparency and sharing of information is very important. For the community to be able to fight this. They need to be armed with facts. We will only fight this with FACTS , not FAKE NEWS

There are things we need to decide earlier on. Amongst those are to reduce academic debates. On what has been proven, we must start implementing. There is no perfect plan in a battle. To try and reach out to as many people as possible to test them
Many countries have used the PCR. Many have used rapid test kits, to good effect. We are evaluating the latter. Combination of testing does not exist in any part of the world. We want to create that.
Look at China & South Korea, & the US. It is the conduct of the community that matters. Take this seriously. Don’t panic. Go out for essentials only.
This disease affects us all, Black, White, Rich or Poor. We need to be united as a nation and focused when addressing this issue. Not that we should panic, but we must not be complacent
The message by President Ramaphosa for people to stay at home is very important, the message of washing your hands is important, the message of good hygiene is important.
We are saying to everyone, that they need to move at a faster pace. We plan for the worst even though we hope for the best. It’s important to remain focused and be courageous
All clinics and hospitals will be asked to provide a daily tally. This will help us ensure we have enough stock of all the resources we need
We will be encouraging all the clinics and hospitals to update daily. All treatment and PPE’s we are asking that the departments of the various provinces must try to procure.

We have approached Presidency to get other countries such as China and Cuba to assist. Cuba- Their community and district health model works when reaching out to many communities to ensure good cover.
We need experienced professionals on the ground, who will take decsions quickly

Rapid test kits will allow us to test and get results quickly
-these tests will come soon
We need each person to make it a personal fight to save our nation.

We need every plan to be put in place. My plea to the colleagues was no1 setting of the mobile units to be set up. These vehicles must go to where we have already identified as hotspots. People who are symptomatic must be tested first

Next month the flu season will start and these will flood our hospitals and clinics. This small growth in numbers means we maybe currently experiencing the calm before the sto. There may not be many warnings before the pounding descends
Those on ARV’s and chronic treatment need to stick to their regimen.
We need to engage all community leaders. Spread the message of stay at home and the importance of hygiene must be made more emphatically

Those people who might have mild symptoms in poorer areas may not seek assistance immediately. Our testing criteria is reactive and restrictive. This means we don’t have a true picture. Although we are talking about 45000 tests, this is too low, given the size of the population.

I ascribe this reduction in the rate of increase due to: closing the borders, enforcing quarantine on inbound travelers, lockdown has slowed internal transmission by reducing the spread during large gatherings and overcrowded transport routes eg Trains, buses and taxis
44202 people have been tested, largely in private Laboratories and Just over 6000 performed in public health NHLS.

CLINICAL OBSERVATIONS WE HAVE MADE THAT ARE OF CONCERN:
1. The infection of people with underlying concomitant diseases is increasing. This is well illustrated by the COVID-19 patient that has passed away in the Western Cape.
Overwhelming as circumstances may be, we ask you to keep up the fight. This is only the beginning and your commitment assures us that we will overcome.

We urge them to remain courageous & focused. We also want to assure all our health workers in the country, who remain in frontline of this pandemic, as @HealthZA & government as a whole, will do everything in our powers to provide support required for them to execute their duties
therefore want to acknowledge and appreciate all our doctors, nurses and all the health workers who were treating these patients. We salute them for their dedication in the service of the nation.
In this instance, doctors and all health workers involved exercised clinical judgment and took extra precaution in managing this patient. We support this approach.

This is common practice, medical doctors often make a diagnosis based on a clinical presentation and physical examination of a patient. They then conduct further tests to confirm or disprove the diagnosis.
As a clinician myself, I want reassure them that making such a diagnosis on presentation is line with our plea to them to keep a high index of suspicion so as not to miss a diagnosis of COVID-19.

I have been informed that the health workers that managed this patient have been debriefed and counselled. I am aware that the public interest around COVID-19 may end up making them feel like they did not perform their duties with outmost care.
This therefore means there is only one confirmed death caused by COVID-19 in South Africa.

The clinical picture was suggestive of COVID-19 & therefore a test was conducted. Her labresults have since been received at 17:20 and were confirmed negative. Her immediate family was also tested and they are also negative. She is therefore no longer considered a COVID-19 case.

. At the time of presentation she was hypoxic. She was intubated and transferred to hospital during the early hours of this morning, (ie 27 March 2020 at 3am). On arrival in ICU, she was declared dead

The second patient who died was a suspected case based on her clinical presentation. The clinicians who were treating her have reported to us that this was a 28 year old female who had presented at the hospital in respiratory distress.

REPORTED DEATHS:
This morning we reported 2 deaths had occurred as a result of COVID-19 virus. The 1sr patient was a 48 year old female who tested positive for COVID-19 on the 23rd March 2020. She was suffering from pulmonary embolism. This means she had an underlying disease.
The total number of tests conducted to date is 28 537.

Watch for signs and symptoms of #COVID19 #CoronaVirus
So if you see someone is coughing, you can just stand at a bit of a distance. Also when going to the bathroom, it is important to wash your hands
The other thing you need to understand , to get this infection you need to be in a really short distance of the infected person. If you are more than 1-1.5metres my droplets won’t reach you

All you do is use a tissue to cover your mouth and nose when coughing/sneezing. If you don’t hav one nearby, you cough onto your elbow or use a cloth/handkerchief. That reduces the infection spread to the next person. The next thing to do is wash your hands with soap and water
So either someone will cough or sneeze next to you and then you can inhale the droplets and get the virus or it can be in your hands and you touch someone else and spread the virus

Droplet infection is this, while I’m busy talking to you I’m throwing out some droplets from the mouth. When I sneeze the same thing happens and when I cough too. If someone has tears, it can also come from the tears
What is important for us is to demystify and make people understand how we can defeat it. It’s very simple: this virus spreads through what we call droplet infection
It was a matter of a time before people were infected in South Africa. All the countries will have someone with the virus. There is no way we are going to stop it

China has managed to deal with the infection. Although they have many people that are sick , they have fewer now that are getting infected. That means that other countries can also do something to reduce the spread
This is going to be a brief meeting , just to raise awareness about the Coronavirus and to explain to people
ZweliMkhize: Uzoba mfishane lomhlangano, sihlabe umkhosi wokuxwayisa. Ukuthi manihlangana nabantu nibazise ukuthi siyibhekile Inkinga ye Corona. Ayiyimbi kakhulu ngoba siyibona komabonakude.

MINISTER #ZweliMkhize BRIEFS PARLIAMENT ON THE RESPONSE TO THE CORONAVIRUS OUTBREAK #COVID19

The DA and any other members of parliament will be advised of the date of the visit that is being arranged through the Chairperson of the Health Portfolio Committee and the Health Department will support MPs to fulfill their oversight role.

The Minister of Health also welcomes any inputs, constructive criticism and suggestions to improve the state of preparedness but take exception to dramatic statements made seemingly with the sole intention of politicizing a matter of serious public health concern.
The Department reiterates it’s commitment to transparency by making relevant information on the developments and preparations publicly available as it has done since the outbreak of the corona virus
It is selfish for the DA to play destructive opposing role to any initiative by government, even on such sensitive matters, at the expense of our people.

The DA must decide whether it will use its energies to grandstand and score cheap political points or work together with the Department of Health and government as whole to ensure that South Africa is safe.

The DA’s statement appears to be opportunistic, meant to create havoc and confusion during a sensitive period when all South Africans are suppose to be working hand in hand to ensure that we improve our preparedness and mitigate any infection risk for Coronavirus each day.

It must therefore be appreciated that this has put an added burden to the staff on the ground. It is important for all South African, especially public representatives to be mindful of the abnormal circumstances that are imposed by this situation.

On top of that, If the Port Health staff identifies a passenger who in their view requires further examination, they are now obliged to identify all other passengers that are seated in close proximity of that particular individual to ensure contact tracing.
on arrival, analyse the questionnaires filled by every passenger to assess the risk and conduct temperature screening of each and every passenger on board even before they disembark.

This is meant to avoid piecemeal inspections that may disrupt day to day operations. Especially taking to account that Port Health staff is not only processing large numbers of inbound travelers but are now required to be more vigilant in conducting inspections inside aircrafts,
On receiving these requests, he immediately contacted the Chairperson of the Portfolio Committee, Dr Sibongiseni Dhlomo to assist him in coordinating a group visit for all MPs who are interested.

In the past week the Minister has been made aware that various members of parliament, including the DA, have requested to conduct an inspection of the screening facilities at OR Tambo International airport.
The Minister of Health, Dr Zweli Mkhize rejects the DA’s sensational statement alleging that members of parliament were blocked from inspecting Coronavirus screening at OR Tambo.
*STATEMENT BY MINISTER OF HEALTH IN RESPONSE TO DA’S MISCHIEVOUS STATEMENT*

Accompanied by Deputy Minister Dr. Joe Phaahla and ADG Dr Pillay during the National Health Insurance(NHI)workshop at Garden Court OR Tambo Internatonal Airport, Gauteng Province. South Africa. 02/03/2020. Siyabulela Duda

#ZweliMkhize:  We understand that both Algeria and Nigeria have infections that have no history of travel to China- they seem to have originated from Italy.  #COVID19

#ZweliMkhize: South Korea has rapidly rising COVID-19 cases. They have over 2000 cases and 13 deaths. The City of Daegu, 300km from Seoul, seems to be the epicenter. We do have South Africans in this area #COVID19

#ZweliMkhize: We are concerned that when we first reported this matter  there were 4500 cases reported largely in China. Today the coronavirus has spread to 50 countries world wide with devastating consequences #COVID19

#ZweliMkhize: Whilst it can never be possible to predict what will happen in South Africa if the virus were to be introduced to our territory, it is a useful exercise to survey the current global status and start to formulate projections that can help us guide public policy.
#ZweliMkhize: The final day of quarantine is denoted by all members testing negative for Coronavirus. The members would then be given the final counseling and then granted leave to depart #COVID19
#ZweliMkhize:It is important to adhere and respect the processes as it’s not about you or a story, it is about the safety of all South Africans #COVID19
#ZweliMkhize: Should someone develop symptoms they would be immediately isolated for further testing #COVID19
#ZweliMkhize: Legal action will be taken against any individual that goes against the stipulated regulations in relation to quarantine #COVID19
#ZweliMkhize: The entire quarantine period will be 21 days duration to allow for arrival and phased exit. #COVID19
#ZweliMkhize: There will be a “no mans land” strip to accommodate the collection of goods whereby there is zero contact between the deliverers and the collectors.#COVID19
#ZweliMkhize: no family members, friends or associates of those under quarantine may visit the Zone.#COVID19
#ZweliMkhize: Those under quarantine will not be allowed to exit the perimeter but will be allowed to move freely within the perimeter, we will be discouraging group meetings. #COVID19
#ZweliMkhize: There will be a perimeter line that will be guarded by the military. Within that perimeter the area will be declared a no entry zone and a no flight zone #COVID19

#ZweliMkhize: 
The nature of quarantine exercise is to isolate a group of COVID negative people who’ve been exposed to a high risk environment,remove them from that high risk environment,and then allow the incubation period to lapse before being integrated into society. #COVID19
#ZweliMkhize: All support staff coming into direct contact with the repatriates will also fall into the quarantine protocol #COVID19
#ZweliMkhize: There will be a Multi-Disciplinary Medical Team on-board the aircraft that will be responsible for pre- and inflight screening and medical care. #COVID19

#ZweliMkhize: The Repatriation Process is implemented in three phases namely Evacuation, Quarantine ad Re-unification. We are guided by the WHO guidelines and the relevant South African laws and policy framework.
 #COVID19
#ZweliMkhize: We are making a special appeal to the families who may have relatives in Wuhan to contact DIRCO at 012 351 1754 and 012 351 1756,  and  #COVID19

#ZweliMkhize: Following the President’s directive for the repatriation of asymptomatic South African citizens in Wuhan City, where the epicenter of the outbreak is, such contingency plans are now being effected as a matter of extreme urgency. #COVID19

#ZweliMkhize: We gave a directive that every citizen must be frequently contacted directly personally and their concerns recorded. This has enabled government to properly evaluate their needs. #COVID19
ZweliMkhize: We must commend DIRCO and the embassy staff as well as Chinese authorities for assisting to locate our citizens in China #COVID19
#ZweliMkhize: As at 26 February 121 people have been tested for Coronavirus and all the results were negative #COVID19

#ZweliMkhize: There is ongoing screening of travelers in particular from China.
#sabcnews

#ZweliMkhize: We are in daily contact with the embassy in Japan, the cruise liner and the two citizens who tested positive for the virus and are being treated in Japan.
They will be free to return to the country once they test negative.

The Minister will also engage nurses at the hospital whom he regards as the backbone of health service delivery, particularly as government looks to strengthening the primary health care model in preparation for the National Health Insurance.

The successful placement of all medical interns is seen as a big step in the right direction as the country and particularly the North West aggressively seek to reduce shortages of doctors and increase patient-doctor contact.
In addition the Minister will also engage doctors from the Cuban Alumni Association of South Africa which has the largest concentration of membership in the North West.

We are acutely aware of the urgency of the situation of short staffing in public facilities and are actively pursuing full placement despite the extreme economic constraints the fiscus faces.

In accordance with the Presidential Health Compact the Department of a Health remains committed to the top prioritization of Human Resources for Health and to ensure that all qualified doctors in the country are placed this year.

Internship and Community Service are statutory posts and hence it is compulsory for the Department to place those who qualify. Fully qualified independent practitioners shall be subject to normal recruitment processes.

The Department wishes to remind all job seekers that due recruitment processes remain in place when when making enquiries or applying for work in the public sector. No advertisements for employment are made through social media but through official government gazettes.
